a75_case_summary: Icelandic hotel company processed employee sickness absence data by displaying a list in communal kitchen area; DPA found this violated security requirements for sensitive health data under Icelandic Data Protection Act; Controller ordered to establish proper procedures for employee data processing; No fine imposed but compliance order issued with January 2020 deadline.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that Landspítali relied on an outdated impact assessment from border screening that did not cover the processing scenario where Icelandic Genetics employees had access to patient names and ID numbers. A new data protection impact assessment should have been conducted before transferring operations to Icelandic Genetics' office.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA audited Landspítali hospital's transfer of COVID-19 testing operations to Icelandic Genetics' office. The DPA found the hospital relied on an inadequate data protection impact assessment that didn't cover the new processing scenario where Icelandic Genetics employees had access to patient names and IDs. While no security deficiencies were found, the DPA criticized the hospital for proceeding without proper assessment and delayed cooperation with the authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed cooperation as aggravating due to delayed responses, and pandemic circumstances as mitigating. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines of the European Privacy Council no. 7/2020 on the concepts responsible party and processor
a75_case_summary: InfoMentor ehf., processor of Mentor educational system, failed to implement adequate security measures resulting in unauthorized access to 424 children's ID numbers and photos. The DPA found breaches of Article 32 regarding security measures and Article 5(1)(f) integrity/confidentiality. A €3.5 million ISK fine was imposed due to the nature of children's data and company's responsibility as educational system processor.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, negligent character, technical measures deficiencies, and categories of personal data (children's data). Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, manner infringement became known, and measures taken to prevent future breaches.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed no authorization was considered; DPA found processing was not authorized under Article 6 of GDPR; Processing lacked legal basis for disclosure of personal information
a75_case_summary: Municipality X contacted trade union Y to verify if complainant's courses were funded by union's vocational training fund; Personal information about complainant was shared without proper authorization; DPA found processing violated data protection law due to lack of legal basis; Municipality stated procedures were reviewed to prevent recurrence

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed regarding surveillance cameras at neighbors' house. DPA found cameras only monitored private property, falling outside GDPR scope under Article 2(2)(c) as personal/household activity. No violation found as processing exempt from data protection rules.

a7_defendant_name: Harpa Music and Conference Center ohf.
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill contract under Article 6(1)(b). DPA found collection of ID numbers and birth dates was not necessary for ticket delivery as contract could be fulfilled using other identifying information.
a75_case_summary: Harpa collected ID numbers and birth dates for ticket purchases without proper legal basis. DPA found this violated data minimization and contract necessity principles under Article 6(1)(b). Processing was not necessary for ticket delivery as other identification methods were available. Fine imposed due to widespread practice and duration of violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/duration was aggravating as violation affected many individuals over time. Negligence was mitigating as company acted in good faith. Cooperation was aggravating due to delayed responses. Special category data was aggravating as ID numbers have special protection.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under national law but DPA found processing was permitted under Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for both employment decisions, as they constituted exercise of official authority.
a75_case_summary: The DPA ruled on a complaint regarding a municipality's processing of personal data in employment decisions. The municipality collected information from a previous employer and used it in dismissal and subsequent job application decisions. The DPA found the processing was permitted under public task legal basis and complied with data protection principles.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was authorized under Article 9(5) for public interest/exercise of official authority. The DPA found the processing unlawful as the disclosure violated administrative procedure laws and data protection principles, making subsequent processing also unlawful.
a75_case_summary: A complainant reported a colleague's inappropriate behavior to a child protection committee without naming specific children. The committee forwarded the complaint with the complainant's personal data to the municipality's school department without proper guidance or transparency. The DPA found this disclosure violated data protection principles of lawfulness, fairness, and purpose limitation, making subsequent processing by the municipality also unlawful.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA ruled on a complaint regarding access requests to personal data of complainants and their daughter from a municipality and school. The DPA found that while the defendants provided all required documents and properly excluded data that would infringe on others' rights, they violated GDPR by not informing complainants within the statutory deadline about withheld data and complaint rights, and by not providing all entitled documents initially, requiring complainants to initiate further submissions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unauthorized as the school sent sensitive personal information about a child's diagnosis to other parents without proper authorization, despite the school's obligation to handle bullying cases.
a75_case_summary: A primary school mistakenly emailed an action plan containing sensitive health information about a student's diagnosis to parents of other children while addressing bullying. The DPA found the dissemination unauthorized under GDPR despite the school's obligation to handle bullying cases. The DPA conducted an on-site inspection and confirmed the sensitive data was improperly shared. No fine was imposed as the case didn't meet preconditions for financial penalty.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Processing was based on consent for scientific research but samples were taken before Scientific Ethics Committee approval and proper consent procedures were not followed
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 03/2020 on the processing of personal data for the purpose of scientific research in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA investigated processing of COVID-19 patient blood samples by Landspítali hospital and Icelandic Genetics for scientific research. Samples were taken before Scientific Ethics Committee approval and proper consent procedures. The DPA found violations of lawfulness, fairness, transparency and purpose limitation principles under GDPR and national law.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation and public task. The DPA found these legal bases valid for epidemiological measures during the COVID-19 pandemic, citing the Epidemiological Control Act and public health legislation.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA conducted an own-initiative investigation into COVID-19 screening and antibody testing by the Chief Epidemiologist. The DPA found general compliance with data protection laws but identified deficiencies in the processing agreement between the Epidemiologist and Landspítali hospital. The DPA also concluded that public information should have been clearer about the purpose of screening not being for scientific research.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found processing of complainant's sensitive health information lawful under Article 9(c) and Article 11(8) of Norwegian Personal Protection Act (equivalent to GDPR Article 6(1)(c) and 9(2)(h)) as necessary for child protection services' legal obligations. However, sharing names and social security numbers of complainant's other children to the father was found unauthorized under Article 9 of the Act.
a75_case_summary: Norwegian DPA ruled on complaint about municipality's social services sharing personal data. Found processing of complainant's sensitive health information lawful under child protection legal obligations, but unauthorized sharing of other children's names and social security numbers to their father who lacked custody. Decision distinguished between justified processing for child protection investigation versus excessive data sharing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA conducted an audit of Íslenskr gerenálys ehf's data protection officer position. The DPA found no issues with the DPO's involvement in privacy matters or resources provided. However, the DPA concluded the company failed to ensure other tasks performed by DPOs (including deputy director, chief legal officer roles) wouldn't cause conflicts of interest, violating Article 38(6). The company was ordered to ensure current DPO doesn't perform conflicting tasks.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f); the DPA found this valid as RU's interests in preventing exam fraud outweighed students' privacy rights, especially given alternative exam options offered.
a75_case_summary: RU conducted electronic exam monitoring via Zoom during COVID-19; the DPA found legitimate interests valid and security adequate but insufficient transparency/information violated Articles 13 and 5(1)(a); RU was ordered to provide proper student instruction on processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered COVID-19 pressures mitigating; no fine imposed due to circumstances and first-time offense; other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Icelandic DPA ruled on complaint regarding Íslenskri gegenyður ehf.'s processing of Danish health data as processor for Capital Region of Denmark. Complainant alleged company acted beyond processor role. DPA found processing agreements valid, company remained processor, and processing complied with GDPR. No violations found.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for security purposes. DPA found monitoring extended beyond private property to common areas and public spaces without demonstrated need, and violated multi-family house regulations requiring house meeting approval.
a75_case_summary: Individual installed surveillance cameras monitoring common areas of multi-family house and public spaces without house meeting approval. DPA found no demonstrated need for monitoring beyond private property boundaries. Ruled monitoring violated legitimate interests basis under Article 6(1)(f) and ordered cessation of monitoring and deletion of recorded material.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The processing lacked adequate authorization under privacy legislation as the dissemination of email addresses did not comply with security requirements
a75_case_summary: The Directorate of Labour mistakenly placed email addresses in visible CC field instead of BCC when sending mass emails, disclosing complainant's email address to approximately 900 recipients. The DPA found this constituted a security breach violating data protection principles. The Directorate had implemented procedural changes but failed to properly notify affected individuals about the breach.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f);DPA found monitoring was not necessary for legitimate interests and interests did not outweigh data subjects' rights;Processing lacked lawful basis.
a75_case_summary: Neighbor installed surveillance camera monitoring complainants' land and apartment building;DPA found monitoring violated lawfulness principle as legitimate interests did not outweigh data subjects' rights;Camera field of view extended beyond defendant's private territory onto public road;No signs were posted about the monitoring.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under national education laws. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 9(3) of Act no. 90/2018 (equivalent to Article 6(1)(e) public task) but violated reliability requirements.
a75_case_summary: A school incorrectly registered a child's attendance in the Mentor system. The DPA found the processing violated reliability requirements under national data protection law (equivalent to GDPR Article 5(1)(d)). The error was corrected within 12 hours, mitigating the violation. No corrective measures were ordered due to prompt correction.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for sharing recordings with police to demonstrate criminal behavior. DPA found the processing necessary to protect her privacy and security, and that her legitimate interests outweighed the complainant's interests in being informed.
a75_case_summary: Individual recorded phone calls with child's father to document abuse and shared recordings with police. DPA found recording fell outside GDPR scope as purely personal/family matter. Sharing with police was justified under legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) and transparency obligations were waived due to criminal investigation context and urgent safety interests.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic Data Protection Authority ruled on complaints alleging Íslandspósts ohf maintained a special register of stamp collectors. The postal service denied maintaining such a register but acknowledged employees developed knowledge over time to assess shipments potentially containing value. The Authority found no evidence of unlawful personal data processing and determined no further investigation was necessary.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under Icelandic Guarantors Act, but the DPA found this invalid as information was communicated to parties who were not actual guarantors, and the bank failed to verify ownership registration before sending notifications.
a75_case_summary: Íslandsbanki shared complainant's debt status information with unauthorized parties who owned property in the same building, claiming legal obligation under Icelandic Guarantors Act. The DPA found the processing unlawful as the bank failed to verify actual guarantor status and implement appropriate security measures. The bank was ordered to implement measures ensuring appropriate security of personal information in future notifications.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature of financial data (AGGRAVATING), inadequate security measures (AGGRAVATING), and failure to ensure appropriate security (AGGRAVATING) contributed to the violation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Norwegian DPA dismissed complaint about neighbor recording private conversations and sharing them. Found processing fell under personal use exemption in Article 2(2)(c) GDPR as recordings were only shared with complainant during neighbor dispute. Case outside DPA's jurisdiction as processing was solely for personal use.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Icelandair claimed legitimate interests and legal obligation under collective agreement. DPA found processing authorized under Article 6(1)(c) based on collective agreement status as secondary legal authority, but violated principles of proportionality and fairness.
a75_case_summary: Icelandair implemented a peer evaluation system for flight crew using CrewApp app. DPA found the processing violated proportionality and fairness principles as it was more extensive than necessary and created burdensome conditions. The DPA also found Icelandair failed to conduct a required DPIA before implementation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not claim any legal basis for the processing. The DPA found the processing lacked authorization under Article 9 of the Icelandic Act (equivalent to GDPR Article 6) and additional conditions for sensitive data processing, making it unlawful.
a75_case_summary: The City of Reykjavík's Eastern Center sent a locked report containing a child's health information via email to an unauthorized recipient, along with the password in a separate email to the same address. The DPA found this violated data protection principles as the security measure was ineffective when password and document were sent to the same recipient. The processing lacked legal basis and appropriate security measures, though the DPA considered the city's response measures sufficient and issued no further instructions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the sensitive nature of children's health data as aggravating, but the city's prompt breach notification, cooperation with authorities, and remedial actions (contacting recipient for deletion, informing parents) as mitigating factors. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for public interest (Art 6(1)(e)) and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)). DPA found public interest basis invalid due to lack of legal foundation, but legitimate interests basis valid for genealogical research purposes.
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding refusal to delete personal data from Íslendingabók genealogical database. DPA found processing justified under legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for genealogical research purposes. Right to erasure not applicable due to exemption for historical research purposes under Art 17(3)(d). Controller permitted to refuse deletion request.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill legal obligations under Icelandic law. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as it was based on the nature of the working relationship between supervisors and subordinates and compliance with ministerial requests.
a75_case_summary: Icelandic DPA ruled on complaint about educational institution collecting teacher information from colleagues and sharing with Ministry of Education. Found processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary to fulfill legal obligations. Data not obtained from third parties so no transparency obligation. Sharing with Parliamentary Ombudsman dismissed as outside DPA jurisdiction.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under Icelandic law on secondary schools; DPA found processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary to fulfill legal obligations; Reasoning included that teaching evaluations are part of school's internal evaluation required by law.
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged educational institution improperly shared teaching evaluation results at meeting; DPA found oral communication constituted processing but was lawful under legal obligation basis; Processing was necessary for school's internal evaluation obligations; Only authorized employees with confidentiality duties received information.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The case involved a complaint about Landsbankinn's refusal of an access request for email communications between bank employees that concerned their work for a trade union (SSF) rather than bank operations. The DPA found the bank was not the controller for this data as it did not relate to the bank's activities. The refusal was deemed lawful as the assessment of access rights fell under SSF as the responsible party.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Icelandic DPA ruled that BL ehf. violated GDPR by refusing to process an access request submitted electronically by a law firm with proper authorization. The company incorrectly required physical presence and paper delivery instead of electronic response. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered BL ehf. to substantively process the access request.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent through terms of use; DPA found consent invalid as it was not free, specific, or distinguished from other terms; DPA also found legitimate interests invalid as controller's interests did not outweigh data subject's privacy interests.
a75_case_summary: DPA ruled against Advania Ísland ehf. for unlawfully publishing complainant's email address and social security number through Signet electronic signature service. The controller claimed consent through terms of use but DPA found consent invalid as it wasn't free or specific. For email addresses, DPA found no legitimate interest justification; for social security numbers, DPA found processing disproportionate when accessible to all users rather than just subscribers needing identification.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under national law Section 6 Article 9;DPA found processing necessary for legitimate interests of Google and public's right to information;Public interest outweighed complainant's privacy interests due to his public role
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding Google search results about workplace bullying allegations;DPA assessed legitimate interests balancing test between public's right to information and complainant's privacy;Found public interest prevailed due to complainant's employment and public role;No violation found as processing was authorized under national law

a7_defendant_name: Office of the National Medical Examiner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill legal obligations under administrative law. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as it was necessary to fulfill the legal obligation to provide information to parties in an administrative case.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA ruled on a complaint against the National Medical Examiner's Office regarding sharing of personal data about a department head. The office shared limited information about the complainant's indefinite leave status with an association that had filed suggestions about patient treatment. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary to fulfill legal obligations under administrative law, and compliant with data minimization and fairness principles.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Nova hf. assigned complainant's phone number to unauthorized third party due to human error. DPA found security breach under Article 32 as unauthorized access enabled potential access to additional personal data through websites/apps using phone number as identifier. DPA ordered Nova to implement measures preventing reassignment of active numbers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was AGGRAVATING; intentional/negligent character was AGGRAVATING; technical/organizational measures were AGGRAVATING; previous infringements were AGGRAVATING; categories of personal data affected were AGGRAVATING. Other factors were NOT_DISCUSSED.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Data Protection Authority dismissed a complaint about publication of a child's photos on Facebook by a parent and a legal entity. The Authority found the photos and accompanying text constituted an inseparable expression protected by constitutional freedom of speech. The DPA determined it lacked competence to rule on whether the parties exceeded limits of freedom of expression.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Creditinfo's processing could be based on legitimate interests but violated principles of fairness, reliability and proportionality by using registration date rather than judgment date for the 4-year retention period.
a75_case_summary: Creditinfo processed personal data about complainant's debt defaults for credit scoring. The DPA found violation because Creditinfo used registration date rather than judgment date for 4-year retention period, violating fairness, reliability and proportionality principles. The DPA ordered deletion of the data and compliance confirmation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) and for establishing legal claims under Article 9(2)(f). The DPA found the processing was not necessary as the law firm failed to demonstrate why sharing personal data with the municipality's general email address was required for dispute resolution.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A law firm sent a claim letter containing sensitive personal data (salary, labor market measures, trade union membership) to both the complainant's personal email and a municipality's general email address. The DPA found the law firm acted as controller, not processor, and failed to demonstrate necessity for sharing data with the municipality. The processing violated GDPR as it lacked legal basis under Articles 6(1)(f) and 9(2)(f).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Data Protection Authority dismissed a complaint regarding access to a written reprimand from an employer. The first part was dismissed as an employment law matter outside the DPA's jurisdiction. The second part regarding access rights could not be determined due to conflicting accounts between complainant and company.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was authorized under its operating license; DPA found the processing complied with Act no. 90/2018 and Regulation (EU) 2016/679; Key reasoning was that adequate notification procedures were followed.
a75_case_summary: Icelandic DPA ruled that Creditinfo's processing of complainant's default registration complied with data protection laws; The company followed proper notification procedures by sending educational notice to registered domicile; DPA found no obligation to eliminate effects of the registration; Processing was authorized under Creditinfo's operating license.

a7_defendant_name: Office of the National Medical Examiner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of security principles (Art 5(1)(f)) and specific security measures (Art 32) rather than invalidating any claimed legal basis for processing. The controller's role in health data processing was established but legal basis validity was not explicitly assessed.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA fined the Office of the National Medical Examiner ISK 12,000,000 for security weaknesses in the Heilsuvera health portal that allowed unauthorized access to patient data. Two vulnerabilities existed: message section access through parameter manipulation (2015-2020) and maternity care attachment access through URL modification (2019-2020). The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 25, and 32 due to inadequate security measures for sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of breach, negligent character, responsibility for technical measures, and categories of sensitive data. Mitigating factors included actions to reduce damage and voluntary breach reporting. The public service role of the defendant was considered as another mitigating factor.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f). The DPA found this basis invalid because the processing was not lawful, fair, or transparent, and the controller failed to demonstrate that legitimate interests outweighed data subjects' rights.
a75_case_summary: Creditinfo Lánstraust hf., a financial information agency, registered loan default information from eCommerce 2020 ApS without verifying that registration conditions were met. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles (lawfulness, fairness, transparency, and accountability) because the agency failed to check loan terms for proper authorization clauses and minimum amount requirements. The fine was based on the processing's onerous nature, profit motive, core business relevance, and delayed corrective actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of the breach, negligence, inadequate technical measures, categories of data affected, and profit motive. Mitigating factors included cooperation with the DPA and actions to reduce damage. The fine amount was set at 2.5% of annual turnover considering these factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Creditinfo relied on consent (Art 6(1)(a)) for using additional information in credit assessments; Netgíró relied on legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) under consumer credit laws; ÍL Fund relied on legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for debt status sharing. DPA found all legal bases valid.
a75_case_summary: Complaint challenged creditworthiness processing by Creditinfo using debt status data, ÍL Fund's debt reporting timing, and Netgíró's authorization cancellation based on credit scores. DPA found all processing lawful: Creditinfo had valid consent for additional data, ÍL Fund's daily settlement system was reasonable, and Netgíró had legal obligation under consumer credit laws.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task/legal obligation under fisheries laws. The DPA found no legal authorization existed at the time of processing as the relevant legal provisions required in-person inspections by fisheries inspectors, not covert video surveillance.
a75_case_summary: The Norwegian Fisheries Agency conducted covert video surveillance of a fishing vessel using binoculars with attached recording equipment. The DPA found no legal authorization existed for this processing method under fisheries laws at the time, as inspections were required to be conducted in-person. The processing violated transparency requirements as the data subject was not warned about the surveillance. No corrective measures were issued due to subsequent legal changes authorizing such surveillance methods.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance. Processing was authorized under Article 9(5) and Article 12(1) of Icelandic law for exercise of official authority and statutory tasks.
a75_case_summary: Complaint about Sheriff obtaining complete police case file for child visitation case. DPA found processing lawful under Article 9(5) and Article 12(1) of Icelandic law for exercise of official authority. National Police Commissioner's sharing was lawful under Children's Act obligation to provide documents.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill legal obligations under Act no. 140/2018 against money laundering. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary for secure identification in banking transactions.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA ruled on a complaint about Landsbankinn requiring a social security number during cash deposit transactions. The bank claimed processing was necessary under anti-money laundering laws requiring identification. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary for secure identification in banking transactions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The case involved a complaint about police officers allegedly recording surveillance footage on personal phones and sharing it with unauthorized parties. The DPA found it unproven that automated processing or processing for law enforcement purposes occurred under Act no. 75/2019. The DPA concluded the alleged activities did not fall within the scope of data protection laws as oral transmission alone generally doesn't constitute processing under Icelandic law.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests basis under Article 6(1)(f) for publishing police files to support his expression. DPA found his interests did not outweigh complainant's interests in non-publication, especially since he was unrelated to the criminal case and the data was not public.
a75_case_summary: Individual published police files containing sensitive personal information about complainant on Facebook. DPA found this processing unlawful as controller's interests (free expression) did not outweigh data subject's privacy interests, especially since controller was unrelated to the criminal case and the data was not public information. DPA ordered removal of the images but declined to rule on the textual expression aspect as outside its competence.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA ruled on a complaint regarding an association's refusal to provide access to board meeting minutes containing personal data about a former employee. The DPA found that while the complainant had right to access specific information about himself in certain agenda items, the full minutes contained discussions and reflections of board members that required protection of others' interests. The DPA ordered the organization to provide limited information including names of attendees and specific agenda items where the complainant was discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 9(5) of Icelandic law. The DPA found this legal basis valid for the processing activities but found transparency violations.
a75_case_summary: The University of Iceland processed student data through Canvas learning management system and peer assessments for grading. The DPA found the processing lawful under public task basis but violated transparency requirements as the student was not informed about monitoring activities or use of peer assessments for grading.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(c) legal obligation and Article 6(1)(e) public task, and for special category data under Article 9(2)(a) explicit consent and Article 9(2)(e) data made public by data subject.
a75_case_summary: The DPA ruled that processing of political opinion data for election agent identification cards was lawful. Processing was based on legal obligation under Election Law and public task. The complainant had consented and his political views were already public. Transparency requirements were met through legal basis and notification when photo was requested.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that processing could be based on public interest under Article 6(1)(e) for background checks of emergency guards, but found violations of fairness and transparency obligations regarding proper information to the data subject.
a75_case_summary: The National Police Commissioner conducted background checks on emergency guard applicants by accessing police case files without proper transparency. While the DPA found public interest justification for the checks, it ruled violations of fairness and transparency obligations under Articles 5(1)(a) and 5(2) for failing to adequately inform applicants about the processing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid because the processing lacked transparency and proper authorization for credit reporting registration.
a75_case_summary: eCommerce 2020 ApS sent information about loan defaults to Creditinfo Lánstrausti hf. without proper authorization in loan terms and below minimum amount thresholds. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles including lawfulness, fairness, transparency and invalid legitimate interests basis. The fine was set at ISK 7.5 million considering the burdensome nature of credit reporting and the company's financial situation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, technical/organizational measures as aggravating, categories of personal data as aggravating, and profit motive as aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage were considered mitigating. The company's financial decline was also considered in fine determination.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The City of Reykjavík failed to locate all requested personal data from a complainant's work permit applications spanning 1998-2023, including sensitive health information. While the DPA found the access request was properly handled for existing data, the loss of sensitive personal data constituted a security breach under Article 32 GDPR. The DPA concluded the city failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data security.

a36_legal_basis_summary: VÍS claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for sending service surveys. The DPA found the processing lawful as VÍS had legitimate interests in improving service quality, the complainant was a customer, and the processing was transparent with objection rights provided.
a75_case_summary: VÍS processed a customer's phone number and email to send a service survey after an anonymous call. The DPA found processing lawful under legitimate interests as the complainant was a customer, processing was transparent with privacy policy reference, and objection rights were provided. The effect on the complainant was deemed extremely limited.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of data (general personal information) as mitigating, the limited effect on complainant as mitigating, and transparency measures as mitigating. No other Article 83(2) factors were discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public interest in healthcare safety; DPA found violations as ministerial permission and DPA confirmation required by national law were not obtained for most agreements.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA conducted an ex officio investigation into the Capital Region Health Service's joint medical record system. The health service failed to obtain required ministerial permission and DPA confirmation for merging systems with 11 parties, violating data protection laws. Processing involved health data of approximately 195,000 individuals over several years. The DPA imposed a 5 million ISK fine considering the serious nature, duration, and sensitivity of data, while acknowledging remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration and sensitive data were aggravating; cooperation and mitigation actions were mitigating; intentional character was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found the complainant's privacy interests outweighed Google's financial interests and public information access interests.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA ruled on a right to be forgotten complaint against Google LLC regarding search results linking to articles about the complainant. The DPA found the complainant's privacy interests outweighed Google's legitimate interests and public information access rights, ordering removal of specific URLs from search results for the complainant's name.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic Data Protection Authority ruled on a complaint regarding the Police in the capital area's retention of personal information after an investigation was cancelled. The Authority found that personal information unrelated to the investigation was deleted without undue delay (within 2.5 months) and that processing delays were justified due to summer vacation and staff illness. The Police's actions were found to be in compliance with Act no. 75/2019 on processing of personal information for law enforcement purposes.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance. DPA found legitimate interests valid for original tachograph purpose but not for secondary purpose of performance evaluation and dismissal.
a75_case_summary: Íslandspóst used tachograph data from an employee's vehicle for performance evaluation and dismissal, which exceeded the originally stated purpose of improving driving style and road safety. The DPA found the processing unlawful due to purpose limitation violation and lack of transparency about the secondary purpose. No consent was valid due to employer-employee power imbalance, though legitimate interests could justify the original monitoring purpose.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller relied on legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) for work permit assessment and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for sharing data in litigation. The DPA found both bases valid, noting the city's legitimate interest in defending legal claims outweighed complainant's rights.
a75_case_summary: The case involved a complaint about Reykjavík City's processing of health data in work permit applications and sharing with attorneys/assessors in litigation. The DPA found the processing lawful under legal obligation for work permit assessment and legitimate interests for litigation purposes. The DPA concluded no GDPR violations occurred as the city's interests outweighed complainant's rights in the legal dispute context.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests but the DPA found no valid legal basis for disclosure of call records and email handling, as the purpose was unclear and not necessary.
a75_case_summary: Employer disclosed call records from complainant's work phone to his ex-wife without valid legal basis. Company also improperly handled complainant's email after retirement by forwarding emails without notice, not allowing presence during inspection, and failing to close mailbox within required timeframe. Violations of Icelandic data protection Act no. 90/2018 and Rules no. 837/2006 on electronic monitoring.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary to comply with legal obligations under Administrative Law. DPA found processing lawful under Article 9(3) of Act no. 90/2018 as necessary to comply with legal obligations.
a75_case_summary: Public agency disclosed complainant's name in notification to other job applicants about complainant's data access request. DPA found processing lawful under Icelandic data protection law as necessary to comply with legal obligations under Administrative Law. DPA concluded disclosure was proportionate and complied with data protection principles.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A real estate franchise partner (Respondent 2) accessed applicant's job seeker profile from a recruitment database and contacted them. Applicant requested access to their personal data but received no response due to administrative error. Authority found Respondent 2 violated Article 15(1) GDPR by failing to respond to access request and ordered compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed. The Authority noted the violation was unintentional due to administrative error, which was considered mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest based on freedom of expression and public interest; DPA found no valid legal basis as processing was not necessary or proportionate, and controller was not a press entity where such exceptions apply.
a75_case_summary: Municipal deputy mayor published photo of complainant and his minor child on Facebook during election campaign without consent, claiming legitimate interest in freedom of expression. DPA found no valid legal basis, violation of data protection principles (lawfulness, purpose limitation, minimization), and failure to respond to data subject rights requests. Ordered deletion and imposed fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (serious infringement affecting privacy), intentional character as aggravating, and previous infringements as mitigating (first violation). Other factors were reviewed but not considered relevant.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public tasks under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this valid for work-related data but invalid for private emails, requiring separate handling.
a75_case_summary: A former employee requested access to his 2018 workplace email archive after termination. The university denied access entirely. The DPA found the university breached Article 15 by refusing access to private emails and Article 12 by failing to provide transparent information. The DPA ordered access to private emails and imposed a HUF 200,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as aggravating, technical measures as aggravating, previous infringements as mitigating, and other factors as aggravating. The fine was set near the minimum considering mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found ROBINSON-TOURS violated GDPR Articles 25(1)-(2), 32(1)(b), and 34(1) due to a website vulnerability that exposed personal data of 781 travelers including children. The data was accessible via Google search without authentication from November 2019 to February 2020. The DPA ordered a €20M HUF fine and mandated notification to data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included high-risk data nature, systemic security failures, and external discovery. Mitigating factors included lack of intentionality and no prior infringements. Cooperation and prompt reporting were noted but not explicitly mitigating.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for data transfer to facilitate SZÉP Card applications; DPA found legitimate interest invalid as it served data subjects' interests, not controller's; Consent was also invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship.
a75_case_summary: The case involved an employee complaint about inaccurate temporary address data retention and unauthorized data transfer to a financial institution. The DPA found violations of accuracy principle (Article 5(1)(d)), right to rectification/erasure (Articles 16-17), transparency obligations (Article 13), and invalid legal basis for data transfer (Article 6). The controller failed to properly respond to data subject requests and transferred personal data without adequate legal basis or information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered several mitigating factors: no harm to data subjects, first-time infringement, deletion of data after procedure initiation, single data subject affected, and transfer intended to benefit employees. Other Article 83(2) factors were not considered relevant. A fine was imposed as warning was deemed insufficient.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntary, specific, informed and unambiguous expression. Consent was not properly separated for different processing purposes.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;WP259 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found that a politician collected signatures for a political initiative without valid consent. The controller processed political opinion data (special category) without explicit consent and failed to provide adequate information. The DPA ordered deletion of all collected data and imposed a 1 million HUF fine for violations of Articles 5,6,9 and 13.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered special category data and duration as aggravating factors. It considered the breach negligible in nature and first-time offense as mitigating factors. Non-compliance with prior orders was also aggravating.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis; DPA found consent invalid as service provision was conditional on data processing; DPA found contract necessity (Art 6(1)(b)) valid for core SMS service functionality
a75_case_summary: Hungarian DPA found website operator violated GDPR transparency requirements; Privacy notice contained false information about newsletters, data retention, and data protection register; Legal basis was unclear mixing consent and contract necessity; DPA ordered compliance but no fine due to defendant's financial situation and cooperation

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was needed as they didn't process applicant's personal data; DPA found they processed telephone number without legal basis and violated Article 6(1) by failing to prove consent.
a75_case_summary: Debt collection agency recorded applicant's telephone number as client contact data without proper identification; DPA found violations of accuracy principle (Article 5(1)(d)) and lack of legal basis (Article 6(1)); fine imposed considering moderate seriousness, negligent conduct, and mitigating deletion before proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature/gravity was aggravating (moderately serious), intentional/negligent character was aggravating, actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (deleted data), previous infringements were mitigating (no prior convictions); other factors not discussed.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for CCTV monitoring. The DPA accepted this legal basis as appropriate for workplace camera systems for property protection purposes but found specific violations regarding implementation.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a private company violated GDPR principles by installing CCTV cameras that monitored both property protection areas and employee workstations. The camera angle in one room allowed unreasonable monitoring of workers, violating purpose limitation and data minimization principles. Additionally, the company failed to provide adequate information about the CCTV system to employees for several months after implementation began.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including previous infringements as aggravating, cooperation as neutral, and limited scope of affected persons as mitigating. The fine was set considering the company's large size and the duration of infringements.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a telecom provider violated Article 16 (right to rectification) and Article 5(1)(d) (accuracy principle) by failing to properly update a customer's email address despite notification. The provider manually corrected the address but failed to update it in their campaign management system, causing newsletters to continue to the old address. The DPA issued a warning rather than a fine due to the low gravity, negligent nature, and eventual correction of the infringement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors and found: low gravity (mitigating), negligent conduct (mitigating), no special data categories (mitigating), and eventual correction of the infringement (mitigating). Previous infringements were considered but found not relevant (neutral). A warning was deemed proportionate rather than a fine.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Hungarian DPA found Google Ireland Ltd violated Articles 12(3) and 15(1) GDPR by failing to provide adequate information on processing of applicant's personal data in Google AdWords within required timeframe. The case involved cross-border processing with Hungarian DPA acting as lead authority after coordination with Irish DPA. Google eventually provided the information during proceedings, making compliance orders unnecessary. A fine of HUF 10,000 was imposed for procedural delays.

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA investigated MarkMyProfessor Kft. for failing to respond to data subject requests from university lecturers who objected to offensive comments posted about them on the markmyprofessor.com website. The company failed to provide information within the one-month timeframe required by GDPR and infringed data subjects' right to information and transparency principles. The case originated from a complaint filed by the University of Debrecen on behalf of its lecturers.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The case involved a data subject complaint regarding the right of access under Article 15. The controller provided only general data management information and references to website policies rather than personalized information about the specific data processing. The Authority found this insufficient and ordered the controller to provide complete, specific information about the data subject's personal data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Authority considered Article 83(2) factors and found the infringement severity was low, no harm occurred, and this was the controller's first GDPR violation. These mitigating factors led to a warning instead of a fine.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for property protection, but the DPA found this invalid as no balancing of interests test was presented and camera surveillance was disproportionate for asset protection purposes.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a solarium company violated GDPR by operating CCTV surveillance without valid legal basis and inadequate transparency. The company claimed legitimate interest for property protection but failed to provide required balancing test. Camera angles monitored excessive areas including tanning machines and public space without masking.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered delayed/incomplete responses aggravating, while cessation of operations was mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) for subscriber data processing and Article 6(1)(a) for newsletter data. The DPA did not assess validity of legal bases but focused on storage limitation and security principles.
a75_case_summary: Digi telecom company stored customer data in test database for 1.5 years after error correction, violating storage limitation principle. A hacker exploited a 9-year-known vulnerability in unpatched CMS to access unencrypted data affecting 322,000+ individuals. DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(e) and 32(1)-(2) regarding storage limitation and security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, categories of data affected, large number of data subjects. Mitigating: no previous infringements. Neutral: actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority.

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: [Respondent name not explicitly stated in provided text]
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contractual basis for status messages and marketing content; DPA found this invalid for marketing content as it was incompatible with original purpose and required separate legal basis
a75_case_summary: Hungarian postal service provider processed names/email addresses for delivery status updates, customer satisfaction surveys, and promotional content about discount services; DPA found invalid legal basis for marketing content (Article 6(1)(b)) and inadequate transparency information (Article 13); Processing affected 175,000-1,050,000 individuals; Fine imposed considering aggravating/mitigating factors under Article 83(2)
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: large scale/systemic nature affecting many individuals, company's data processing expertise; Mitigating: negligence not intent, no previous sanctions, cooperation/remedial actions, no special category data; Neutral: categories of data affected

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a7_defendant_name: Óbuda Family Counseling and Child Protection Center
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(e) for public task. The DPA found the initial processing lawful under this basis but found unauthorized processing occurred between document transfer and deletion.
a75_case_summary: The case involved a child protection center that received an audio recording containing the applicant's voice, processed it as part of child protection documents, and forwarded it to another child welfare center. The DPA found the initial processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) but found unauthorized processing occurred between document transfer and deletion. The defendant violated access rights by providing false information about the recording's availability and deletion status.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the defendant's deceptive behavior and obstruction of rights as aggravating factors. Mitigating factors included the defendant's admission of wrongdoing and its social welfare function. The Authority waived a fine in favor of a warning due to these circumstances.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: Cooperative Communities Association for the Living World
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a) for special category data processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information provision, lack of explicit consent for political contact purposes, and failure to implement two-step verification as described in privacy notice.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent;WP29 Guidelines WP259 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found two joint controllers violated GDPR in a political signature collection campaign. The controllers collected personal data without valid legal basis, provided inadequate information about processing purposes, and failed to demonstrate accountability. The DPA ordered data deletion, issued reprimands, and imposed 3 million HUF fines on each controller for processing special category data without proper consent and transparency.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: serious nature affecting many data subjects, multiple violations, long duration, negligent conduct, special category data, and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factor for one controller was being a natural person. The fine was imposed considering both specific and general deterrence objectives.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid as it was not voluntary or demonstrated by unambiguous affirmative action; no other legal basis established for processing
a75_case_summary: Telecommunications provider failed to delete complainant's personal data from online directory despite multiple requests; DPA found invalid consent basis for processing and violations of erasure right, transparency obligations, and accountability principle; technical and administrative errors cited but controller responsibility upheld
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligence, previous infringements, categories of data; Mitigating: cooperation, compensation offered, deletion during proceedings; Neutral: not applicable factors

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a7_defendant_name: Budapest Capital XVIII. district with the Pestszentlőrinc - Pestszentimre Municipality
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(e) for name/address data and Article 6(1)(a) for contact/health data. The DPA found the legal bases invalid due to lack of adequate information, specific purposes, and necessity/proportionality requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a municipality violated GDPR by sending vaccine questionnaires without adequate information, processing contact data without specific purpose/valid consent, and unnecessarily processing health data. The DPA ordered compliance measures and imposed a 3M HUF fine. Violations included Articles 5(1)(b)(c), 6(1), 7(2), 9(1), 12(1), 13, and 14.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity, public authority role, lack of information, health data involved, multiple complaints. Mitigating: negligent not intentional, partial remediation, no previous infringements, financial situation. Neutral: cooperation.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller lacked any valid legal basis under Article 6(1) for processing the applicant's email address, as the data was provided erroneously by a third party without proper verification.
a75_case_summary: Magyar Telekom processed an email address erroneously provided by a third party customer and failed to delete it despite repeated requests from the actual data subject. The DPA found violations of accuracy principles, transparency obligations, and erasure rights, noting this was part of a recurring pattern of similar infringements. The company's organizational measures were inadequate as they required unnecessary administrative barriers like account login for non-customers to exercise data subject rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included persistent internal procedural problems, previous similar infringements, and the company's large size. Mitigating factors included the unintentional nature of the breach, deletion after Authority intervention, and that only contact data (not sensitive) was affected. The fine was set at 0.04% of annual turnover considering both aggravating and mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid in employment context and required legitimate interest balancing test instead
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a car repair company violated GDPR by using CCTV cameras that monitored employees excessively in office-waiting and kitchen areas. The company improperly relied on employee consent instead of legitimate interest, failed to conduct balancing test, and provided inadequate information to employees. The DPA ordered camera angle adjustments, policy revisions, and imposed a HUF 500,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors including duration of infringement and notification via complaint after prior warnings. Mitigating factors included small number of affected persons, limited scope to two cameras, no specific harm, negligence rather than intent, and first-time violation. Cooperation was noted but not explicitly mitigating.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed both consent and legitimate interest as legal bases for marketing data processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information and lack of proof, and legitimate interest invalid due to lack of proper balancing test and documentation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency facilitating the application and interpretation of GDPR (WP259)
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a hotel company violated GDPR by processing personal data for marketing without valid legal basis. The controller failed to prove consent or legitimate interest, provided unclear information, and did not properly respond to data subject requests for deletion and access. Violations included Articles 5(2), 6(1), 7(1), 12(1)-(4), 15(1), and 17(1).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included long duration of violation and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factors included no previous infringements and procedural delays by the authority. The fine was set at HUF 500,000 considering both specific and general preventive purposes.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis for processing. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and no exception under Article 9(2) for processing special category data, making the processing unlawful.
a75_case_summary: An individual secretly recorded a kindergarten meeting discussing a child's behavioral and health issues, then shared the recording in a parents' Facebook group and via email. The Hungarian DPA found violations of GDPR principles (lawfulness, fairness, purpose limitation, data minimization) and Articles 6 and 9 regarding legal basis for processing special category data. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered deletion of the recording.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the sensitive nature of health data and secret recording as aggravating factors. The defendant's lack of malicious intent, short duration of availability, and prompt removal were mitigating factors. A warning was deemed proportionate rather than a fine.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a religious organization violated Article 12(3) GDPR by failing to respond to a data subject's access request within the required timeframe. The respondent claimed the request was harassment and not a valid access request, but the DPA found the January 7, 2022 letter constituted a valid access request that was received but unanswered. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered compliance with the access request but rejected the complainant's request for a fine.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 9(2)(d) as legal basis for processing political opinion data. The DPA did not explicitly validate or invalidate this legal basis but focused on security violations.
a75_case_summary: Hungarian DPA found political party violated GDPR Articles 32(1)(a-b) and 32(2) by storing party sympathizer data in Google Sheets with inadequate security measures, allowing unauthorized public access. Also violated Article 5(2) by failing to demonstrate compliance measures to authority. Fine of 3,000,000 HUF imposed considering aggravating factors including special category data involvement and lack of cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: large number of data subjects, special category data, systemic security problem, lack of cooperation. Mitigating: no specific harm to data subjects, no previous infringements. Neutral: manner infringement became known.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: Deichmann Shoe Trade Limited Liability Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the company violated GDPR principles by failing to properly handle data subject requests for access and restriction of camera recordings, without establishing valid legal bases for processing.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA fined Deichmann for GDPR violations related to CCTV operations. The company failed to properly handle a data subject's requests for access to camera recordings and restriction of processing. The DPA found inadequate organizational measures and restrictive internal regulations that violated data subject rights under Articles 12, 15, 18, and 25.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included serious negligence, nature/gravity of infringement, and inadequate technical measures. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage. Neutral factors included categories of personal data affected.

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) as legal basis for processing pregnancy data; the DPA found this valid only for verifying the 12th week of pregnancy and expected delivery date, but invalid for all other health data copied from pregnancy books which lacked proper legal basis under Article 6 or Article 9.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a financial institution violated GDPR by excessively copying pregnancy books containing health data beyond what was necessary to verify loan eligibility conditions. The controller lacked proper legal basis for processing extensive health data and failed to provide transparent information about data processing related to baby waiting loans.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included serious nature of infringements affecting many data subjects and sensitive health data processing. Mitigating factors included remedial actions taken, cooperation with authority, first-time offense, and uncertain legal situation created by government decree.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) as legal basis for direct marketing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate prior information, insufficient specificity of purposes, and lack of separate consent options for different marketing channels.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found Éremkibocsátó Kft. violated GDPR by processing personal data for direct marketing without adequate prior information and valid consent. The company failed to provide specific purpose definitions, separate consent options for different marketing channels, and transparent information about data transfers to processors. The DPA ordered compliance measures and imposed a 30 million HUF fine based on the serious nature of violations affecting potentially hundreds of thousands of data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: serious nature affecting many data subjects, gross negligence, insufficient technical measures, and profit-seeking motive. Mitigating factors were: no direct financial damage to data subjects and non-sensitive data. Neutral factors included: no mitigation measures taken, previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and manner of detection.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for debt collection purposes. DPA found this invalid as the legitimate interest did not outweigh data subject's rights since the claim was unenforceable against heirs under civil law. DPA found legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) valid for retention of transfer order documents.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Opinion 1/2010 on the concepts of "controller" and "processor";EDPB Guidelines 2/2019 on the processing of personal data under Article 6(1)(b) GDPR in the context of the provision of online services to data subjects
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a debt collection company violated multiple GDPR provisions in processing a claim against an heir. The company unlawfully processed personal data for debt collection purposes from May 25, 2018, to August 21, 2021, using an invalid legitimate interest basis since the claim was unenforceable against heirs under civil law. The DPA imposed a HUF 10 million fine citing aggravating factors including long duration, intentional negligence, lack of cooperation, and previous infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included: serious nature of multiple principle violations, significant impact on data subject's mourning process, long duration (3+ years), intentional/negligent character, lack of cooperation with authority, and previous infringements. No mitigating factors were mentioned.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: No decision text provided for analysis

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Article 6(1)(f) for audio recordings during installation work. DPA found no legitimate interest assessment was performed and data processing was unnecessary and disproportionate, violating Article 6(1).
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a private installation company violated GDPR by making audio recordings during installation work without proper legal basis. The company claimed legitimate interest but failed to conduct an interest assessment and the processing was deemed unnecessary and disproportionate. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(b), 5(1)(c), 5(2), 6(1), and 13(1)-(2).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating circumstances included multiple violations and gross negligence. Mitigating circumstances included cooperation with authorities, termination of the practice, no previous violations, and administrative delay. The fine was set at HUF 300,000 considering the company's HUF 130 million turnover.

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for customer satisfaction surveys. The DPA found this invalid due to lack of adequate information, lack of proper relationship between data subject and controller, and failure to demonstrate necessity of data processing for the stated purpose.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found an automotive importer violated GDPR by processing customer data for satisfaction surveys without adequate information and invalid legal basis. The importer used legitimate interest but failed to demonstrate proper relationship with data subjects or necessity of collected data. The DPA imposed a 5 million HUF fine and ordered compliance within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of infringement, lack of technical measures, market position. Mitigating: negligent character, no previous infringements, data categories not sensitive. Neutral: cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage.

a7_defendant_name: District Office of the BFKH XI
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task as legal basis; DPA found this valid for health data processing; No discussion of other legal bases
a75_case_summary: DPA conducted audit finding data security deficiencies in health data processing; Controller failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures; Reprimand issued with order to bring processing into compliance; Case involved special category health data of patients
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature of data (aggravating), technical measures (aggravating), cooperation (mitigating), mitigation actions (mitigating); No systematic Art 83(2) analysis performed

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on previous consent but the DPA found the consent was invalidly maintained after withdrawal; the DPA focused on how the controller handled the withdrawal request rather than the original consent validity.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a travel services company violated GDPR when it failed to properly process a data subject's newsletter unsubscribe requests due to a technical system error. The company continued sending marketing emails for nearly two years after the data subject withdrew consent, violating Articles 6(1)(a), 12(3) and 25(1). The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered the company to inform the data subject about deletion measures taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the prolonged duration (July 2019-May 2021) as aggravating, the company's cooperation and corrective actions as mitigating, and inadequate technical measures as aggravating. Other factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for all processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information, lack of transparency, and non-compliance with GDPR requirements for valid consent.
