a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic reporting basis under Italian law; DPA found original publication legitimate but current indexing required balancing; DPA ordered technical measures to prohibit indexing by external search engines.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria of the right to be forgotten in cases involving search engines
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA ruled on right to be forgotten complaint against two newspaper publishers. Original 2014 articles about legal case were legitimate journalistic reporting, but DPA ordered technical measures to prohibit indexing by external search engines after 2019 acquittal. Both publishers received warnings for inadequate responses to data subject rights requests under Article 12.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: ANM sent disciplinary proceeding notification to prosecutor's office email instead of magistrate's personal email, causing unauthorized disclosure. DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principle (Art 5(1)(f)), data protection by design/default (Art 25), and security measures (Art 32). Fine imposed despite corrective measures taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Art 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity of violation, data sensitivity, security measures deficiency. Mitigating: negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, cooperation, spontaneous compliance, isolated incident. Neutral: none specified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found the communication of email addresses to third parties occurred without legal basis, violating Articles 5(1)(a) and 6.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines concerning the application and provision of administrative fines for the purposes of regulation (EU) no. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Bank of Italy sent mass email to competition candidates with recipients visible in CC field instead of BCC, disclosing email addresses. The DPA found violation of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 as communication lacked legal basis. The incident was isolated human error during COVID-19 period. The DPA issued reprimand considering mitigating factors and improvements made.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed with mitigating effect: isolated nature, human error, general nature of communication, no special categories data, mitigation measures taken, technical improvements implemented, no previous violations, and minor violation qualification.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: DPA found absence of appropriate legal basis for collection of personal data and processing for algorithm training purposes
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA imposed temporary limitation on OpenAI's ChatGPT processing due to multiple GDPR violations. Found no information provided to users, no legal basis for data collection/training, inaccurate processing, and no age verification exposing minors to unsuitable content. Violations of Articles 5,6,8,13,25 identified pending full investigation.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed to act as processor for Vodafone, but the DPA found Problem Solving acted as independent controller when acquiring personal data lists from third parties and transferring them to Vodafone without proper legal basis or information to data subjects.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Problem Solving acquired 4.3 million personal data records from third-party list providers and transferred them to Vodafone for telemarketing. The DPA found Problem Solving acted as independent controller, not processor, violating Articles 5(1)(a), 6, 7 and 13 by failing to provide proper information and obtain consent for data transfers. The company was fined €54,609.62 (2% of turnover) and ordered to cease processing and implement compliant procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the seriousness of violation (aggravating due to pervasive telemarketing nature, duration, and high number of data subjects), collaboration with authority (mitigating), and economic capacity (mitigating). The fine was set at 2% of turnover considering proportionality and pandemic economic context.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the camera was not functional, but the DPA found it was active and processing personal data without proper information signage and without required labor authorization for employee monitoring.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines no. 3/2019 of the European Data Protection Committee on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined a fruit/vegetable retailer €3,000 for operating CCTV without required information signage and without proper labor authorization for employee monitoring. The camera was found active despite defendant's claims it was non-functional. Violations included Articles 5(1)(a), 13 GDPR and Article 114 Italian Code.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and degree of responsibility as aggravating, absence of precedents and eventual system removal as mitigating, and economic conditions as mitigating. The fine was determined based on effectiveness, proportionality and dissuasiveness principles.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes and compliance with essentiality principle; DPA found violation as images resembled mugshots without sufficient public interest justification; dissemination exceeded journalistic limits and harmed data subjects' rights.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found RCS Mediagroup violated data protection rules by publishing police-style images of arrested individuals in journalistic context. The images resembled mugshots and lacked sufficient public interest justification. The DPA issued a reprimand and processing prohibition order but no fine, citing mitigating factors including removal upon request and good faith belief in lawfulness. The decision balances journalistic freedom with data subject rights protection.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered multiple mitigating factors: controller acted in good faith belief of lawfulness, images came from police sources, immediate removal upon request, and cooperation. The nature of sensitive police-style images was aggravating. Overall assessment favored warning over fine due to mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no role in processing but DPA found Razmataz acted as controller by selecting Flowers R and conveying instructions; DPA invalidated consent basis as consent was not documented; violation of Article 6(1)(a) found.
a75_case_summary: Razmataz Live S.r.l. engaged Flowers R for promotional email campaigns without verifying data processing compliance. DPA found Razmataz acted as controller by selecting Flowers R and conveying instructions. Violations included failure to verify consent, lack of supplier due diligence, and non-response to information request. Fine of €1,000 imposed with order to implement compliance procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligent character, no mitigation actions, lack of cooperation. Mitigating: no previous infringements, common data nature, socio-economic pandemic situation, company financials.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed contract as legal basis for processing user data for algorithm training; DPA found this invalid and ordered company to remove contract reference and rely on consent or legitimate interest instead
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA ordered OpenAI to implement corrective measures for ChatGPT's GDPR violations including transparency improvements, age verification systems, legal basis modification from contract to consent/legitimate interest, and tools for data subject rights; The DPA suspended its previous temporary limitation order pending implementation of these measures; The case involves processing of personal data for AI algorithm training without proper legal basis and inadequate information to data subjects

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Città della Salute e della Scienza University Hospital of Turin
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for scientific research purposes under Article 110 of the Italian Code and Article 9(2)(j) GDPR. The DPA found the legal basis valid due to disproportionate effort in obtaining consent and impossibility of informing data subjects, but rejected selection bias as justification.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR;WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymisation techniques;EDPB-EDPS Joint Opinion 03/2022 on the Proposal for a Regulation on the European Health Data Space
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA issued a favorable opinion on a hospital's request for prior consultation regarding processing health data of minors for epidemiological research without consent. The DPA found the processing justified due to disproportionate effort in obtaining consent but imposed conditions for data anonymization. The study analyzes emergency neurological/psychiatric accesses during COVID-19 pandemic involving 6,000-10,000 patients across multiple centers.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no legal basis for processing; DPA found consent invalid as it was never obtained; Processing was unlawful under Article 6(1)(a) and Italian Code Article 130.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Malalan Mitja violated GDPR by conducting email marketing campaigns without consent; Used randomly generated email addresses and false identity; Imposed €5,000 fine and data deletion order; Violations involved thousands of data subjects over more than a year.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: wide scope/duration, intentional disguise, manner authority became aware; Mitigating: blacklist implementation, no previous violations, cooperation, nature of data; Fine set at 0.025% of statutory maximum.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed data acquired from third party with consent guarantees, but DPA found no valid consent documentation and invalidated consent basis under Article 6(1)(a).
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned Aesse S.r.l.s. for unlawful marketing calls using personal data acquired from third-party supplier without valid consent documentation. Company failed to verify consent legitimacy, provide proper information to data subjects, and respond adequately to access requests. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1)(a), 7, 12, 13, 14, 15 and Italian Code Article 130.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: high number of data subjects, gross negligence, inadequate cooperation, discrepancy with Authority guidance. Mitigating: no previous infringements, ceased activity, company's economic capacity. Neutral: none specified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union judgment on Google Spain and Inc. and Google v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González in relation to the right to be forgotten;Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria of the Right to be Forgotten in the search engines cases under the GDPR (part 1)
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA ordered Google LLC to remove search results linking complainant's name to decade-old articles about criminal charges for which he was acquitted. The DPA found Google's refusal unjustified as the outdated information violated accuracy principles under Article 5(1)(d). The decision applied EDPB guidelines on right to be forgotten, requiring removal within 20 days.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed data was manifestly made public by data subjects under Article 9(2)(e), but DPA rejected this argument finding no evidence of public disclosure and that sharing with limited individuals did not constitute manifestly public data.
a75_case_summary: Condominium administrator emailed all residents identifying COVID-positive family members. DPA found violation of Article 9 as health data processing lacked legal basis. Purpose of health protection could have been achieved without identifying individuals, violating data minimization principle.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature of violation (health data disclosure) as aggravating, absence of previous violations as mitigating, and that only two data subjects were involved as mitigating. Economic conditions of offender were also considered.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Dutch authority concluded no violation of Article 6(1) occurred as the processing resulted from fraudulent account creation and the account was immediately blocked; no valid legal basis assessment was needed since no legitimate processing occurred.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA adopted Dutch lead authority's decision finding no GDPR violations; complaint involved fraudulent account creation at Dutch bank where account was immediately blocked; case determined to involve criminal fraud rather than data protection violations; complaint was dismissed as unfounded.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for monitoring activities, but the DPA found the processing unlawful due to lack of proper information about monitoring purposes and methods, violating transparency obligations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines of the Guarantor for e-mail and internet, Provision 1/3/2007, n. 13
a75_case_summary: SWG S.p.A. monitored an employee's IT activities without proper transparency information. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 13 GDPR due to inadequate information about monitoring purposes and methods. The company claimed legitimate interest but failed to provide clear information about control activities. A €15,000 fine was imposed considering the nature of violations and cooperation factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating, while cooperation, absence of previous violations, and small number of data subjects were mitigating. The company's conduct in employment context and reference to defensive investigations were also considered in sanction determination.

a2_authority_name: The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes under Article 137 of the Italian Code, but the DPA found the processing unlawful as it violated the essentiality principle and Deontological Rules regarding health data dissemination.
a75_case_summary: Citynews S.p.A. published health data including a detailed laboratory report about a mafia boss in a journalistic article. The DPA found this violated data minimization principles and journalistic deontological rules regarding health data. The company took remedial actions but was fined €15,000 for the violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating factors included harm to dignity (a), nature of data processed (g), and economic conditions (k); mitigating factors included measures taken to remedy (c) and journalistic purposes pursued.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: Volkswagen Leasing GmbH failed to fully respond to a data subject's access request regarding creditworthiness information obtained from CRIF S.p.A. The company only provided partial documentation and directed the complainant to contact CRIF directly rather than providing the credit report itself. The Italian DPA found violations of Articles 12 and 15 GDPR for insufficient response to access requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/duration of violation and sensitive data type. Mitigating factors included absence of intent, cooperation with authority, no previous violations, and remedial actions taken. The company's economic conditions were also considered.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed contractual purposes for data retention but the DPA found violations of data minimization and storage limitation principles, particularly regarding indefinite retention of customer data beyond what was necessary for the purposes.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Benetton Group violated GDPR principles on data minimization, storage limitation, and security measures. The company retained excessive customer data indefinitely and had inadequate security protocols for store access to loyalty program data. The DPA imposed corrective orders for data deletion and security improvements, plus a €240,000 fine considering both aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included high number of data subjects, duration of violations, and company's economic importance. Mitigating factors included corrective measures taken, absence of previous violations, cooperation with authority, and pandemic-related financial difficulties.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes under national provisions, but the DPA found the processing violated principles of lawfulness, fairness, and minimization as the images were acquired using invasive techniques and their dissemination was disproportionate to the journalistic purpose pursued.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found RCS Mediagroup violated GDPR principles by publishing private photographs taken with invasive techniques from a celebrity's home. The images showed intimate moments and were acquired remotely without consent. The DPA determined the processing was disproportionate to journalistic purposes and issued a €40,660 fine with prohibition on further dissemination.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included seriousness of violation (private data collected invasively), duration of violation, previous infringements, and defendant's economic conditions. Mitigating factors included journalistic purpose and cooperation with authority. The fine was set at 0.2% of statutory maximum.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed processing was for defensive judicial purposes but DPA found no specific explicit legitimate purpose; processing violated principles of purpose limitation minimization storage limitation and integrity confidentiality
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines of the Guarantor for electronic mail and internet Provision 1/3/2007 n. 13;Recommendation CM/Rec (2015) 5 of the Committee of Ministers to the Member States on the processing of personal data in the employment context
a75_case_summary: Geico S.p.A. kept former employees' email accounts active for approximately two years after termination redirecting messages to other company accounts; DPA found violations of information obligations and Article 5 principles including purpose limitation minimization storage limitation integrity confidentiality and fairness; Company claimed processing was for defensive judicial purposes but DPA found no specific explicit legitimate purpose; €40000 fine imposed considering nature duration cooperation and absence of previous violations
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature and gravity was aggravating; cooperation was mitigating; absence of previous violations was mitigating; fine was based on effectiveness proportionality and dissuasiveness considering company's economic conditions

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: ASPI claimed Free to X was controller for Cashback service, but DPA found ASPI was controller as it determined purposes and essential means of processing; Free to X acted as processor despite contractual designation stating otherwise.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Autostrade per l'Italia violated GDPR by incorrectly designating Free to X as controller instead of processor for Cashback service processing. ASPI determined purposes and essential means but failed to properly inform users and designate processor. Violations concerned principles of lawfulness/fairness/transparency (Art 5(1)(a)), information obligations (Art 13), and processor designation (Art 28) affecting ~100,000 users.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of violations (~1 year), negligent conduct. Mitigating: measures to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, no previous infringements, no economic benefit from processing. Neutral: not specified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for marketing and profiling activities. The DPA did not explicitly invalidate consent but found transparency violations regarding information about data processing purposes and retention periods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data protection impact assessment (WP248rev.01);Guidelines on transparency (wp260rev.01)
a75_case_summary: La Rinascente was fined for GDPR violations including inadequate security measures leading to data breaches, insufficient transparency in privacy notices, excessive 7-year data retention for marketing purposes without proper justification, and failure to conduct a data protection impact assessment for large-scale profiling activities. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a)(b)(c)(e)(f), 12(1), 32(1)(b)(d), and 35(1). The company was ordered to establish differentiated retention times and delete/anonymize data beyond necessary periods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included high number of data subjects, duration of violations, broad territorial scope, and company's economic capacity. Mitigating factors included absence of previous infringements, timely corrective measures, and socio-economic crisis effects. The fine was set at €300,000 considering proportionality.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Local Health Authority of South East Tuscany
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unlawful without assessing specific legal bases, determining that health data dissemination violated GDPR principles and special category data rules.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for purposes of advertising and transparency on the web by public subjects and other bodies obliged
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA sanctioned a local health authority for displaying an advertising billboard in an emergency department corridor that showed a patient's name and surname alongside emergency medical service information. The DPA found this constituted unlawful dissemination of health data in violation of GDPR principles and special category data rules. The authority considered mitigating factors including prompt removal, cooperation, staff training, and new procedures, but imposed a €20,000 fine due to the sensitive nature of health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature of health data and gravity of dissemination. Mitigating factors included prompt cooperation, remedial actions, staff training, new procedures, and the COVID-19 context. Previous violations were considered neutral as they didn't involve health data dissemination.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Cooperjob S.p.A. failed to respond to a data subject's erasure request within the required timeframe. The company only complied after intervention by the Italian DPA. The DPA found violations of Articles 12(3) and 17 regarding timely response to data subject requests and erasure obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of violation (rights-related) as aggravating. Mitigating factors included: culpable nature due to operational difficulties, actions to mitigate damage through data deletion, technical measures implemented, absence of previous violations, cooperation with authority, and providing response during proceedings.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Municipality claimed processing was necessary for public task purposes under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this legal basis valid for waste management enforcement but noted the processing violated multiple GDPR principles despite the valid legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: The Municipality of Modica used video surveillance for waste management enforcement from 2017-2021. The DPA found violations including inadequate information provision, excessive data retention (15 days instead of 7), lack of proper data processor agreements, and delayed DPO appointment. Processing occurred in public areas affecting numerous data subjects over an extended period.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the long duration and public nature of processing as aggravating factors. Non-intentional behavior, cooperation with authorities, and lack of previous violations were mitigating. The fine was reduced from the maximum due to these mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The company acted as processor without proper data processing agreement as required by Article 28. The DPA found processing occurred without lawful basis and in violation of lawfulness principle.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the concepts of owner and manager of processing in the GDPR no. 07/2020
a75_case_summary: Cat s.r.l. processed personal data through video surveillance for waste management without proper data processing agreement as processor. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 due to lack of lawful basis and failure to comply with processor requirements. A €10,000 fine was imposed considering the scope affected all residents but absence of intent and prior violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the scope affecting all residents as aggravating, non-intentional behavior and absence of previous violations as mitigating. Article 83(2) factors were discussed but not systematically.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for aggregate analysis but DPA found no profiling occurred; legal basis discussion focused on marketing consent issues; DPA dismissed profiling violation claim
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679 (wp260rev.01);Article 29 Working Party Guidelines on legitimate interests
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Tiscali violated GDPR principles regarding transparency, purpose limitation, data minimization, storage limitation and accountability in marketing activities. The company failed to provide adequate information about data retention periods, used excessive storage times (up to 10 years), and lacked proper procedures to track consent changes. DPA imposed €100,000 fine and corrective measures including establishing proper retention periods and implementing consent tracking procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered timely corrective measures, cooperation with authority, national market role, and company's financial crisis as mitigating factors. No aggravating factors were identified. Fine was set at 0.5% of statutory maximum considering proportionality and dissuasiveness principles.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing under Article 110 of Italian Code which exempts consent for medical research when informing data subjects is impossible or involves disproportionate effort. The DPA found the legal basis valid due to the high mortality rate of patients and reasonable efforts made to contact them through regional health registries.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent; Guidelines on transparency; Opinion 3/2019 on Clinical Trials Regulation interaction; WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymization techniques; Guidelines concerning data protection impact assessment WP248rev.01
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA issued a favorable opinion on a multicenter observational study involving deceased or uncontactable lung cancer patients. The hospital requested prior consultation under Article 110 of Italian Code and Article 36 GDPR. The DPA found the legal basis valid but required modifications to information notices and additional safeguards for data anonymization at study conclusion.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of proper information provision and failure to verify original consent from data provider. The DPA rejected the controller's argument that it was merely a processor.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB guidelines 4/2022;Guidelines on promotional activities and combating spam - 4 July 2013
a75_case_summary: Compara Facile S.r.l. conducted telemarketing using data from Moldovan provider without proper consent verification. The DPA found multiple GDPR violations including lack of transparency information, invalid consent basis, failure to respond to data subject rights, and failure to consult opposition register. The company was fined €40,000 and ordered to implement compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included high number of data subjects, seriousness of violations, negligent conduct, dissimilarity from regulatory activity, and economic capacity. Mitigating factors included absence of previous proceedings and cooperation with authority.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid due to coercion of will through mandatory acceptance of marketing consent to access services, and lack of proof of valid consent for promotional calls.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Maximum International Corp. responsible for multiple GDPR violations related to telemarketing and website data processing. The company failed to control third-party call centers using its brand for unauthorized promotional calls and implemented coercive consent mechanisms on its website. Violations included lack of valid consent, failure to honor data subject rights, and inadequate organizational measures. The DPA imposed €5,000 fine and corrective orders including data deletion and compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included seriousness of violations, negligent conduct, and inconsistency with regulatory activity. Mitigating factors included common data nature, absence of previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and consideration of company's economic capacity. The fine was set at 0.025% of statutory maximum.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unlawful due to lack of proper information signs and failure to follow the required authorization procedure under Article 114 of the Code regarding employee monitoring, regardless of employee awareness.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices;Provision on video surveillance - 8 April 2010
a75_case_summary: Prodav s.r.l. operated a video surveillance system in its retail store without proper information signs and without required authorization from the Labor Inspectorate for employee monitoring. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 13 GDPR regarding transparency and information obligations, and Article 114 of the Italian Code regarding employee protection procedures. The company removed the camera after inspection and cooperated with authorities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and categories of data as aggravating factors. The company's good faith, cooperation, remedial actions, lack of precedents, and economic conditions were mitigating factors. The manner the infringement became known was considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic exemption under Article 85 and Italian Code provisions, arguing will data was public and essential. The DPA found the publication violated the principle of essentiality of information, as the complainant's personal data was not indispensable to the news story and exceeded what was necessary for correct information.
a75_case_summary: RCS Mediagroup published an article on Corriere della Sera containing a photographic reproduction of a holographic will that revealed the complainant's full personal data. The DPA found this violated journalistic ethics rules and Article 5 principles by publishing excessive personal data not essential to the news story. A €10,000 fine was imposed considering aggravating factors including nature of violation, delayed remediation, and previous infringements, while acknowledging the journalistic purpose as mitigating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of violation, actions to mitigate damage only after procedure initiation, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included the journalistic purposes pursued and that only one complainant was involved. The DPA considered the defendant's economic conditions as aggravating.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed contract basis but DPA found processing occurred without data subject's knowledge or desire to complete contract, making legal basis invalid.
a75_case_summary: GFB One s.r.l., a Vodafone dealer, activated two SIM cards using a copy of complainant's ID without proper verification. The DPA found GFB acted as independent controller, violating Articles 5(1)(a), 6 and 13 by processing without valid legal basis and failing to provide information. The company also failed to respond to the Authority's information request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity (aggravating), intentional character (aggravating), lack of mitigation efforts (aggravating), lack of cooperation (aggravating), and economic capacity (mitigating). Fine set at €90,000 (0.45% of maximum).

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Mednow Medical Center di Giugni Marco
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not explicitly claim a legal basis for the processing. The DPA found the communication of health data to an unauthorized third party violated Article 9 as it lacked any legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) No. 2016/679;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA sanctioned a medical center for GDPR violations related to COVID-19 testing. The controller processed inaccurate patient data, sent a health report to an unauthorized email address, and failed to respond to data subject rights requests. The DPA considered the pandemic context as mitigating but found violations of accuracy, security, special data protection, and data subject rights obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The nature of health data was aggravating, while the isolated incidents, good faith error, cooperation with authority, lack of previous violations, and pandemic operational difficulties were all mitigating factors. The manner the infringement became known was neutral.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest and consent from third parties;DPA found consent invalid due to lack of verification and legitimate interest invalid for marketing purposes;Key reasoning: consent must be specific,documented,and from data subjects themselves,not third parties
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Caffè Scionti violated GDPR through unlawful telemarketing practices;Company made promotional calls without proper consent,using random dialing,word-of-mouth referrals,and third-party data lists without verification;Violations included lack of transparency,failure to honor data subject rights,and inadequate organizational measures;DPA imposed €70,000 fine and corrective orders including data deletion and compliance measures
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors;Aggravating: seriousness/duration of violations,inadequate cooperation,discrepancy with regulatory activity;Mitigating: no previous infringements,nature of data processed;Neutral: none specifically mentioned

a2_authority_name: The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for security purposes, but the DPA found no evidence of actual risk justifying the processing of public areas and audio recordings, invalidating the legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines no. 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found an individual violated GDPR by installing CCTV that captured public playground areas and audio recordings without valid legal basis. The controller claimed legitimate interest for security but provided insufficient evidence of actual risk. The DPA issued a reprimand as the violation was minor and the controller had already replaced the camera to limit filming to private areas.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the violation minor under Article 83(2) and Recital 148. Mitigating factors included the controller's cooperation, remedial actions taken, and the violation having exhausted its effects. No aggravating factors were discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6 for health data processing; DPA found consent invalid as healthcare professionals should not request consent for treatment purposes under GDPR, and consent for thesis purpose was not specific and informed.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679;WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymization techniques
a75_case_summary: An osteopath processed patient health data in a thesis without proper anonymization. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, 9, 12, and 13 due to invalid consent, inadequate information, and unauthorized communication to third parties. A reprimand was issued along with corrective orders to update privacy documentation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Nature of data was aggravating; intentional/negligent character, mitigation actions, technical measures, previous infringements, cooperation, and other factors were mitigating. The violation was classified as minor.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Region claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) for legal obligation and Article 6(1)(e) for public task, citing transparency obligations under Legislative Decree 33/2013. The DPA found these legal bases invalid as the legislation did not authorize publication of employee personal data or health data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for advertising and transparency purposes on the web by public entities and other obliged bodies
a75_case_summary: The Lombardy Region published personal data of approximately 732 employees including salary information and ongoing disputes on its website for over a year, claiming legal obligation under transparency laws. The DPA found no legal basis existed for publishing employee data and health information, violating GDPR principles and special category data protections. A €20,000 fine was imposed considering data sensitivity, duration of publication, and mitigating factors including prompt removal and pandemic context.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of violation, categories of data affected, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included prompt removal actions, cooperation with authority, and pandemic emergency circumstances. The violation duration was considered aggravating while the Region's organizational measures were assessed as inadequate.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic exemption and public interest justification. The DPA found violations of accuracy, minimization, and lawfulness principles, noting failure to verify health-related information and correct inaccuracies despite requests.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found newspaper violated GDPR by publishing inaccurate health information about a municipal councilor's COVID-19 status without verification. The publication failed to correct errors despite requests and violated principles of accuracy, minimization, and lawfulness. A €20,000 fine was imposed along with an order to cease dissemination of the inaccurate data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included seriousness of health data violation, failure to mitigate harm, and poor cooperation. Mitigating factors included public interest justification and absence of previous violations. The fine was set at 0.1% of maximum possible amount.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the right of access
a75_case_summary: Amazon Italia Transport failed to respond to a former employee's Article 15 access request within statutory deadlines, taking nearly six months to comply only after complaint and investigation. The company claimed internal coordination difficulties due to broad request nature but failed to use GDPR mechanisms to seek clarification or notify delay reasons. The Italian DPA found violations of Articles 12(3) and 15 regarding access rights and transparency obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration and manner infringement became known were aggravating. Negligent nature, cooperation, mitigation actions, technical measures improvements, and economic conditions were mitigating. The sanction was set at €40,000 considering effectiveness, proportionality, and dissuasiveness principles.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for property protection. The DPA found this invalid as the administrator lacked a legitimate interest, effective and current, linked to a real risk situation, and proper balancing with fundamental rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines n. 3/2019 on the processing of personal data using video devices
a75_case_summary: A condominium administrator installed CCTV without required assembly resolution. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 as processing lacked lawfulness basis and transparency. The administrator was fined €1000 and processing was prohibited.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating and absence of previous infringements as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: A.O.U. Città della Salute e della Scienza di Torino
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing under Article 110 of the Italian Code for deceased/uncontactable patients in medical research. The DPA found the legal bases correctly identified with adequate justification for impossibility to inform/obtain consent due to high mortality rates and observation periods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines concerning the impact assessment on data protection as well as the criteria for establishing whether a processing may present a high risk pursuant to Regulation 2016/679 - WP248rev.01
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA issued a favorable opinion on two medical research studies involving deceased/uncontactable patients. The controller correctly identified legal bases under Article 110 of Italian Code, justifying impossibility to inform/obtain consent due to high mortality rates. The DPA required additional measures including ensuring information availability on websites and clarifying data protection roles for multicenter study.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found no evidence of valid consent acquisition; promotional calls were made based on geographical criteria rather than specific consent; DPA invalidated consent as legal basis for marketing activities.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned A.C. Group for unlawful telemarketing practices; Company made promotional calls without verifying consent validity or consulting Public Registry of Oppositions; DPA found violations of transparency obligations and accountability principle; Fine imposed reflected aggravating factors (seriousness, high data volume) and mitigating factors (cooperation, micro-enterprise status, minor harm).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: seriousness of violations, high number of data processed, discrepancy with Authority's regulatory activity; Mitigating: no previous infringements, nature of data and minor harm, cooperation with Authority, micro-enterprise status; Neutral factors not specifically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was justified for journalistic purposes under sector provisions, but the DPA found the publication of excessive identifying details violated the principle of essentiality of information, especially regarding a minor.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found newspaper publisher violated data protection principles by publishing excessive identifying details about a robbery victim and her minor daughter. The article contained name, address, photos, and family details that enabled identification. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered restrictions on further processing while acknowledging the publisher had removed the online version.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the publisher's remedial actions (removing online content) as mitigating and the absence of previous violations as mitigating. The involvement of a minor's data was considered aggravating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess legal bases as the case focused on data subject rights and journalistic processing exemptions rather than establishing a valid legal basis under Article 6.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 1/2022 on the exercise of rights;Guidelines on the right of access adopted by the EDPB on 23 March 2023
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found R.T.I. S.p.a. violated transparency obligations by failing to respond to a data subject's erasure request sent via official PEC address. The DPA acknowledged the journalistic nature of the content but found the company should have responded within regulatory timelines. A warning was issued emphasizing the need to facilitate rights exercise through various communication channels.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of the infringement as mitigating, characterizing it as an "involuntary failure" rather than intentional negligence. The company's subsequent removal of content was viewed as mitigating action. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed to rely on consent but failed to provide evidence of valid consent acquisition. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of proper information provision and documentation proving free, specific, informed consent.
a75_case_summary: Limit Call S.r.l.s., a telemarketing call center, processed personal data acquired from a Moldovan list provider without verifying lawfulness. The DPA found multiple violations including lack of proper information provision, invalid consent basis, failure to facilitate data subject rights, and insufficient cooperation. An administrative fine of €60,000 was imposed alongside corrective measures including data deletion and processing prohibition.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included seriousness of violations, negligent conduct, absence of mitigation measures, and disregard for regulatory activity. The only mitigating factor was the company's economic capacity based on turnover. The fine amount considered both aggravating and mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal bases under Article 6(1)(b) contract and 6(1)(f) legitimate interests. The DPA found both invalid as the processing was not objectively necessary for contract execution and no legitimate interest balancing test was conducted.
a75_case_summary: Sirio S.p.A. communicated employee personal data to a credit institution for deposit card issuance without adequate information or valid legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 13 GDPR. The company claimed contract execution and legitimate interests but failed to demonstrate necessity or conduct proper balancing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature of violation (data communication to third parties) as aggravating. Absence of previous violations and single affected data subject were mitigating factors. Economic conditions were considered in sanction determination.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was legitimized by legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)). The DPA found no evidence of legal obligation and determined legitimate interests did not apply due to lack of urgency and availability of proper notification methods.
a75_case_summary: A lawyer sent judicial documents via certified email to a company mailbox accessible by multiple individuals instead of the data subject's personal address. The DPA found violations of data minimization (Art 5(1)(c)) and lack of legal basis (Art 6). The lawyer claimed legal obligation and legitimate interests but failed to demonstrate urgency or proper notification methods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: sensitive judicial data involved. Mitigating: no intentional attitude, good cooperation, no previous infringements, small number of affected persons. Neutral: case discovered through complaint.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed software was GDPR compliant but a bug allowed unauthorized access to health data. The DPA found inadequate security measures and testing procedures violated integrity/confidentiality principles.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found CB Sistemi violated Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR as processor for Medical Center's health data platform. A bug allowed URL manipulation revealing usernames and download times of health reports. The DPA issued a reprimand considering prompt remediation, cooperation, and limited impact on one data subject.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed. Aggravating: inadequate security measures and health data nature. Mitigating: prompt remediation, cooperation, no previous violations, limited duration and impact. Neutral: manner infringement became known.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (DPOs);Guidance document on the designation, position and duties of the Data Protection Officer (DPO) in the public sector
a75_case_summary: Municipality of Syracuse failed to communicate DPO contact details to Italian DPA as required by Article 37(7) GDPR. Violation concerned two DPO appointments (2018 and 2022) and persisted despite 2020 warning. Municipality partially remedied by communicating current DPO details in June 2023. DPA imposed €5,000 fine considering negligence, partial remediation, and no prior violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: duration and repetition (aggravating), negligent character and remedial actions (mitigating), no previous infringements (mitigating). Fine set at €5,000 considering these factors collectively.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: G. Brotzu National and High Specialization Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller argued biological samples were not personal data, but the DPA found they constituted health data under Article 9. The DPA determined the processing lacked adequate safeguards regardless of legal basis qualification.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 Version 2.0;Opinion 4/2007 on the concept of personal data;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: ARNAS Brotzu lost histological slides containing patient health data. The DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality and accountability principles due to lack of documented procedures for biological sample management. Despite remediation efforts, a €18,000 fine was imposed for failure to ensure adequate security measures and demonstrate compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of health data and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included negligent character, cooperation with authority, remedial actions taken, no previous infringements, and organizational obstacles from healthcare reforms.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for publishing health data on social media. The DPA found the consent invalid as it was not explicit, specific, and informed regarding social media publication of health data, and health data dissemination is prohibited under Italian law except with explicit consent after pseudonymization.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent;Guidelines 07/2020 on concepts of data controller and processor;WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymization techniques
a75_case_summary: David S.r.l. published a video on Instagram showing a patient during an aesthetic medicine procedure without valid consent. The DPA found health data processing violations as the consent was not explicit, specific, and informed for social media dissemination. The company was ordered to revise its information documents and fined €8,000 for multiple GDPR violations including unlawful processing of special category data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity involving health data. Mitigating: good faith, prompt remediation, cooperation, no previous violations, implemented compliance measures. The fine was reduced based on mitigating factors.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed patient consent for prescription collection method but DPA found this insufficient justification for exposing health data; DPA emphasized health data requires special protection and cannot be left accessible to undetermined subjects regardless of consent claims.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned a doctor for leaving medical prescriptions in an unlocked container accessible to the public; 67 prescriptions containing health data were found exposed; DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and security obligations regarding special category health data; fine imposed for Articles 5,9,32 violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration and data categories were aggravating; cooperation was aggravating; manner infringement became known was mitigating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; fine set at €20,000 based on overall assessment.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal obligation and public task bases under Articles 6(1)(c) and (e) but the DPA found no specific regulation authorizing the publication of absence data, making the processing unlawful.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, including those contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for advertising and transparency purposes on the web by public bodies and other obligated bodies;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines concerning the assessment of the impact on data protection and the criteria for establishing whether a processing operation is likely to present a high risk
a75_case_summary: An Italian school published 37 management decisions on its website containing teachers' names and absence dates. The DPA found this violated GDPR principles as no specific legal basis authorized such publication. The school claimed organizational difficulties during COVID-19 but cooperated by removing data and implementing new procedures. A €2000 fine was imposed considering mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity and data sensitivity. Mitigating factors included lack of intent, cooperation, remedial actions, organizational measures, no previous violations, and COVID-19 context. The violation was deemed medium severity.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale degli Spedali Civili di Brescia
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 9(2)(j) and Article 110 of Italian Code. The DPA found the legal bases correctly identified for deceased/uncontactable subjects under prior consultation procedure, and consent for contactable patients.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the impact assessment on data protection as well as the criteria for establishing whether a processing may present a high risk;Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default;WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymization techniques;A Preliminary Opinion on data protection and scientific research
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued favorable opinion on medical research study processing health data of deceased/uncontactable laryngeal cancer patients. Study involves developing predictive algorithm using retrospective data from 300 patients across 20 Italian centers. DPA approved processing under Article 110 Italian Code/Article 9(2)(j) GDPR due to impossibility of consent, but imposed conditions including transparency measures, data minimization, and 10-year retention limit.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed security measures were not contractually required and they couldn't implement them independently since the system resided on hospital's environment. The DPA found the processor had obligations under Article 28 to implement adequate security measures regardless of contractual terms and location.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Dedalus Italia S.p.a, as data processor for Bambino Gesù Pediatric Hospital, failed to implement adequate security measures for its DNLAB software integration component, resulting in a bug that caused health data breaches. The bug led to 6 patients' reports being accessible to unauthorized persons and 8 patients experiencing unavailability of their reports. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 9, and 32 GDPR, imposing an €8,000 fine despite the processor's defense that security measures weren't contractually required and couldn't be implemented independently.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included health data category, duration (4 days), number of data subjects affected, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included absence of intent, cooperation with authority, and actions to mitigate damage. The violation was assessed as medium severity.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed adequate security measures were in place; the DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and security obligations due to vulnerabilities allowing unauthorized access to personal data.
a75_case_summary: UniCredit suffered a cyber attack on its mobile banking portal exposing personal data of 777,765 customers. The DPA found security deficiencies including a vulnerability allowing data exposure during failed login attempts and inadequate brute force protection. Despite UniCredit's arguments about sophisticated attacks and third-party responsibility, the DPA held them liable for violating integrity/confidentiality principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; mitigation measures were mitigating; cooperation was mitigating; previous infringements were aggravating; data categories were neutral; intentional/negligent character was neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found NTT Data violated Article 28(2) by engaging sub-processor Truel IT without prior written authorization from the controller, and violated Article 33(2) by failing to notify the controller of the personal data breach without undue delay after becoming aware of it.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 9/2022 on the notification of personal data breaches pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: NTT Data Italia S.p.a. was found to have violated Articles 28(2) and 33(2) GDPR. The company engaged sub-processor Truel IT without prior written authorization from controller UniCredit, and failed to notify the controller of a personal data breach without undue delay after becoming aware of vulnerabilities that were later exploited in a cyber attack. The DPA imposed an €800,000 fine considering the negligent nature of violations but acknowledged mitigating factors including cooperation and absence of previous infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The nature and duration of violations were aggravating, while the negligent (not intentional) character, actions to mitigate damage, absence of previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other mitigating factors (including early GDPR application period) were considered mitigating. The categories of personal data affected were considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis for processing health data; DPA found consent valid for initial processing but invalid for data sharing due to insufficient information; Key reasoning was failure to inform patients about legal basis for sharing data with healthcare professionals.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2021 on examples regarding the notification of a personal data breach; Guidelines 5/2020 on consent pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679; Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR; Guidelines on transparency pursuant to Regulation 2016/679; Opinion 02/2013 (WP202) on applications for intelligent devices
a75_case_summary: Medtronic Italia violated GDPR by sending server maintenance emails with 732 Italian recipients' addresses visible in CC field, disclosing health data. Additionally, failed to provide adequate information about legal basis for sharing patient data with healthcare professionals via HPS functionality. DPA found violations of principles, transparency obligations, and security measures regarding health data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity involving health data, inadequate security measures. Mitigating: negligent not intentional character, immediate remedial actions, cooperation with authority, no previous infringements. Neutral: Not discussed for some factors. Overall assessment led to €300,000 fine.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess specific legal bases as the case focused on rights violations and minimization principle rather than legal basis validity.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines of the Guarantor for electronic mail and Internet
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found MP1 s.r.l. violated GDPR by failing to properly respond to data subject's erasure request and redirecting former employee's email account for at least 7 months post-termination. The company claimed redirection was necessary for transitional order management but failed to demonstrate proportionality or necessity. Violations included Articles 5(1)(c), 12, and 17 regarding minimization principle and rights response obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating (rights violations lasting 7+ months), intentional/negligent character as aggravating, cooperation with authority as mitigating, and economic conditions/limited scope as mitigating factors. The sanction was reduced from maximum based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on employment relationship obligations but DPA found no valid legal basis for processing former employees' data in bills after termination. The DPA determined Articles 6(1)(b) and (c) could not justify continued processing post-employment.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found violations regarding processing former employees' data in company bills after employment termination and failure to properly respond to access requests. The company continued using bills containing complainants' initials and surnames despite termination and access requests for training certificates. The DPA determined violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, 12, 15 and 17 of GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character were aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and economic conditions were mitigating. The sanction was reduced considering the company's micro-enterprise status and good faith efforts.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Euro Servizi per i Notai S.r.l.
a36_legal_basis_summary: ESPN claimed legitimate interest as legal basis for processing notary authentication credentials and reports. DPA found authentication processing should be based on Article 6(1)(b) contract, and report processing lacked any valid legal basis as ESPN acted autonomously without bank instructions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor;Opinion of 9 April 2014, WP 217 of the Art. 29 Working Group
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found ESPN violated GDPR by using incorrect legal basis (legitimate interest) for processing notary authentication credentials and by autonomously sending reports to notaries without valid legal basis. ESPN processed authentication credentials under Article 6(1)(b) contract basis and reports lacked any legal basis as ESPN acted beyond bank instructions. DPA imposed €5,000 fine and ordered compliance within six months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature of violations aggravating. Mitigating factors included company cooperation during procedure, regularization of information provision, and no previous violations. Economic conditions based on 2022 revenues were considered in determining proportionate sanction.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Territorial Agency of the Puglia Region for the waste management service (AGER)
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data protection officers;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined AGER €6,000 for failing to designate a DPO promptly (3-year delay), failing to inform data subjects of DPO contact details, and failing to communicate DPO details to the supervisory authority. The violations stemmed from organizational challenges during the agency's startup phase and COVID-19 pandemic. The DPA found medium severity violations but applied mitigating factors including remedial actions and no prior infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity was aggravating (medium severity). Intentional/negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other factors were all mitigating. The violations resulted from organizational challenges during startup and pandemic.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: local social and health authority no. 1 of Sassari
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed health data without proper authorization. The DPA found the processing violated Article 9 as health data was transmitted to an unauthorized third party without legal basis. No valid legal basis was established for the processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A local health authority mistakenly emailed a patient's health data to a third party. The DPA found violations of Articles 5, 9 and 32 GDPR and Article 157 of Italian Code. The authority failed to respond to information requests and lacked adequate security measures for health data transmission.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature of health data affected. Mitigating factors included non-intentional nature, actions to mitigate damage, and implementation of security measures. The violation concerned only a specific internal structure.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed reliance on Article 9(2)(b) based on manufacturer certification, but the DPA found no valid legal basis as Italian law does not permit biometric data processing for employee attendance monitoring, regardless of encryption or supplier guarantees.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data protection impact assessment (DPIA) and determining whether processing is likely to result in a high risk; Guidelines 05/2022 on the use of facial recognition technology in the area of law enforcement; Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined a waste management company €70,000 for using facial recognition to monitor employee attendance without legal basis. The system processed biometric data of 276+ employees across multiple sites. Violations included unlawful processing of special category data, lack of transparency, inadequate security measures, failure to conduct DPIA, and improper processor agreements. The company claimed absenteeism problems but less invasive alternatives existed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration (AGGRAVATING), intentional/negligent character (AGGRAVATING), technical measures (AGGRAVATING), and data categories (AGGRAVATING) as increasing the sanction. Cooperation with authority (MITIGATING) and damage mitigation actions (MITIGATING) reduced the sanction. The company's economic conditions were considered in the final determination.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Wi-Planet sas di Torri Carlo Alberto e C.
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful based on contract existence. The DPA did not explicitly invalidate this legal basis but found violations related to data subject rights fulfillment.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Wi-Planet violated Articles 12(3) and 15 by failing to respond to data subject's access request for approximately 10 months. Company claimed organizational difficulties due to pandemic but DPA rejected this defense. DPA ordered compliance with access request and imposed €5,000 fine, considering violation duration but also company's cooperation and remedial measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating. Intentional/negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, technical measures, previous infringements, cooperation, and other factors were mitigating. Categories of data and manner infringement became known were neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for cookie processing; the DPA found this invalid as cookies require consent under Article 122 of the Code; legitimate interest was incorrectly applied even though only technical cookies were actually used.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on cookies and other tracking tools
a75_case_summary: Maggioli S.p.A. used cookie banners on 8 websites that lacked clear information about the X command meaning and incorrectly referenced legitimate interest as legal basis. The DPA found violations of transparency principles and accountability obligations. The company cooperated, made corrections, and switched suppliers, leading to a warning instead of fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered several mitigating factors: prompt corrective actions, no actual harm to data subjects, cooperation with authority, and first-time violation. The selection of an inadequate processor was considered aggravating. Overall factors supported issuing a warning rather than a fine.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for biometric data processing. The DPA found the consent invalid due to lack of transparency about risks and the promise of free tokens negatively impacting consent conditions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices;Guidelines 05/2022 on the use of facial recognition technologies for police tasks
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued warning to Worldcoin Foundation regarding planned iris scanning biometric data processing in Italy. Found consent invalid due to insufficient transparency about risks and promise of free cryptocurrency tokens. Processing involves high risks including potential collection of minors' biometric data without age verification.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed nature/gravity of infringement (aggravating), categories of personal data affected (aggravating), and other factors including risks to minors (aggravating). No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed health data through electronic health records. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f), 9, 25 and 32 due to inadequate access controls allowing unauthorized healthcare personnel to access patient records without proper treatment relationship.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA sanctioned Alto Adige Health Authority for inadequate security measures in its electronic health record system, allowing unauthorized access by healthcare personnel to patient records. The case involved multiple complaints and breach notifications about healthcare professionals accessing records of patients not under their care. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f), 9, 25 and 32, noting this was a repeat offense as similar issues were identified in a 2014 decision.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors.
