Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, categories of data affected, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, and cooperation with authority. The manner infringement became known was considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Banca di Credito Cooperativo Appulo Lucana soc. cooperative
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the right of access
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned cooperative bank for failing to properly respond to former employee's data access request regarding disciplinary proceedings. Bank initially provided incomplete documentation and failed to communicate reasons for withholding certain correspondence. DPA found violations of Articles 12(3)-(4) and 15 GDPR regarding access rights and transparency obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature of violation (rights of data subjects) as aggravating; absence of previous violations and provision of feedback during proceedings as mitigating; economic conditions considered for proportionality.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found processing occurred without any legal basis as SIM cards and services were activated without customer knowledge or consent.
a75_case_summary: Sigma s.r.l., a Vodafone franchisee, systematically activated SIM cards and services using customer data without consent to meet sales targets. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(2), 6, 13, 24(1) and 25(1) for unlawful processing and lack of transparency. A €150,000 fine was imposed due to intentional conduct, lack of mitigation, and failure to cooperate.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: seriousness (aggravating), intentional nature (aggravating), lack of mitigation actions (aggravating), data categories (aggravating), and lack of cooperation (aggravating). No mitigating factors were identified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent from telesellers but DPA found consent invalid due to contacting numbers registered in Public Opposition Register and inadequate verification of legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned energy company Facile.Energy for unlawful telemarketing practices involving unsolicited calls and contract activations. Company failed to verify legal basis for processing and implement adequate controls over third-party telesellers. DPA found violations of GDPR principles and Italian telemarketing regulations, imposing €100,000 fine and corrective measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Seriousness of violations, intentional/negligent character, categories of data affected, and manner infringement became known were aggravating. Remedial actions were mitigating but insufficient. Lack of full cooperation was aggravating. Company had no prior sanctions from this authority.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: BdM Banca failed to respond to an access request from a data subject within the required timeframe. The bank claimed operational issues including incorrect email routing and misclassification of the request. The DPA found violations of Article 12(3) and (4) regarding timely response to data subject requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature of violation concerning data subject rights. Mitigating: degree of responsibility attenuated, measures to mitigate consequences, cooperation with Authority, small number of affected parties, organizational measures implemented, absence of previous violations. Neutral: categories of data affected, manner infringement became known.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Innova Camera - Special Agency of the Rome Chamber of Commerce, Industry, Crafts and Agriculture for Innovation
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor pursuant to the GDPR;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Innova Camera, as data processor for Rome Chamber of Commerce, failed to delete a backup copy containing personal data of 22,334 users after server migration. The backup was compromised in a cyber attack due to inadequate security measures, including use of outdated MD5 hashing for passwords. The DPA found violations of storage limitation and integrity/confidentiality principles, imposing €25,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was mitigating (human error); mitigation actions were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; previous infringements were mitigating (first time); cooperation was mitigating; data categories were neutral.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Municipality claimed public security and judicial police purposes but the DPA found these invalid. The processing was found to lack legal basis as it violated Article 4 of Italian Law 300/1970 regarding workplace monitoring requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices;Opinion 2/2017 on the processing of data in the workplace;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Municipality violated GDPR by using workplace video surveillance without proper union agreement or Labor Inspectorate authorization. The camera was used for disciplinary purposes against an employee and lacked proper transparency information. The DPA imposed €3,000 fine and ordered compliance with information obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the violation severity high due to non-compliance with sector regulations. Mitigating factors included no previous violations and the municipality's small size (2,700 inhabitants). The violation concerned specific internal structure rather than overall organization.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data protection officers (DPOs);Guideline document on the designation, position and duties of the Data Protection Officer (DPO) in the public sector
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Free Municipal Consortium of Enna violated GDPR Articles 37(1) and (7) by failing to designate a DPO for over 3.5 years and failing to publish/communicate DPO contact details. Also violated Article 38(2) and (6) by appointing an employee with multiple managerial roles who lacked sufficient time/resources and faced potential conflicts of interest. The DPA imposed €6,000 fine considering the negligent nature, remedial actions taken, and absence of prior violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged non-compliance. Intentional/negligent character was mitigating as violation was negligent. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as Consortium appointed new DPO and remedied violations. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to inadequate DPO resources. Previous infringements were mitigating as no prior violations. Other factors were neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Gestore Dei Servizi Energetici - Gse S.p.A.
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: GSE S.p.A. failed to respond to a former employee's access requests regarding performance evaluation files for 11 months. The DPA found violations of Articles 12 and 15 GDPR for delayed response to data subject rights. The company claimed IT issues but failed to demonstrate adequate organizational measures to facilitate rights requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation, negligent conduct, and manner authority became aware. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and sending response after learning of complaint. The violation concerned only one data subject.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: INPS claimed processing was based on public task and legitimate interests. DPA found no valid legal basis as national regulations only permit publication of final rankings, not intermediate results. Administrative acts cannot override higher-level regulations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for advertising and transparency purposes on the web by public entities and other obliged bodies; Guidelines for the processing of personal data carried out by public entities for the purpose of publication and dissemination on the web; EDPB Guidelines on consent pursuant to EU Regulation 2016/679; Opinion 2/2017 on data processing in the workplace; Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: INPS published competition lists containing names and scores of over 5000 candidates on its website. DPA found violation of Articles 5 and 6 GDPR as publication exceeded legal basis in national regulations. Only final rankings may be published, not intermediate results. Fine imposed considering high number of data subjects and previous violations, but mitigated by cooperation and removal of data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: high number of data subjects (over 5000) and previous violations. Mitigating: good cooperation, removal of data, no special categories disclosed, and limited duration (few months). Neutral factors not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The legal basis discussion focused on the right of access under Article 15, not on processing legal bases under Article 6.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: C.I.EL. S.p.A. failed to adequately respond to an employee's Article 15 access request regarding training certificates. The company initially claimed certificates were deleted post-employment, then recovered some certificates during investigation. The DPA found violations of Articles 12 and 15 for improper response handling and failure to inform about complaint rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of violation (rights exercise), categories of data affected (special categories). Mitigating: negligent nature (not intentional), cooperation with authority, economic conditions. Neutral: Not specified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued favorable opinion on draft regulation for digital infrastructures and cloud services for public administration. The regulation establishes security requirements, migration procedures, and qualification processes for cloud services. The DPA noted the draft addressed previous concerns regarding data processing roles, breach notification mechanisms, and international data transfers.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent for marketing but DPA found no valid consent acquired for promotional messages and processing occurred without suitable legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Rossi Carta used obsolete Prestashop CMS with known vulnerabilities, failing to protect personal data from unauthorized access. The company sent unwanted promotional emails without valid consent and failed to respond properly to data subject access requests. The DPA found violations of security obligations and data subject rights, imposing a €30,000 fine and ordering technical measures to secure the website.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: severity/duration of violations, failure to mitigate damage, degree of responsibility. Mitigating: limited number of affected subjects, absence of malice, no previous violations, cooperation with authority, company size and economic losses. Neutral: none specifically mentioned.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for employment relationship management under Article 6(1)(c) and (e). The DPA found the forwarding of detailed health information was not necessary and violated principles of lawfulness, fairness, and transparency.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679;Guidelines on the processing of personal data of workers for the purposes of managing the employment relationship in the public sector
a75_case_summary: An employee complained that her hierarchical superior forwarded an email containing her health symptoms to the General Director. The DPA found the hospital violated Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 9 by unnecessarily circulating health data. The forwarding was not necessary for shift reorganization purposes and compromised confidentiality expectations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating: sensitive health data category. Mitigating: single data subject affected, negligent violation, no previous infringements, good cooperation, minor violation circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for diagnosis and treatment purposes, but the DPA found the health dossier was used for administrative purposes and clinical follow-up verification without proper legal basis, violating principles of lawfulness, transparency, and data minimization.
a75_case_summary: The Padua University Hospital was sanctioned for unauthorized access to health dossiers. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a)(c)(f), 9, 25, and 32 GDPR due to improper access by administrative staff and healthcare professionals not involved in patient treatment. The hospital failed to implement adequate security measures and alert systems, allowing access for administrative purposes and clinical follow-up without proper legal basis.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, categories of data affected, and manner infringement became known. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority. The fine was deemed effective, proportionate, and dissuasive.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a) for biometric processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship and determined no valid legal basis existed for biometric processing under current Italian law.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Cappello Giovanni & Figli s.r.l. violated GDPR by using facial recognition for employee attendance tracking without valid legal basis. The company also failed to provide adequate information about Infinity DMS software processing employee work activity data. DPA ordered €120,000 fine, prohibited biometric processing, and required compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating (ongoing violation), intentional/negligent character as aggravating, cooperation with authority as aggravating (poor collaboration), and categories of data as aggravating (biometric data). Economic conditions of offender were considered in sanction determination.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Rhodense Territorial Social and Health Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the request was improperly sent to a general institutional email rather than designated channels, but the DPA found that institutional email addresses constitute valid channels requiring reasonable efforts to redirect requests to competent offices.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access, Version 2.0; Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR Version 2.1
a75_case_summary: A healthcare company failed to respond to a data rectification request for 156 days and maintained inaccurate address data. The DPA rejected the company's defense that the request was improperly sent to a general institutional email, finding this constituted a valid channel requiring redirection. Violations of Articles 5(1)(d) and 12/16 were found, with a €4,500 fine imposed considering mitigating factors including cooperation and isolated nature.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating: None specifically mentioned. Mitigating: Isolated case without fraud, high cooperation, complaint-based discovery, and high volume of requests handled. Neutral: Not applicable. The overall assessment led to a reduced fine amount.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 9(2)(g),(h),(i) GDPR combined with national provisions for significant public interest. The DPA found no legal basis existed for communicating health data to unauthorized third parties.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A healthcare employee mistakenly sent an email with therapeutic plan information to 44 patients using CC instead of BCC, revealing health data. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 9 GDPR due to unauthorized disclosure of health data without legal basis. The fine was reduced due to prompt breach notification, remedial measures, and negligent rather than intentional nature.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of health data and number of affected individuals. Mitigating factors included prompt breach notification, cooperation, remedial measures, and negligent character. The previous violation was considered neutral as it concerned different matters.

a2_authority_name: The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior (Livorno Police Headquarters)
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public safety purposes under Article 6(1)(e), but the DPA found no legal basis authorizing the specific communication of employee data to the employer, rejecting both public safety and manifestly made public defenses.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Ministry of Interior violated GDPR by communicating an employee's firearms license information to his employer (Ministry of Infrastructure). The Police Headquarters claimed public safety justification and that the data was manifestly public, but the DPA found no legal basis for this specific communication between public administrations. The violation was deemed minor due to limited scope, negligent nature, and good cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The violation was mitigating due to: limited scope (single data subject), negligent nature, no specific harm to data subject, good cooperation with authority, no previous violations, and concerning only a specific internal structure rather than overall organization.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Ministry claimed processing was necessary for workplace safety and public safety, but the DPA found no legal basis existed under Italian law for communicating health data to third parties or acquiring weapon license information unrelated to employment assessment.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Ministry of Infrastructure violated GDPR by communicating an employee's health data and mobbing lawsuit details to police/prefecture without legal basis, and by acquiring information about the employee's weapon license. The Ministry claimed workplace safety concerns, but the DPA found no Italian law authorized such processing. The violation was deemed minor due to good faith, limited scope, and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included special category data involved. Mitigating factors included nature/gravity (single data subject), intentionality (negligent/good faith), cooperation, no previous violations, and specific internal articulation. Damage mitigation and technical measures were neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Azienda Unità Sanitaria Locale della Romagna
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under public task basis for employment benefit verification. The DPA found the legal basis valid but held the processing violated minimization and security principles by disclosing excessive health data including HIV status.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the notification of personal data violations;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Romagna Local Health Authority transmitted a complete medical report including HIV status to a prison administration during employment benefit verification. The DPA found violations of data minimization and security principles under Articles 5(1)(c), 5(1)(f) and 32. Despite COVID-19 staffing challenges, the error was deemed negligent. A €24,000 fine was imposed considering the sensitive nature of HIV data and previous violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature of sensitive HIV data, previous violations, and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included: cooperation through breach notification, remedial actions taken, and the specific pandemic context. The non-intentional nature was considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed legal basis under Article 19 of Legislative Decree 33/2013 and Article 15 of Presidential Decree 487/1994 for transparency purposes. DPA found these provisions only authorize publication of final competition rankings, not intermediate test results, making the publication unlawful under Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 of GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor in the GDPR;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Municipality of Nepi published pre-selection test ranking containing names and scores of 211 candidates online from 2015-2022 without proper legal basis. Also failed to regulate relationship with website management company Grafiche E. Gaspari S.r.l. until November 2022. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 28 GDPR for unlawful data dissemination and inadequate processor agreements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation and inadequate technical measures. Mitigating factors included good faith, cooperation, no previous violations, small municipality size, and no special category data involved.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed data was already public but the DPA found no legal basis existed for the communication of personal data by a public entity, which requires specific legal authorization under Italian law.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Municipality of Torri del Benaco violated GDPR by communicating personal data about a parliament member's traffic fines to journalists. The Mayor disclosed exact numbers of sanctions, points deducted, and speeds while defending municipal actions. The DPA determined this communication lacked legal basis and violated principles of lawfulness, fairness, transparency, and data minimization.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors, finding multiple mitigating circumstances: the violation involved only one data subject who contributed to data dissemination, the communication occurred in good faith to defend municipal choices, full cooperation with authorities, no previous violations, and the case qualified as a minor violation.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for organizational purposes related to teaching function during COVID-19, but DPA found no suitable legal basis for communication of health data, violating Articles 6 and 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) No. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: A teacher at State High School Duca degli Abruzzi disclosed a student's COVID-19 positive status to classmates' parents via email. The DPA found this constituted unlawful communication of health data without proper legal basis. The school was warned but no fine imposed due to mitigating factors including COVID-19 context, cooperation, and isolated nature of incident.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors, finding multiple mitigating circumstances: small entity size, isolated case, cooperation with authority, no previous violations, COVID-19 context, and remedial actions taken. The health data nature was aggravating, but overall qualified as minor violation.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under its privacy policy for fraud prevention, but the DPA found it unlawful because the company accessed SCIPAFI data through its bank without proper authorization from the Ministry of Economy and Finance.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Drivalia Leasys Rent unlawfully processed customer data by accessing SCIPAFI System through its bank without proper authorization. The company used income verification data from a government anti-fraud system to deny car rentals. Violations included inadequate transparency information and improper controller-processor relationship with the bank.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity and intentional/negligent character as aggravating factors. Cooperation, remedial actions, technical measures improvements, absence of previous infringements, and other factors were considered mitigating. The fine was reduced based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the request was too generic and raised concerns about protecting company secrets. The DPA found these arguments unjustified, noting that Article 15(4) restrictions should not lead to complete refusal and that appropriate measures should balance conflicting rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the right of access
a75_case_summary: TS Food Processing failed to respond to an employee's Article 15 access request for nearly two years, initially refusing due to company secret concerns and later claiming the request was too generic. The Italian DPA found these justifications invalid, noting the controller should have balanced rights rather than denying access entirely. The company only complied after DPA intervention, resulting in a €10,000 fine for violating Articles 12(3) and 15.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to the rights violation and two-year delay. The negligent/intentional nature was aggravating as compliance only came after reminders. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as the company eventually complied. Other factors were not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Municipality claimed transparency purposes under public task legal basis, but DPA found no suitable regulatory basis existed for publishing intermediate competition documents containing personal data beyond final rankings.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Municipality published competition minutes containing personal data online without legal basis. Failed to respond timely to erasure request. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, 12 GDPR and Italian Code provisions. Imposed €4,000 fine considering mitigating factors including small size, COVID-19 context, and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: long duration of publication. Mitigating: no previous violations, good cooperation, small municipality size, COVID-19 organizational difficulties, no special category data, negligent not intentional conduct.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed public task legal basis but DPA found Local Police lacked general competence for crime mapping via app without request from competent authorities, violating Articles 5(1)(a) and 6.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor under the GDPR;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined Municipality of Treviso €7,000 for GDPR violations related to "TrevisoSicura" app processing citizen crime reports. Violations included unlawful processing basis, inadequate information notice, no data processing agreement, and failure to implement privacy by design/default. Drone usage allegations were archived as unproven.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Art 83(2) factors: duration and inadequate measures were aggravating; negligent character, cooperation, mitigation actions, and no prior violations were mitigating; data categories were neutral. Fine set at €7,000 considering medium severity and mitigating factors.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was justified under journalistic purposes and public interest balancing under Article 17(3)(a) GDPR, but the DPA found violations of data protection principles regarding minors' data.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned Nomodidattica S.r.l. for publishing a court ruling containing minors' personal data on its journalistic website. The DPA found violations of data minimization and lawfulness principles under Article 5(1)(a) and (c) GDPR, as well as national provisions protecting minors' data. The company claimed journalistic purpose but failed to anonymize minors' identities. A €10,000 fine was imposed with consideration of aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: seriousness of violation involving minors' sensitive data. Mitigating: measures to eliminate consequences, full cooperation, no previous infringements, and organizational/economic conditions. Neutral: not specified.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for judicial protection purposes, but the DPA found the processing unlawful as it was not limited to actual disputes or pre-litigation situations but involved systematic storage and monitoring.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for electronic mail and internet;Guideline document. Computer programs and services for managing email in the workplace and processing of metadata
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Selectra S.p.A. violated GDPR by systematically backing up employee emails for 3 years post-termination and using MailStore software for monitoring purposes. The company claimed security purposes but DPA found disproportionate retention and unlawful worker monitoring. Violations included inadequate information provision, unfair processing, lack of minimization, and excessive storage.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Nature/gravity was aggravating due to multiple violations affecting many employees. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating. Cooperation and absence of precedents were mitigating. Technical measures were aggravating due to non-compliance.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found INPS violated GDPR principles despite emergency context; controller claimed emergency justified measures but DPA rejected this defense
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the notification of personal data breaches pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data protection by design and by default;Guidelines 01/2021 on examples concerning the notification of a personal data breach
a75_case_summary: INPS experienced three data breaches during COVID-19 emergency benefit distribution. Breaches involved caching misconfigurations exposing personal data and authorization system flaws allowing unauthorized access. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles despite emergency context, issuing a warning rather than fine due to exceptional circumstances.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Emergency context, prompt remedial actions, cooperation with authority, and no previous infringements were mitigating factors. Inadequate security measures were aggravating. Data categories were neutral as non-sensitive data was involved.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of security principles and breach notification requirements without discussing specific legal bases for processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 9/2022 on personal data breach notification under GDPR;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Postel S.p.A. suffered a ransomware attack resulting in data breach affecting 25,000 individuals. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 25, 32, and 33 GDPR due to inadequate security measures and incomplete breach notification. The company failed to patch known Microsoft Exchange vulnerabilities for nearly 12 months despite public warnings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation, negligent character, inadequate security measures, and sensitive data categories. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage. The manner of discovery was neutral.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Order of Nursing Professions of Udine
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Article 6(1)(f) for processing complainant's data; DPA found this invalid as public authorities cannot rely on legitimate interest basis for processing performed in their official capacity; processing lacked any valid legal basis under Article 6.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor under the GDPR;WP260 rev.01 Transparency Guidelines under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR;Guidelines concerning the data protection impact assessment and the criteria for establishing whether a processing "is likely to present a high risk" pursuant to Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Order of Nursing Professions violated GDPR by processing complainant's employment data through internet searches and communicating it to his military command and other nursing orders. The processing lacked legal basis as public authorities cannot rely on legitimate interest. Violations included unlawful data processing, failure to provide information, and delayed response to access request. The DPA imposed €8,000 fine considering the small size of the public body and cooperation during investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to workplace repercussions; intentional character was aggravating as Order exceeded institutional competences; cooperation was mitigating; no previous violations was mitigating; data categories were neutral as no special categories; small organization size was mitigating. The violation was assessed as medium severity.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for property protection, but the DPA found the processing extended to areas pertaining to third parties without adequate legal basis, violating Articles 5(1)(a) and 6.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found individual violated GDPR by installing CCTV cameras that recorded areas pertaining to neighbors' homes. The controller claimed property protection via legitimate interest, but DPA determined processing extended beyond personal/domestic exclusion and lacked legal basis. DPA ordered camera angle limitation and imposed €400 fine for Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered two Article 83(2) factors: the conduct of extending surveillance to third-party areas was aggravating, and the failure to modify camera angles despite findings was also aggravating. No mitigating factors were discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior - Prefecture of Rome
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(e) for public task performance. The DPA did not dispute the legal basis but found violations in response procedures.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Ministry of Interior violated Article 12 by failing to respond timely to a data subject's erasure request. The Ministry claimed the request was unfounded due to legal obligations but delayed response until after DPA intervention. The DPA issued a reprimand considering mitigating factors including first violation, organizational challenges, and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating factors included: limited impact (one data subject), first violation, critical organizational context with staff shortages, full cooperation with authority, awareness-raising measures taken, and no previous infringements. The violation was considered minor.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found CI & DI Food s.r.l. violated Articles 12 and 15 GDPR by failing to respond to an employee's data access request for over 13 months. The company claimed the failure was due to human error during summer holidays when only the legal representative could access certified emails. The DPA rejected these defenses, noting the obligation to implement organizational measures to facilitate rights exercise, and imposed a €4,000 fine while acknowledging the company's cooperation and remedial measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of violation (data subject rights), seriousness, and extended duration (over one year). Mitigating factors included company's negligent conduct, cooperation with authority, measures taken to facilitate rights exercise, and that violation concerned only one complainant. The company's economic conditions were also considered.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for employment relationship management, but the DPA found no appropriate legal basis existed for communicating health data to unauthorized personnel, violating Articles 5, 6 and 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data of workers for the purposes of managing the employment relationship in the public sector;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Municipality of Verona communicated an employee's health data by including unauthorized personnel on an email discussing the employee's pathologies and Law 104 status. The DPA found violations of Articles 5, 6 and 9 for unlawful communication of special category data without appropriate legal basis. The fine was reduced due to mitigating factors including cooperation, no prior violations, and COVID-19 context.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity was neutral (single data subject), intent was mitigating (negligent/isolated error), mitigation actions were mitigating (DPO awareness training), cooperation was mitigating (good cooperation), prior infringements were mitigating (no previous violations), and other factors were mitigating (COVID-19 organizational difficulties). Data categories were aggravating (health data).

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal bases under Art 6(1)(b) contract, (c) legal obligation, and (f) legitimate interest. DPA found these bases valid for the processing activities but noted a data breach occurred due to human error in data entry.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 9/2022 on personal data breach notification under GDPR;Guidelines 01/2021 on examples regarding the notification of a personal data breach;Guidelines 02/2022 on the application of article 60 of the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Avis Budget Italia erroneously associated Norwegian customers' data with wrong license plate due to human error in data entry, leading to incorrect traffic violation notifications. The DPA found this constituted a data breach but determined it was an occasional human error, not systemic. Controller took proactive corrective actions and updated security measures, leading to case closure without sanctions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Art 83(2) factors extensively. Found human error nature, proactive corrective actions, low risk to data subjects, and absence of special categories data as mitigating. No aggravating factors identified. Concluded violation warranted no corrective measures.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA sanctioned Dr. Roy De Vita, a plastic surgeon, for failing to respond to a data subject's access request and multiple DPA information requests. The violation concerned Article 157 of the Italian Data Protection Code (failure to provide information to supervisory authority). The DPA imposed a €4,000 fine and ordered publication of the decision, finding the violation intentional and serious due to repeated non-cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to continued violation. Intentional character was aggravating as omission was voluntary. No previous infringements was mitigating. Lack of cooperation was aggravating as it hindered administrative efficiency. Other factors were not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unlawful due to lack of proper signage (violating transparency principle) and failure to obtain required authorization for employee monitoring under Italian labor law, making the processing non-compliant with sector regulations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines no. 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Mark s.r.l.s. violated GDPR by operating CCTV without proper signage and without required labor authorization for employee monitoring. The bar had 10 cameras (5 inside/5 outside) with no informational signs. The DPA imposed €5,000 fine and ordered compliance with signage requirements, considering the violation non-minor but noting no previous infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, absence of precedents as mitigating, and economic conditions as mitigating. Other factors were not discussed in detail. The sanction was deemed effective, proportionate and dissuasive.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not claim a specific legal basis for the processing; the DPA focused on breach notification obligations rather than legal basis validity.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 9/2022 on the notification of personal data breaches under the GDPR;Guidelines 01/2021 on examples of notification of a personal data breach;Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA ordered Intesa Sanpaolo to communicate a data breach to affected customers after an employee accessed thousands of customer accounts without authorization. The bank had initially notified only 9 affected parties but press reports revealed 3,572 customers were accessed, including politicians and public figures. The DPA found the breach presented high risk due to sensitive financial data and ordered individual communication to all affected customers within 20 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature of breach (unauthorized access to financial data) and categories of data affected (sensitive financial information) as aggravating factors. Other factors were not systematically addressed in this interim order focused on breach communication obligations.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued warning to T.A. Format S.r.l., publisher of Telerama News, for failing to provide privacy information on website. Company claimed technical issues during site restructuring caused temporary omissions. DPA found violation of transparency obligations despite company's mitigation efforts. No fine imposed due to immediate remediation and no prior violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered several mitigating factors: company immediately took action to resolve problems, published required information, and had no previous violations. These factors led to proportionate application of warning measure rather than financial penalty. Article 83(2) factors were discussed but not systematically enumerated.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no processing occurred, but the DPA found the individual acted as controller by commissioning promotional calls through a third party without proper legal basis, consent, or Register of Oppositions verification.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found individual telecom agent violated GDPR by commissioning promotional calls through Tunisian call center without proper legal basis, consent, or Register of Oppositions verification. The controller failed to provide adequate responses to data subject rights requests and transparency obligations. The DPA issued warnings and compliance orders but no fine due to the minor nature of the single violation and defendant's personal business status.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors, finding the violation minor due to single contact, low invasiveness, and defendant's personal business nature as mitigating factors. No aggravating factors were mentioned. The case was classified as a minor violation under Article 83(2) and recital 148.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed legal basis under Italian transparency laws but DPA found these laws only permit publication of final rankings, not intermediate test results; DPA determined publication lacked appropriate legal basis under GDPR
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor in the GDPR; Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Municipality published pre-selection test ranking containing names and scores of 211 candidates from 2015-2022 without proper legal basis; also failed to regulate relationship with website management company under Article 28; DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 28 GDPR; imposed €20,000 fine considering aggravating and mitigating factors
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration and technical measures; mitigating factors included intentional/negligent character, actions to mitigate, no previous infringements, cooperation, and other factors including municipality size

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed right to publish photo based on joint custody. DPA found consent invalid as both parents' consent required for publishing minors' images on social media. Publication occurred without mother's authorization.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found individual violated GDPR by publishing minor's photo on Facebook without both parents' consent. Controller claimed joint custody rights but DPA ruled consent of both parents required for social media publication of minors' images. DPA issued prohibition order against further processing and formal reprimand.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered processing of child's data as aggravating factor and defendant's first-time offender status as mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis conducted.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: GEDI claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for journalistic purposes. The DPA found this insufficient for processing special category data and for communicating data to OpenAI for AI training purposes, stating legitimate interest cannot legitimize special category data processing under Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 1/2024 on the processing of personal data based on Article 6, paragraph 1, letter f, of the Regulation
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued warning to GEDI Group regarding planned data sharing with OpenAI. The DPA found insufficient legal basis for sharing special category data and inadequate transparency measures. The processing involves large-scale transfer of journalistic content including personal data for AI training purposes.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Territorial Health Authority of Ascoli Piceno
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not claim a specific legal basis; the DPA found violations of data minimization and confidentiality principles in health data processing for administrative certificates without assessing legal bases.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25, Data Protection by Design and by Default;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guideline document on the designation, position and tasks of the Data Protection Officer (DPO) in the public sector
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found a public health authority violated GDPR by including health department details in absence certificates for employers, breaching minimization and confidentiality principles. The authority failed to respond to information requests and had organizational issues post-restructuring. A €17,000 fine was imposed considering health data sensitivity, negligent violation, and remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of violation, data categories affected, and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factors included negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, and complaint disclosure. Other mitigating factors included organizational difficulties and first-time violation.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found no valid consent obtained for marketing calls; processing lacked appropriate legal basis; DPA invalidated consent-based processing under Article 6(1)(a)
a75_case_summary: Real estate company made unwanted marketing call without consent; failed to respond adequately to data subject rights request; stored personal data on insecure paper media; lacked proper security measures and accountability; fined €5,000 for multiple GDPR violations including Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2), 6, 7, 12, 15, and 32
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating: negligent conduct, seriousness/duration, failure to mitigate damage, low cooperation; mitigating: limited number of affected subjects, no previous violations, micro-enterprise economic capacity; neutral: categories of data affected

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Serfin 97 S.r.l. violated Article 28(3)(a),(e),(h) GDPR as data processor in debt collection activities. The company failed to track origin of debtor contact data and update the controller, using an inaccurate email address. Violation occurred from October 23 to December 1, 2021 during credit recovery operations for a securitization transaction.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating: nature/gravity of violation, technical/organizational inadequacy. Mitigating: negligent nature, cooperation with authority, measures to mitigate damage, no previous violations, other mitigating factors. Duration was short and limited number of data subjects involved.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal obligation/public task basis under regional laws; DPA found no specific law requiring publication of excluded professionals list; Consent invalid due to public authority imbalance
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions pursuant to the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Health Authority published list of excluded lawyers with reasons on website; DPA found no legal basis for dissemination under Article 2-ter Code; Violated Articles 5,6,17; €8000 fine imposed; Authority removed list after investigation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/duration affected 20 people, previous violations; Mitigating: acted in mistaken belief, good cooperation, COVID-19 difficulties; Neutral: no special categories data

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: OpenAI claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) as legal basis for processing personal data for algorithm training purposes. The DPA found this invalid because the company could not demonstrate proper assessment before processing began and failed to consider data subjects' reasonable expectations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines WP 253 regarding the application and provision of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found OpenAI violated GDPR regarding ChatGPT service. Violations included inadequate transparency information, invalid legal basis (legitimate interest) for training data processing, insufficient age verification measures, data breach notification issues, and failure to comply with DPA orders. The DPA imposed €15 million fine and required institutional communication campaign.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of violations, intentional/negligent character, inadequate technical measures, involvement of special category data, and competitive advantage gained. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority. The violations were considered serious given innovative technology and large scale of processing.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent mechanism did not allow free, specific and granular expression, thus invalidating Article 6(1)(a) basis for cookie processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on cookies and other tracking tools of 10 June 2021
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found AOSOM ITALY S.r.l. violated cookie consent requirements by lacking granular consent mechanism and providing inadequate transparency information. The company updated its cookie banner and deleted previously acquired data post-investigation. DPA issued a warning but no fine due to remediation efforts and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered technical measures deficient (aggravating) but cooperation and remedial actions mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted beyond these factors.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller failed to provide adequate cookie information and obtain valid consent. The DPA found violations of consent requirements under Article 7 due to insufficient information preventing free, informed, and specific consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on cookies and other tracking tools of 10 June 2021
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found cookie violations on e-commerce website. The banner lacked proper information and consent mechanisms for non-technical cookies. The controller partially remedied violations by adding a preferences button. DPA issued warning and compliance order but no fine due to remedial efforts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the controller's partial remediation efforts as mitigating factors. Technical and organizational measures deficiency was aggravating. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union judgment on Google Spain and Inc v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González;C-131/12;Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria of the Right to be Forgotten in the search engines cases under the GDPR (art. 17)
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA ordered Google LLC to remove specific URLs from search results associated with complainant's name under right to be forgotten provisions. The URLs contained outdated or incomplete information about a legal case where complainant was acquitted, violating accuracy principle. DPA found Google's refusal unjustified for certain URLs as they contained inaccurate or misleading information about the case outcome.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed proper security measures were in place, but the DPA found inadequate technical measures failed to prevent unauthorized access through URL manipulation, violating Article 32 security requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Engineering Ingegneria Informatica S.p.A. was found to violate Article 32 GDPR by failing to implement adequate security measures for Molise Region's Electronic Health Record system. A vulnerability allowed authenticated users to access other patients' health data through URL manipulation. The DPA imposed a €10,000 fine considering the sensitive health data involved but noted the company's cooperation and immediate remediation efforts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of health data and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included company cooperation, immediate remediation, and no previous violations. The violation severity was assessed as low.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent forms were signed but the DPA found the processing unlawful as it was carried out outside treatment purposes and violated Articles 5 and 9 of the GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative acts and documents, carried out for advertising and transparency purposes on the web by public bodies and other obliged entities
a75_case_summary: Dr. Rubino disseminated photographs of a patient on Instagram showing before/after aesthetic medicine procedures, revealing health data. The DPA found violations of Articles 5 and 9 GDPR for processing health data outside treatment purposes. A €20,000 fine was imposed considering the sensitive nature of health data and dissemination operation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the category of personal data (health data) as aggravating and the manner of discovery (complaint) as neutral. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed in detail.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations related to legal bases for employee monitoring under Italian employment law (Article 4 of Law 300/1970) rather than assessing GDPR Article 6 legal bases directly.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Ambiente 2000 S.r.l. violated GDPR by failing to properly respond to an employee's data erasure request and maintaining internal regulations permitting systematic employee monitoring through log file collection. The company failed to provide written response within one month as required by Article 12, and its monitoring provisions violated data minimization and Italian employment law requirements for remote monitoring.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to violations of general principles and data subject rights. Intentional/negligent character was mitigating as conduct was negligent. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating due to cooperation and initiating policy review. Technical measures were aggravating due to non-compliant internal regulations. Cooperation was mitigating. Categories of data were aggravating as employee data was involved. Other factors were mitigating considering case peculiarities.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for marketing activities, but the DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate verification measures for online forms and incorrect recording of consent preferences in company systems.
a75_case_summary: E.ON Energia processed personal data for telemarketing without adequate legal basis verification. The DPA found violations in digital campaign data collection through online forms without proper source verification, and in consent management where preferences were incorrectly recorded. The company failed to demonstrate adequate accountability measures despite having some compliance structures in place.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the seriousness of violations as aggravating, particularly regarding telemarketing practices. Cooperation with the authority and efforts to improve compliance were considered mitigating. The sanction was set at 1% of maximum possible fine based on these factors.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e) for traffic law enforcement. DPA found legal basis valid but violations occurred in transparency obligations and impact assessment requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Municipality of Portici used traffic light violation detection system without providing first/second level information to data subjects and without conducting DPIA. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a),12,13,35 GDPR. Municipality claimed good faith belief obligations didn't apply but took corrective measures during investigation. Fine reduced due to cooperation and prompt remediation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating but negligence as mitigating. No previous violations and cooperation were mitigating factors. Processing of non-sensitive data was mitigating. Overall violation considered medium severity.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed transparency obligations as legal basis;DPA found no specific legal basis existed for dissemination of employee data;Publication violated data protection principles despite transparency claims
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data protection officers;Guidelines on the application and provision of administrative pecuniary sanctions for the purposes of Regulation (EU) no. 2016/679;Guidelines on the processing of personal data of workers for purposes of managing the employment relationship in the public sector;Guidelines on the processing of personal data, including those contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for purposes of advertising and transparency on the web by public bodies and other obliged entities;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR;Guideline document on the designation, position and tasks of the Data Protection Officer (RPD) in the public sector
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Municipality of Corte Franca violated GDPR by publishing employee resignation resolution online containing personal data;DPA determined publication lacked legal basis despite transparency claims and violated Articles 5,6;Separate violation for delayed DPO contact details communication resulted in warning;€6000 fine imposed for data dissemination violation with publication order
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors;Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of violation, inadequate technical measures;Mitigating: negligent not intentional conduct, no previous violations, good cooperation, small municipality size;Neutral: no special category data involved

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the communication was for organizational work purposes, but the DPA found no suitable legal basis for transmitting health data to multiple recipients including external parties, violating Article 9 requirements for special category data processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A healthcare professional at Alto Adige Health Authority emailed patient health data to 15 recipients including external parties while disputing work hours. The DPA found violations of data minimization, integrity/confidentiality principles, Article 9 special categories requirements, and Article 32 security obligations. The €5,000 fine reflects aggravating factors (sensitive data, previous violations) and mitigating factors (cooperation, training initiatives, no complaints).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity of violation, technical/organizational measures, previous infringements, categories of data. Mitigating: intentional/negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, manner infringement became known. The non-intentional nature and cooperation were mitigating while sensitive data and previous violations were aggravating.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest basis for marketing communications; DPA found this invalid as Italian law requires consent for electronic marketing communications; Only consent is valid legal basis under Article 130 of Italian Privacy Code.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Start To Fly violated GDPR by sending unwanted marketing emails/SMS without valid consent despite repeated unsubscribe requests. Company claimed legitimate interest basis but DPA ruled Italian law requires explicit consent for electronic marketing. DPA also found violation of right to erasure as data wasn't properly deleted despite requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: duration/gravity of violation, negligent character, insufficient measures taken, degree of responsibility, poor cooperation. Mitigating: only one data subject affected, no previous violations, only common data involved. Neutral: none specifically mentioned.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis existed as activations were fraudulent. The DPA found processing occurred without any legal basis, violating Article 6, as data was used without the data subject's knowledge or consent for unauthorized telephone service contracts.
a75_case_summary: Sintesi Evolution, a Vodafone dealer, fraudulently activated five telephone service contracts using a data subject's personal data without her knowledge or consent. The DPA found the company acted as independent data controller and violated Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 13 by processing without legal basis and failing to provide required information. The sanction was set at €20,000 considering the serious nature of fraudulent activations but limited impact to one data subject.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: seriousness of violations (aggravating), number of data subjects affected (mitigating), negligent nature of conduct (aggravating), categories of data processed (aggravating), and no previous violations (mitigating). The sanction was determined based on effectiveness, proportionality, and dissuasiveness principles.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(e) public task under national law. The DPA found the legal basis invalid because the processing violated accuracy principles and lacked proper verification measures, making the processing unlawful despite the claimed public task basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Revenue Agency violated GDPR by improperly communicating a taxpayer's debt information to third parties. The Agency failed to verify the validity of a rental agreement and current property ownership before initiating seizure procedures. The DPA determined inadequate organizational measures led to inaccurate data processing. A €40,000 fine was imposed along with corrective orders to improve verification procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity of violation and sensitive data categories. Mitigating factors included negligent character, cooperation with authority, mitigation actions, and no previous infringements. The violation was assessed as medium severity.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract as legal basis. The DPA did not invalidate this legal basis but found violations related to transparency and information obligations under Article 14 for data not obtained directly from data subjects.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (DPOs);Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found multiple GDPR violations by a credit rehabilitation company. The company failed to provide proper information to data subjects under Article 14, violated storage limitation principles by retaining data indefinitely, improperly appointed its legal representative as DPO creating a conflict of interest, and failed to properly regulate relationships with data processors. The DPA imposed a €70,000 fine and corrective measures including data deletion and proper processor contracts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violations, negligent character, poor cooperation with authority, categories of data affected, and manner infringement became known. The absence of specific precedents was considered mitigating. Economic conditions based on turnover were also considered relevant.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for continued processing of employee email account, but the DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationships and lack of evidence of freely given consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 1/2022 on the rights of data subjects - Right of access;Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Sicurnet Liguria failed to respond to a former employee's data subject rights requests regarding his company email account. The company kept the account active after employment termination, forwarding emails to another monitored address without proper legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a,b,c,e), 12, 13, 15, and 17 GDPR for failure to respond to rights requests, lack of transparency, and improper processing of employee data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional/negligent character as aggravating, technical measures as aggravating, and categories of data affected as aggravating. The violation was deemed medium severity considering all relevant factors including nature, scope, number of data subjects affected, and level of damage.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6 but the DPA found violations of Article 5 principles due to excessive monitoring and failure to comply with authorization requirements from the labor inspectorate.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found transport company violated GDPR by using geolocation system for employee monitoring without proper information and exceeding minimization principles. System collected continuous location data including breaks, retained for 180 days, and failed to comply with labor inspectorate authorization requirements. Fine of €50,000 imposed for violations of Articles 5(1)(a,c,e), 13, 88, and national provisions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional/negligent character as aggravating, and absence of previous violations as mitigating. Other factors were not discussed systematically.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Hospital – University Città della Salute e della Scienza of Turin
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on sector-specific COVID legislation; the DPA found the communication of health data to unauthorized colleagues violated Articles 5, 6 and 9 as it exceeded the permitted scope of processing under the legal framework.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data of workers for purposes of managing the employment relationship in the public sector; Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative pecuniary sanctions under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Hospital sent email containing vaccination status and suspension information of two employees to shared DPO mailbox, making them mutually aware of each other's sensitive data. DPA found this violated Articles 5, 6 and 9 as communication exceeded permitted scope under COVID legislation. Fine reduced due to isolated incident, emergency context, and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity involving health data, previous violations. Mitigating: unintentional error, cooperation, remedial measures, emergency context. Neutral: not specified.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (DPOs);Guideline Document on the designation, position and tasks of the Data Protection Officer (DPO) in the public sector
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Municipality of Palma di Montechiaro violated Article 37(1) and (7) by failing to designate a DPO and communicate/publish contact details. The violation was discovered during ex officio checks. Municipality remedied violations after procedure initiation.
