DPA imposed €3,000 fine considering the mandatory nature of DPO designation for public authorities and the municipality's remedial actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered failure to designate DPO as aggravating factor. Municipality's remedial actions were mitigating. Lack of previous violations was mitigating. Fine was deemed effective, proportionate and dissuasive.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent was valid through cookie banners, but the DPA found consent invalid due to generic information in banners and broken policy links that prevented informed consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on cookies and other tracking tools of 10 June 2021
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found cookie consent mechanism violations on XX S.r.l.'s website including generic banner information and broken policy links. The company remedied violations during proceedings. DPA issued warning but no fine due to remediation efforts and specific investigation nature.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered remediation efforts as mitigating factor, leading to warning instead of fine. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion occurred beyond noting specific investigation nature and remediation efforts.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the processing did not constitute automated individual decisions under Article 22. The DPA found automated decisions likely occur for patients not selected for healthcare professional review, requiring compliance with Article 22(2) and (4) conditions.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA assessed a healthcare predictive tool called Health Benefit Assessment. The DPA found automated individual decisions under Article 22 likely occur for patients not selected for healthcare professional review based on profiling results. A warning was issued as the controller failed to recognize these automated decisions and comply with Article 22 requirements.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found a photography registrar violated data minimization principles by including children's thumbnail images on invoices sent to collection agencies. The controller claimed images ensured correct delivery matching, but DPA found this unnecessary as purpose could be achieved by other means. Decision orders controller to bring processing into compliance with GDPR Articles 5(1)(c) and 25(2).

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Healthcare controller charged fees for MRI images when patients didn't specifically invoke Article 15 GDPR. DPA found controller complied when Article 15 was invoked but violated Article 12(2) by not facilitating data subject rights. Controller ordered to bring processing into compliance and issued reprimand for failing to inform patients of free access rights.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Debt collection company Alektum Oy failed to respond to data subject access requests and complicated the investigation by avoiding the supervisory authority. The company showed disregard for data protection legislation and was unfamiliar with its requirements. The penalty was imposed for violations of right of access and cooperation obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the company's disregard for legislation and unwillingness to cooperate as aggravating factors. The case involved legal protection of individuals as an additional aggravating factor. Nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, and cooperation factors were discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for legal compliance and defense of legal claims regarding discrimination. The DPA found the two-year retention period justified under Article 17(3)(b) and (e) but rejected the additional six-month precautionary period as excessive.
a75_case_summary: A job applicant requested deletion of his recruitment data from a private recruitment firm. The controller refused, citing a need to retain data for two years to defend against potential discrimination claims. The DPA found the two-year retention period justified under Article 17(3)(b) and (e) GDPR but rejected the controller's additional six-month precautionary period as excessive storage. The complaint was partially rejected as the two-year period had not yet elapsed.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on consent and public interest task. The DPA found consent was not voluntary due to power imbalance and public interest basis was invalid as processing exceeded what was permitted by special law on criminal background checks for volunteers working with children.
a75_case_summary: The City of Helsinki processed criminal background data of volunteer support person applicants beyond what was permitted by the special law on criminal background checks for volunteers working with children. The DPA found the processing violated GDPR principles as consent was not voluntary and the public interest basis was invalid. The controller was ordered to bring processing into compliance and received a formal reprimand.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for public safety concerns. DPA found processing of personal identity number not permitted under national law for legitimate interest purposes, invalidating this legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union judgment Google Spain and Inc v Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González C-131/12;Guideline 5/2019 on the criteria for the Right to be Forgotten in search engines cases under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Applicant requested removal of Google search result linking to content about his 2016 child sexual abuse conviction containing his personal identity number. Google denied removal citing seriousness/recentness of crimes and public safety interest. DPA found Google's legitimate interest claim invalid under national law prohibiting personal identity number processing for legitimate interests. Ordered Google to remove the search result link under Article 58(2)(c).

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a7_defendant_name: Chief Medical Officer of the Registrar
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was justified for professional development purposes under healthcare legislation. The DPA found no legal basis in patient data legislation (Patients Act, Secondary Use Act) or GDPR for processing patient data for professional development after the care relationship ended.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA investigated healthcare provider processing patient data for professional development after care relationship ended. Found violation of purpose limitation principle as processing wasn't for patient care purposes. Ordered compliance under Article 58(2)(d) but no fine due to public authority status. Controller relied on outdated 2011 guidance.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller had no legal basis for processing employee location data as it was unnecessary for employment purposes under national law and collected unintentionally without proper assessment.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion on the concept of personal data
a75_case_summary: The Northern Savonia Hospital District automatically enabled Windows 10 location tracking on employee laptops without legal basis or necessity assessment. The DPA found violations of data minimization principles and default data protection requirements. The controller was ordered to delete collected location data and received a reprimand. The controller had already disabled the function during the investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. The controller's actions to mitigate damage (disabling function) were mitigating, while inadequate technical measures were aggravating. Other factors were not discussed in detail.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on consent under Article 6(1)(a). The DPA found consent invalid because data subjects were not provided with relevant information to make informed decisions, particularly regarding whether companies were contractual partners and the low probability of obtaining responses to requests.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 15/2011 on the definition of consent;EDPB Guidelines on consent
a75_case_summary: Oy Suomen Henkilötieto Ab operated a service facilitating data subject access requests to companies. The DPA found consent invalid under Article 6(1)(a) because data subjects were not adequately informed that most companies weren't contractual partners and requests were unlikely to be fulfilled. The controller was ordered to bring processing into compliance and received a reprimand for constructing business around fundamental data protection rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA found the controller acted in a particularly reprehensible way by constructing business around exercising fundamental data protection rights, which was an aggravating factor. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing under Article 6(1)(b) for contract implementation and national law exception under Data Protection Act Section 6(1)(1). DPA found national exception only applies to insured persons and claimants, not insurance applicants, making processing of applicant health data unlawful under Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent according to the General Data Protection Regulation
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found insurance company violated GDPR by processing health data of insurance applicants. Controller requested complete medical records from healthcare units to assess liability. DPA determined national insurance exception only applies to insured persons/claimants, not applicants. Processing violated Article 5(1)(a) fairness and (c) minimization, and Article 25(2) data protection by design. DPA issued reprimand and compliance order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity aggravating due to sensitive health data processing. Data categories aggravating as health data carries high risks. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion; penalty assessment focused on proportionality between reprimand vs fine given legal interpretation issues.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest and legal obligation as bases for retaining data after customer relationship ended. The DPA did not explicitly assess the validity of these legal bases but found the controller failed to properly implement deletion requests and provide required information.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found a bank violated GDPR Articles 12(3-4) and 17(1)(a) by failing to properly implement a data subject's deletion requests and provide required information. The controller failed to delete data that was no longer necessary and did not properly guide the data subject through secure communication channels. The DPA issued a reprimand considering it an individual case with mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and severity of the error as mitigating, noting it was a human error with little effect on data subject rights. The controller's corrective actions and cooperation were viewed as mitigating factors. The error involved ordinary personal data affecting only one individual.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public interest task but lacked proper legal basis. The DPA found no legal basis existed under Article 6(1) for requiring data subjects to exercise inspection rights and process criminal conviction data.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found Kymsote violated GDPR by requiring foster family applicants to exercise data subject inspection rights to obtain police criminal data. The controller lacked proper legal basis under Article 6(1) and Article 10 for processing criminal conviction data. The DPA ordered termination of this procedure and compliance with proper criminal background check laws.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish Meteorological Institute used Google Analytics and reCAPTCHA services on its website, transferring personal data to the US without proper legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 44 and 46 regarding international data transfers and Article 35 regarding failure to conduct a data protection impact assessment. The controller was ordered to delete unlawfully transferred data and received a reprimand, but no fine was imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as mitigating, technical measures as aggravating, and cooperation as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA removed its August 2023 temporary ban on Yango taxi app's data transfers to Russia after receiving expert opinion that Russian taxi legislation does not apply to operations outside Russia. The DPA found that requirements for urgent measures under Article 66 GDPR were no longer met, though it noted potential for incorrect application of Russian law. The case will continue through normal Article 60 cooperation procedure with Dutch DPA as lead authority.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed transfers were based on Article 46 protective measures; the DPA found these measures insufficient given new Russian legislation granting security services broad access rights; the DPA determined transfers would violate GDPR Chapter V principles and fundamental rights protections.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued urgent temporary ban on Yango taxi app data transfers to Russia due to new legislation granting Russian security services broad access to passenger data. The DPA found Article 46 protective measures insufficient given the risk of unauthorized access. The ban takes effect September 1, 2023 and lasts three months under Article 66 urgent procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, noting the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to serious risks to fundamental rights. Other aggravating factors included the new Russian legislation creating unrestricted access. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent through browser settings and cookie banner; DPA found consent invalid as it wasn't voluntary, specific, informed, unambiguous expression of intent; withdrawal not as easy as giving consent
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines on Consent under Regulation 2016/679, WP259 rev. 01
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found controller's cookie consent mechanism non-compliant with GDPR. Consent was obtained through banner without refusal option and required browser settings changes. DPA ordered controller to modify procedures to obtain valid consent under Articles 4(11), 6(1)(a) and 7 GDPR, issuing reprimand but no fine due to unclear legal situation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered infringement aggravated as it affected multiple data subjects; mitigating factors included unclear legal situation since GDPR implementation; no systematic Article 83(2) analysis conducted

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for direct marketing in lottery participation. The DPA found consent valid and voluntary under Article 4(11) despite being conditional, noting participation was voluntary and not giving consent caused no negative consequences. The DPA also found withdrawal mechanisms compliant with Article 7(3).
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA investigated a complaint about a lottery requiring consent for direct marketing as participation condition. The DPA found the consent voluntary under Article 4(11) despite conditionality, noting lottery participation was optional and refusal caused no harm. The DPA also found withdrawal mechanisms compliant with Article 7(3) and issued no sanctions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for identification in decisions, enforcement of payments, and insurance requirements. The DPA found these justifications invalid as invoices are not decisions, enforcement doesn't require SSN on invoices, and insurance companies don't require SSN-marked invoices.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered a municipal healthcare provider to cease printing social security numbers on patient invoices. The controller claimed SSNs were necessary for identification, enforcement, and insurance purposes. The DPA rejected all arguments, finding the practice violated data minimization and security principles under GDPR and national data protection law.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Finnish Credit Information Act; DPA found no valid legal basis under GDPR Article 6 as conditions for default entry were not met; judgments in disputed cases cannot indicate solvency or willingness to pay.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered credit registry to correct erroneous default entries based on final judgments in disputed cases. Controller's case-by-case assessment of judgments violated GDPR Article 5(1)(a) lawfulness principle and failed privacy by design requirements. DPA found judgments in contested cases cannot indicate solvency/willingness to pay under Finnish Credit Information Act.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration aggravating; technical measures aggravating; data categories aggravating; legal interpretation difficulties mitigating. No administrative fine imposed due to proportionality concerns and complex legal interpretation issues.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(b) contract and Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests. The DPA found valid legal bases including Article 6(1)(c) legal obligation for healthcare record-keeping requirements.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found optician had valid legal bases under Article 6(1)(b),(c),(f) for processing customer data including healthcare record-keeping obligations. The online form for data subject rights requests complied with minimization principle. However, controller failed to properly respond to deletion request under Article 12(3)-(4) and was issued a reprimand and ordered to comply with deletion request except for patient records.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered credit registry to remove default entries from applicant's credit information. The DPA found that a bankruptcy application that was withdrawn and never became final could not serve as extension basis for maintaining default entries under Credit Information Act. The DPA also found that default entries based on unilateral judgments that were later set aside should be removed as they no longer accurately reflected the applicant's creditworthiness.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for security camera surveillance but failed to perform and document the required balancing test. The DPA found this legal basis invalid due to lack of proper assessment and documentation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidance on Impact Assessments;Guidance on the use of legitimate interest as a legal basis
a75_case_summary: Taksi Helsinki Oy violated GDPR through security camera surveillance processing audio data without justification, failing transparency requirements for both security cameras and loyalty program profiling, inadequate documentation of processing activities, and failure to conduct required data protection impact assessments. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5,6,12,26,28,30,35 and imposed corrective orders plus a €72,000 fine. The controller processed audio data in taxis without proper legal basis assessment and provided insufficient information to data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement and categories of data affected. Mitigating factors included negligence rather than intent, actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, no previous infringements, and financial impact of COVID-19 on taxi operations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed offering call listening and summaries complied with GDPR; the DPA found summaries were not valid copies under Article 15(3) as they excluded personal data and did not correspond to the original recording; the DPA emphasized that listening alone does not fulfill the right of access requirement.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found Suomen Avainsanat Oy violated GDPR by failing to provide proper copies of call recordings to data subjects, instead offering summaries that excluded personal data. The controller also failed to comply with a prior order from March 2021 requiring compliance with access rights. The DPA issued a reprimand and referred the case to the sanctions board, which imposed a €23,000 fine for violations of Articles 12(1), 15(3) and non-compliance with an Article 58(2)(d) order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional character, lack of technical measures, previous infringements, and poor cooperation. Mitigating factors included some actions to mitigate damage. The data categories affected were considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not properly implement the data subject's right of access under Article 15 and failed to provide adequate information about its role as controller. The DPA found violations of transparency obligations and data subject rights facilitation requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: A medical clinic failed to properly implement a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The DPA found systematic violations including failure to facilitate data subject rights, inadequate transparency information, and poor cooperation with the supervisory authority. The clinic processed health data but lacked proper procedures for rights implementation and information provision. A €5,000 fine was imposed due to the serious and systematic nature of the violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation, negligent character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, poor cooperation, and processing of special category health data. No mitigating factors were identified. The violation was considered serious and systematic.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller argued that vehicle maintenance history data constitutes personal data of previous owners, not the current owner, and thus Article 15 access rights do not apply. The EDPS agreed that the data does not relate to the new owner under content, purpose, or outcome factors, and therefore the applicant has no right of access under Article 15.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 4/2007 on the concept of personal data
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA ruled on whether a used car buyer has right to access vehicle maintenance history under Article 15 GDPR. The DPA found maintenance history constitutes personal data of previous owners, but does not relate to the new owner under content, purpose, or outcome factors. Therefore, the applicant had no right of access to historical maintenance data under Article 15.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no explicit legal basis but argued necessity for child protection. The DPA found no legal basis existed under Article 6(1) as national legislation (Act on investigating criminal background of those working with children) already provided a proportionate procedure that should have been used instead.
a75_case_summary: The City of Oulu required family caregiver applicants to exercise their right of access to obtain police records and present them to authorities. The DPA found this violated Articles 6(1) and 10 GDPR as it lacked legal basis and circumvented the proper criminal background check procedure under Finnish law. The controller ceased the practice after becoming aware of the issue.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A cleaning company used WhatsApp to transmit customer personal data including names, addresses, telephone numbers, door codes and alarm system codes to employees' personal phones. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 24, 25 and 32 GDPR due to inadequate security measures and failure to implement built-in data protection. The controller was issued a reprimand and ordered to bring processing into compliance.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal obligation under Article 17(3)(b) for data retention; DPA found this valid due to statutory healthcare record retention requirements; Controller was not required to delete data but failed to properly respond to deletion requests.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found optician shop violated GDPR by continuing direct marketing after data subject's objection and failing to properly respond to deletion requests. Controller claimed legal obligation to retain health data under national law, which DPA validated. DPA issued reprimand for violations of Articles 12(4), 21(2), and 25(2) but no fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: No decision text provided for analysis

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA rejected a parent's request to exercise GDPR rights on behalf of minor child regarding medical data. The parent had court-confirmed information access rights but was not the guardian. DPA determined information access rights under national law do not extend to exercising GDPR correction/deletion rights. No order issued as applicant lacked standing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A psychotherapist failed to respond to a patient's data access requests under Article 15 GDPR for nearly three years despite multiple requests and DPA guidance. The DPA found violations of Article 12(3) and (4) GDPR regarding timely response to data subject requests. The controller claimed exceptional circumstances but the DPA found intentional neglect of GDPR obligations, particularly concerning sensitive health data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation (3-year delay), intentional character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, lack of cooperation with DPA, and sensitive health data involved. Neutral factors included: no previous infringements and no financial benefit obtained.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish telecom company failed to provide easy opt-out mechanism in direct marketing messages, requiring login to online service. DPA found violation of national electronic communications law §200.3 and GDPR transparency principles. Controller ordered to bring processing into compliance by providing easy objection option in marketing messages. Guidance given on making DPO contact information more accessible on website.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for journalistic purposes only under national law exception. The DPA found the tax machine processing qualified for the journalistic exception under Section 27 of the Data Protection Act, meaning Articles 17 and 21 of GDPR do not apply.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA ruled that Sanoma Media's processing of personal data through online tax machines qualified for the journalistic exception under Section 27 of the Data Protection Act. The DPA found the publication of high-income individuals' tax information contributed to societal debate on income distribution and taxation fairness. The decision emphasized that journalistic freedom includes choosing how to present information and that ex-post remedies adequately protect privacy rights.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on consent as stated in their privacy policy. The DPA found Article 20 applies to email data as it involves data consciously provided by the subject and generated from their activities, and processing is automated.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Guidelines on the right to data portability
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found email service provider violated Article 20 by only allowing manual export of emails one-by-one for free users while charging for bulk export tools. The DPA determined this effectively hindered data portability and made full exercise of the right chargeable, violating Article 12(5). A reprimand was issued under Article 58(2)(b).

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Legal basis discussion focused on failure to comply with supervisory order rather than processing legal basis; controller failed to provide call recording to verify lawful basis; DPA did not assess validity of any specific Article 6 legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Telemarketing company failed to comply with DPA order to provide call recording to data subject under Article 15; company only complied after DPA initiated sanction proceedings; DPA imposed €8,300 fine for non-compliance with supervisory order under Article 83(6); breach considered serious due to disregard for data protection regulations and lack of cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; cooperation with authority was aggravating; compliance with prior orders was aggravating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for legal claims defense under Article 17(3)(e) for data retention. The DPA found this basis valid for 2019 subscription data but invalid for 2007 customer data that was retained beyond defined retention periods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for transparency according to Regulation 2016/679, WP260 rev.01
a75_case_summary: A data subject requested deletion of personal data from a mobile operator. The DPA found the controller had valid grounds under Article 17(3)(e) to retain 2019 subscription data for three years post-termination for billing complaint purposes. However, data from a 2007 customer relationship was improperly retained due to a technical error and should have been deleted, warranting a reprimand.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: No decision text provided for analysis

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Instructions 1/2022 on the rights of data subjects – the right to access information
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA addressed complaint regarding telecom operator's failure to provide requested data in electronic format. The DPA found jurisdiction limited regarding proxy data questions but determined Article 15(3) violation for not providing data in commonly used electronic format. Ordered controller to resubmit already provided personal data in electronic format and issued reprimand.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b);DPA found processing for customer account creation was not objectively necessary for online purchase contract;DPA stated contract basis should be interpreted narrowly and processing was typically for business benefit
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found Verkkokauppa.com violated storage limitation principle by requiring customer registration for single online purchases;Controller stored personal data indefinitely unless data subject requested deletion;DPA held this transferred data protection responsibility to data subjects and violated Articles 5(1)(e) and 25(2);Controller was ordered to define proper retention periods and fined €856,000
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors;Nature and duration of violation were aggravating (deliberate practice since 2018 affecting millions);Intentional character was aggravating (controller consciously implemented non-compliant procedure);Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (planned inactive account deletion mechanism)

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for patient identification, but the DPA found the personal identification number was unnecessarily included in text messages, violating data minimization principles.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found a welfare district violated GDPR by including personal identification numbers in automated text messages to patients about laboratory results. The controller claimed this was necessary for identification, but the DPA found the inclusion unnecessary and violating data minimization principles. The DPA issued an order to bring processing into compliance and provided guidance on securing text message communications.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for educational purposes but the DPA found personal data was used to promote third-party sports services without legal basis, violating purpose limitation and lawfulness principles.
a75_case_summary: A college teacher used the college's information system to send marketing emails promoting third-party sports courses to students. The DPA found this violated Article 5 principles as the processing was unrelated to college operations and lacked legal basis. The city as controller received a reprimand for failing to ensure proper data handling by staff.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found media company violated GDPR by requiring excessive identity verification for data access requests. Controller mandated in-person delivery of signed forms with SSN and photo ID verification as standard practice. DPA ruled this violated data minimization principle (Art 5(1)(c)) and failed to facilitate data subject rights (Art 12(2)). Controller ordered to change policy and reprocess the data subject's request.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish Tax Administration required data subject to submit signed paper form for access request and refused to deliver data to agent. DPA found violations of Article 12(2) for failing to facilitate data subject rights. Ordered compliance with GDPR and processing of original request.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but the DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 regarding security of processing health data transmitted to third-party monitoring services.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: University Pharmacy transmitted health data (medicine browsing/purchase information) to third-party monitoring services (Google, Meta, New Relic) without adequate security measures. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR. The infringement lasted approximately four years during GDPR application period and affected a large number of data subjects. The penalty was imposed due to the serious nature of processing sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, technical/organizational measures, and categories of personal data affected. Mitigating factor was that controller's revenues support education/research. Neutral factors included actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract basis for processing employees' personal phone numbers. DPA found this invalid because other employees are not parties to employment contracts. DPA stated processing was not necessary or proportionate for business purposes.
a75_case_summary: Bus operator published employees' personal phone numbers on company intranet accessible to all bus drivers. Controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract basis but DPA found this invalid as other employees are not parties to employment contracts. DPA found processing violated necessity requirement of Working Life Data Protection Act. DPA issued reprimand and compliance order.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed contract basis under Article 6(1)(b); DPA found this valid as data subject registered and participated in training; legitimate interest basis was mentioned but not assessed as contract basis was sufficient.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: Data controller required signed request forms and ID copies for all access requests, violating data minimization. Controller failed to delete customer data after defined retention periods. DPA ordered compliance with access request, policy changes for identification procedures, and deletion of overdue data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Data subject requested access to call recording and materials related to customer satisfaction survey. Controller initially provided transcription instead of electronic recording, then provided both after repeated request. Deputy DPA found controller complied with Articles 12(1) and 15(3) by assessing appropriate delivery format and providing both transcription and electronic recording. No violations found, no corrective measures issued.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA investigated Finnish Golf Association's eBirdie system security following a complaint. Found weak authentication using predictable identifiers instead of passwords, allowing unauthorized access to personal data. Issued reprimand and compliance order for violating Articles 25(1) and 32(1)(b) GDPR regarding data protection by design and security measures.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Meta IE claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract as legal basis for behavioral advertising; EDPB found this invalid as profiling was not necessary for contract performance; Controller switched from consent to contract basis when GDPR came into force
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines on calculation of fines;EDPB Guidelines on Administrative Fines;WP29 Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interests;WP29 Opinion 02/2010 on online behavioural advertising
a75_case_summary: EDPB binding decision regarding Meta IE's Facebook service;Found invalid legal basis under Article 6(1)(b) for behavioral advertising processing;Issued corrective measures including compliance order and increased fines;Case involved cross-border processing with IE SA as lead authority
a76_art83_weighing_summary: EDPB systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors;Nature/gravity and technical measures were aggravating;Intentionality and complaint discovery were neutral;Financial benefit was potentially aggravating but required further assessment

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under GDPR Article 6(1)(f) but the EDPS found this invalid as Regulation 2018/1725 applies instead, and the legal basis reference was copied from another website in error.
a75_case_summary: The EDPS found the European Parliament violated multiple articles of Regulation 2018/1725 regarding a COVID-19 testing website. Issues included inadequate controller oversight of processor Ecolog, unlawful data transfers to the US via Google Analytics and Stripe cookies, non-compliant data protection notices and cookie banners, and failure to respond to access requests. The Parliament was reprimanded and ordered to update its data protection notices.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The EDPS considered the large number of affected data subjects and impact on fundamental rights as aggravating, while the Parliament's responsiveness and remediation of most infringements were mitigating factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found multiple legal basis violations including failure to assess compatibility of further processing purposes (Art 6), failure to assess necessity/proportionality of data transfers (Art 9), and failure to ensure transfers solely for controller tasks (Art 47).
a75_case_summary: EDPS found European Commission violated EU Regulation 2018/1725 in its use of Microsoft 365. Infringements included purpose limitation failures, inadequate international transfer safeguards, and unauthorized disclosure risks. The Commission failed to provide clear instructions to Microsoft and assess third-country data protection adequacy. Corrective measures include suspension of data flows and compliance orders.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA overturned initial decision not to investigate complaint about Storybook OÜ processing personal data from commercial register to create personal profiles. DPA acknowledged ongoing supervision of information portals including Storybook but found complainant had right to individual complaint procedure. Decision orders processing of complainant's specific case.

a7_defendant_name: Center of Registers and Information Systems
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Data Protection Inspectorate dismissed a challenge regarding allegedly inaccurate criminal record data. The Inspectorate found that the criminal record entry was lawful as it was based on a valid court judgment that remained in force despite multiple appeals. The DPA concluded the data processing had legal basis under national criminal register legislation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Estonian Data Protection Inspectorate ruled on a challenge regarding access to a 2004 police directive. The Police and Border Guard Board had partially refused access, claiming some information still needed protection despite the 10-year maximum restriction period under Public Information Act §40(1). The Inspectorate found no legal basis for extending restrictions beyond 10 years and ordered full disclosure unless the information constituted a state secret.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract basis for transferring data to payment default register; DPA found legitimate interest (Article 6(1)(f)) was the correct legal basis and required proper assessment
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA investigated complaint about financial company transferring debt data to Spanish payment default register ASNEF. DPA found controller used incorrect legal basis (contract instead of legitimate interest) and violated right of access by failing to respond properly to data subject's request. Issued reprimand but terminated proceedings as data subject received information through ASNEF and debt was settled.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes under national law §4 of Personal Data Protection Act, but the DPA found that GDPR applies to processing beyond what was published and that the controller breached its obligation to respond to the data subject's access request.
a75_case_summary: Viimsi Uudised OÜ, a media company, failed to respond to a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR regarding personal data collected for a "Viimsi Brake 2020" survey. The DPA found the controller breached its obligation to respond within one month and issued a precept ordering compliance with the access request while allowing redaction of third-party information. The controller incorrectly argued that a previous court ruling prevented the DPA's supervision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for security and property protection. DPA found no valid legitimate interest analysis was prepared and filming beyond own property lacked legal basis. DPA required proper legitimate interest analysis showing necessity and balancing test.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data in video devices
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA issued injunction against company XXX for CCTV violations. Cameras filmed beyond company property into neighboring properties and public space without legal basis. DPA found breaches of Articles 5,6,12,13 and ordered cessation of filming, deletion of recordings, proper legitimate interest analysis, signage, and data protection conditions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis. The DPA found that after termination of employment, there was no legal basis for keeping the email addresses open, as the original legal basis (employment contract) no longer applied.
a75_case_summary: The Estonian DPA issued an injunction against Retent AS for failing to delete former employee email addresses after employment termination. The DPA found no legal basis for keeping the addresses open after the employment contract ended. The company failed to respond to multiple requests from both the data subject and the DPA.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found no valid consent under Article 6(1)(a) and no legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f); Disclosure of debt data without legal grounds violated GDPR principles.
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA ordered individual Facebook group administrator to cease illegal disclosure of debtors' personal data. Controller failed to demonstrate valid legal basis under Article 6(1)(a) consent or 6(1)(f) legitimate interest. DPA issued injunction to terminate processing and delete Facebook group containing unlawfully published personal data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA cited nature/gravity of infringement (illegal public disclosure) and categories of data affected as aggravating factors; failure to comply with prior proposal also considered aggravating; no systematic Article 83(2) discussion.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA annulled its prior decision to return a data subject's complaint regarding right of access to documents from a shooting association. The DPA found the return unlawful as the civil case compromise did not preclude access rights under GDPR Article 15. The matter was reopened and referred to another body for substantive examination.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and contractual basis for processing, but the DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 9 for processing special category health data. The DPA determined that displaying prescription data based solely on personal identification codes without verification of legal representation rights violated GDPR requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Estonian DPA discovered that e-pharmacies allowed anyone with ID card login to access others' prescription data by entering personal identification codes. The DPA issued an urgent injunction requiring immediate suspension of this processing due to high risk to data subjects' sensitive health information. The DPA found violations of data protection principles including lawfulness, data minimization, and security requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, noting the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data affected as aggravating, and technical/organizational measures as aggravating. The decision focused on the high risk to data subjects rather than systematic Article 83(2) analysis.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis; DPA found consent invalid in employment relationship due to subordination; DPA indicated legitimate interest could be valid basis if properly assessed
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Hotel used CCTV surveillance without valid legal basis; DPA found consent invalid in employment context; DPA ordered cessation of camera use until proper legitimate interest assessment conducted; DPA also found transparency obligations breached regarding notification signs

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: This text provides procedural information about contacting the Estonian Data Protection Inspectorate for various purposes including clarification requests, information requests, and filing complaints against the inspectorate's own actions. It outlines submission methods and timelines but does not contain any actual case decision or enforcement action.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that publishing personal data in stairwells accessible to third parties requires prior consent under Article 6(1)(a), which was not obtained. The controller claimed no legal basis and continued the practice despite warnings.
a75_case_summary: Apartment association published members' personal data (names, apartment numbers, signatures) in building stairwells accessible to third parties without consent. DPA found this violated GDPR Article 6 requirements for lawful processing. The association continued the practice despite warnings. DPA issued injunction to cease disclosure and imposed potential penalty fee for non-compliance.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPI investigated Bolt Operations OÜ regarding a data subject's right to rectification of phone number data. Bolt failed to respond to rectification requests in due time and had technical limitations preventing phone number changes. The DPI issued proposals for system changes and response improvements, which Bolt implemented after delays. The DPI found violations of GDPR articles regarding rectification rights, response timelines, and security measures.

a7_defendant_name: Police officer and health care worker
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendants claimed public task basis but DPA found no need for knowledge arising from service task, making processing unlawful
a75_case_summary: Police officer and health care worker fined for unauthorized curiosity requests in government databases. Police officer accessed future spouse's information 3 times; healthcare worker researched ambulance call data at third party's request. Both violated data protection requirements despite employer training. Fines reduced due to regret and agreement to expedited procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered regret and agreement to expedited procedure as mitigating factors. Nature of violations was aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for requesting ID verification; DPA found this valid for identity confirmation purposes but noted lack of transparency in explaining the legal basis to data subjects.
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA investigated multiple complaints against Bolt regarding data access and deletion requests. Found transparency violations under Article 5(1)(a) due to unclear communication about ID verification requirements and processing explanations. Issued reprimand but no fine, noting cooperation and eventual compliance.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed multiple legal bases including consent (Art 6(1)(a)), contract (Art 6(1)(b)), legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)), and legitimate interest (Art 6(1)(f)). The DPA did not invalidate any specific legal basis but found issues with storage limitation and transparency.
a75_case_summary: The Estonian DPA investigated  regarding consent mechanisms, data retention periods, and transparency of data transfers. The controller initially required consent for direct marketing to register an account (technical error), applied a 15-year retention period without proper justification, and provided unclear information about third-party data sharing. The DPA issued a reprimand under Article 58(2)(b) GDPR and terminated proceedings after the controller fixed the consent issue.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA received cross-border complaint via IMI system regarding failure to delete personal data. Controller violated Article 17 by not deleting data due to procedural mistakes despite confirming deletion to complainant. Controller improved processes and deleted data except AML-retained data, leading to reprimand and case closure.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted inspection of Arp-Hansen Hotel Group and found approximately 500,000 customer profiles stored beyond their own deletion deadlines, some for several years. The DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(e) storage limitation principle. A fine of DKK 1,100,000 was recommended due to extensive storage without objective reasons.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Lejre Municipality was fined for inadequate security measures after uploading sensitive meeting minutes containing personal data of minors to a staff portal accessible to many employees without work-related need. The DPA found violation of security requirements and failure to notify data subjects about the breach. The fine considered the nature of violation, sensitive data type, and municipality size.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Data Inspectorate emphasized the nature of the violation (lack of security), nature and amount of personal data affected, and municipality size as aggravating factors. The fact that the municipality self-reported the breach was considered mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: JobTeam A/S deleted personal data after receiving an access request but before responding, violating GDPR principles. The Danish Data Inspectorate reported the company to police and recommended a DKK 50,000 fine. The authority emphasized fines must be effective, dissuasive, and proportionate to the infringement.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Data Inspectorate criticized Attorney General's Board for failing to provide timely disclosure to a lawyer regarding a complaint against him. The Board received the complaint on June 14, 2018 but only notified the lawyer on November 28, 2018, exceeding the reasonable timeframe under Article 14(3)(a). The Board's justification that they wanted adequate case disclosure did not exempt them from their disclosure obligations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Two Danish municipalities fined for inadequate security measures; Unencrypted computers containing sensitive personal data were stolen; Gladsaxe Municipality had data on 20,620 citizens stolen; Hørsholm Municipality had employee data on 1,600 individuals stolen
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Data Inspectorate emphasized nature of infringement (lack of security), failure to encrypt as general measure, and municipality size in population and operating allowance; Recommended fines of DKK 100,000 and DKK 50,000 respectively

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. The DPA found this invalid because continuous CPR subscriptions were not necessary when single inquiries could suffice for identification needs in handling citizen requests.
a75_case_summary: The City of Copenhagen maintained continuous CPR subscriptions for former residents without current need. A citizen complaint revealed automatic resubscription upon inquiry. The DPA found Article 6(1)(e) invalid as single inquiries suffice for identification needs, violating data minimization principles.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid because users had to accept terms of use and privacy policy with same click, which did not constitute unambiguous expression of intent. For special categories, DPA found no valid exception under Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 regarding consent pursuant to Regulation 2016/679;The Danish Data Protection Agency's and the Ministry of Justice's guidelines on consent;The Danish Data Protection Agency's guide to consent
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted audit of Dating.dk's dating service processing. Found invalid consent basis as users had to accept terms and privacy policy with same click, violating Article 6(1)(a). Also processed special categories without valid exception under Article 9. Security measures inadequate under Article 32. Issued reprimand and compliance order.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned inspection of Varde Municipality's Article 30 record-keeping compliance. Municipality's records lacked clarity on categories of data subjects/personal data, links between them, and recipient information. DPA found accountability principle breached and ordered compliance improvements. DPA updated guidelines based on inspection findings.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA ruled Pandora's general ID validation procedure for data subject rights requests violated GDPR. Pandora required credentials without exception, failing to conduct case-by-case assessments of reasonable doubt. The DPA found this violated Article 12(6) and Article 5(1)(c) on data minimization. Orders were issued to process the deletion request and bring procedures into compliance.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed medical consultant assessments were internal documents exempt from access rights under business secrets and private interests. The DPA found these assessments constitute personal data and exceptions to access rights are very narrow, requiring concrete assessment rather than general refusal.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Article 29 Working Party Opinion No 4/2007 on the concept of personal data (WP136)
a75_case_summary: A pension company refused access to medical consultant assessments claiming they were internal documents exempt from access rights. The Danish DPA found medical assessments constitute personal data and exceptions to access rights are very narrow, requiring concrete assessment rather than general refusal. The DPA issued serious criticism and an order to conduct a concrete assessment of whether access should be granted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: TDC claimed processing based on legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) for accounting data and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for marketing profiling. DPA found legal obligation valid for accounting but storage period exceeded legal requirements. DPA found legitimate interests valid for marketing profiling until objection.
a75_case_summary: DPA addressed multiple complaints against TDC Group companies regarding data processing practices. Found TDC A/S violated Article 15 by delayed response to access request. Found Dansk Kabel TV A/S violated Article 6(1) and Article 5(1)(e) by retaining accounting data beyond legal requirements. Found no violations for Nuuday A/S's marketing profiling or disclosure practices.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA reprimanded Reto Moto ApS for failing to provide copies of direct in-game chat messages under Article 15(3). The DPA found Reto Moto was entitled to withhold other chat messages under Article 15(4) due to language/jargon complexities and anti-cheat information under Danish Data Protection Act section 22(1) due to trade secrets. The case involved a complaint about incomplete response to an access request.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing under Article 6(1)(c) and (e) and Danish Data Protection Act section 11(1). The DPA found processing was conducted on a basis other than consent, which was appropriate for the public task of recovering claims.
a75_case_summary: The Labor Market Holiday Fund failed to provide complete transparency information within required timeframes and requested invalid consent. The DPA found violations of Articles 12(1), 14, and 5(1)(a) for providing information piecemeal over months rather than in a single concise communication, and for requesting consent when processing was already based on legal obligation/public task.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found contract and legal obligation were more appropriate bases. DPA criticized using consent when other bases were clearly more suitable, as consent gives data subjects control expectation that shouldn't apply to necessary contractual/legal processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP259 rev. 01 Guidelines on Consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DPA found Rejsekort improperly used consent as legal basis for processing travel card data when contract and legal obligation bases were more appropriate. DPA issued serious criticism and ordered deletion of travel data and agreement information not required by Accounting Act. Controller must reassess processing bases for all consent-based processing and submit written statement.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. DPA found processing necessary for municipality's exercise of authority and valid under Article 6(1)(e). Reasoning emphasized search function supports compliance with general duty of guidance to citizens.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA ruled on complaint about municipality's website search function suggesting complainant's name. Municipality claimed processing under Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for providing citizen guidance. DPA found processing lawful and necessary for municipality's exercise of authority, complying with data minimization principles.

a7_defendant_name: Medical Guard Region of Southern Denmark
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(e) and Article 9(2)(h). The DPA found recording could be based on Article 6(1)(e) and Article 9(2)(h) for quality assurance and complaint handling purposes, but rejected the claim that recordings were part of patient records subject to 10-year retention.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA addressed a complaint about medical emergency service recording telephone conversations and refusing deletion. The DPA found recordings were not part of patient records and could only be kept for 5 years based on complaint handling needs. The DPA issued serious criticism for retaining recordings beyond 5 years and ordered deletion of all recordings over 5 years old.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature of health data (Art 83(2)(g)) and duration of storage (Art 83(2)(a)) as aggravating factors for the storage limitation violation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned supervision of law firm's email security practices. Found firm uses end-to-end encryption with S/MIME certificates and forced TLS 1.2 for transmitting confidential/sensitive data. Firm demonstrated adequate risk assessment and no known unencrypted transmissions since January 2019.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted audit of Krifa's email security practices. Found violations: using social security numbers as passwords for email access, and sending unencrypted emails containing trade union affiliation information without reporting breaches. Issued order to cease using social security numbers as passwords by November 26, 2019.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned audit of law firm office community focusing on email encryption security. Found violations of Article 32 security requirements and Article 5(2) accountability principle for failing to implement TLS encryption procedures and conduct proper risk assessment for transmitting confidential/sensitive personal data to clients. Office community implemented corrective procedures post-audit but received formal reprimand for prior non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered inadequate security measures as aggravating and post-audit remedial actions as mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted beyond these factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that SIF Gruppen failed to provide information about the legal basis for processing personal data in connection with GPS monitoring, which violated transparency requirements.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted written inspection of SIF Gruppen regarding employee monitoring practices. Found deficient information provision for GPS monitoring (missing legal basis, data subject rights, complaint information) and TV surveillance (lack of transparency about control purposes). Issued serious criticism and orders to comply with Articles 5(1)(a), 13 and 14.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned audit of Payment Denmark's compliance with data subject rights. Found violations of Articles 15 and 12(2) regarding access requests and automated decision information. Authority failed to provide information about automated decisions in 5 cases and missed response deadlines in 4 cases.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Data Protection Agency conducted planned audit of Odense Municipality's compliance with data subject access rights. Municipality had procedures and templates but responded late to 3 of 9 access requests. DPA issued reprimand for violating Article 12(2) response deadlines but took no further action.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) obtained through lead agencies' competitions. DPA found consent invalid due to pre-ticked boxes and lack of specificity regarding recording of calls. Consent declaration could not be extended to cover recording of telephone conversations.
a75_case_summary: Burda Nordic recorded telephone conversations during sales/marketing of magazines without valid consent. DPA found consent invalid due to pre-ticked boxes in competition terms and lack of specificity regarding call recording. DPA also found violations of information obligations under Articles 13-14. The recording was deemed unnecessary as order confirmations could serve the same documentation purpose with less intrusion.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The Conservative People's Party claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests. The DPA found this valid, noting the processing was necessary for the party's legitimate interest in informing potential voters, involved publicly available name/address data, and did not interfere with data subjects' rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP 260 rev. 01 guidelines for transparency in accordance with Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA found the Conservative People's Party violated Article 14 transparency obligations by failing to provide required information when collecting voter data from third parties. The party sent targeted campaign letters using names/addresses obtained from Geomatic based on segmentation of statistical and public data. While the DPA found legitimate interests basis valid under Article 6(1)(f), it rejected the party's claim that Danish practice exempted them from disclosure duties.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: KMD acquired development server through business acquisition without proper security assessment; Server classified as internal without personal data but contained sensitive information including social security numbers; Server compromised for Bitcoin mining; DPA found violation of Article 32 due to inadequate security measures that could have prevented breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; technical measures deficiency as aggravating; categories of data affected as aggravating; actions to mitigate damage as mitigating; other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Kombit A/S as data processor failed to implement proper technical and organizational security measures in the FLIS system, resulting in unauthorized access to sensitive personal data of 4.2 million citizens by 84 municipalities and their BI suppliers. The breach occurred due to a missing filter in data extraction that went undetected for over 4 months. The DPA found violations of Article 28(3)(f) and Article 32 regarding processor obligations and security measures. Serious criticism was expressed due to the large scale of the incident and lack of basic testing procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including aggravating circumstances (large scale of incident, lack of basic tests) and mitigating circumstances (low potential consequences for data subjects, disclosure to professionals, sufficient logging, quick handling). The incident scale and security deficiencies were aggravating while the nature of processing and response measures were mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: BEC, a data processor for Danish banks, inadvertently disclosed protected address information for over 20,000 persons during automated payment transfers between banks from May 2018 to August 2019. The error resulted from system flaws including improper data conversion, reset address protection markers, and lack of address protection checks for special addresses. The DPA found breaches of Article 5(1)(f) and Article 32(1) due to inadequate security measures and failure to detect the longstanding system errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating factors included the large number of affected customers, sensitive nature of protected addresses, and duration of errors since 2015. Mitigating factors included conflicting regulatory requirements and BEC's prompt remediation actions after discovery. The DPA issued serious criticism but no fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess legal bases under Article 6 as the case focused solely on whether MaCom A/S acted without proper instructions as a data processor under Article 28(3)(a).
a75_case_summary: MaCom A/S, a data processor for secondary schools, disclosed pseudonymized extracts of student assignments to university researchers for plagiarism detection development without proper instructions from data controllers. The DPA found this violated Article 28(3)(a) as assignment answers constitute personal data reflecting students' thinking and judgment. The DPA issued serious criticism, noting aggravating factors (inability to account for disclosure scope) and mitigating factors (scientific purpose, pseudonymized form, physical access only).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly but not systematically. Aggravating: inability to account for number of disclosures. Mitigating: scientific purpose, societal benefit, disclosure by physical access not transfer, pseudonymized form. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: JH Schultz Information A/S operated Schultz Expose system for municipalities' job centers. During a system update, a security component was disabled and not reactivated, allowing unauthorized access to employment-related information of approximately 1.5 million citizens. The DPA found Schultz violated Article 28(3)(f) and Article 32 by failing to implement sufficient technical and organizational security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating circumstances: lack of procedures to verify security component reactivation and large scope affecting 1.5 million citizens. Mitigating circumstances: low potential consequences for data subjects, pseudonymized data, disclosure to professionals bound by confidentiality, sufficient logging, and rapid handling of the breach.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid as not specific, informed, or voluntary. DPA emphasized lack of granularity for multiple purposes and insufficient information about marketing use and storage period.
a75_case_summary: Epic Booking processed nearly 500,000 photos of children/young people on Facebook without valid consent. DPA found consent invalid due to lack of specificity and information about purposes/storage. Violated storage limitation principle by indefinite retention. Ordered deletion of existing photos and 60-day maximum retention for future photos.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to extensive processing over many years. Categories of personal data was aggravating due to children's special protection. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public task under Article 6(1)(e). DPA found this valid as Visitdenmark is a public authority and processing was necessary for carrying out tasks under public authority.
a75_case_summary: Visitdenmark, a public authority, processed personal data to send letters via Digital Post informing cottage owners about new tax rules. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for public task performance. However, Visitdenmark failed to adequately comply with Article 14 disclosure obligations when collecting data from BBR register, warranting criticism.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: PrivatBo AMBA distributed 424 USB keys containing confidential tenant information during a property sale process. The DPA found PrivatBo failed to implement appropriate security measures by not reviewing material before distribution. The disclosure caused significant discomfort to tenants and risked reputation damage.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity of infringement (AGGRAVATING), technical/organizational measures (AGGRAVATING), and categories of personal data affected (AGGRAVATING). Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on notification of personal data breach pursuant to Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Nemlig.com experienced a security breach where customer order information was accessible online due to insufficient access controls. The DPA found Nemlig's risk assessment inadequate as it failed to consider risks for customers with secret/protected addresses. The DPA ordered Nemlig to notify affected data subjects under Article 58(2)(e) as the breach likely posed high risk to certain individuals.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for reporting personal data breaches under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Intervare A/S experienced a security breach where customer order information (names, addresses, purchase history) was accessible online due to insufficient access controls on a web-based reporting service. The DPA found Intervare's risk assessment inadequate as it failed to consider special risks for customers with secret/protected addresses and elderly/vulnerable customers. The DPA ordered Intervare to notify affected customers about the breach, particularly those with secret/omitted addresses, as the breach posed a high risk to their rights and freedoms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors implicitly but not systematically. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged exposure (2016-2019) and large number of affected data subjects. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to insufficient access controls. Categories of personal data were aggravating due to exposure of confidential address information.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: BroBizz A/S experienced three data breaches where customer service representatives disclosed personal data including location information to unauthorized persons. The Danish DPA found violations of Article 32(1) and 32(2) due to insufficient security measures and risk assessment procedures. The DPA issued a reprimand and order to conduct proper risk assessment, but found no violations of breach notification obligations under Articles 33-34.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed multiple Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to three incidents in short time. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating due to insufficient procedures. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as company took remedial actions. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to inadequate security. Previous infringements were aggravating due to repeat incidents. Cooperation with authority was mitigating. Categories of data were aggravating as location data carries high risk. Manner infringement became known was mitigating as company self-reported.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Prison and Probation Service initially denied a prison officer's access request regarding documents mentioning his name in violent incidents, citing technical limitations. After DPA intervention, the Service provided access to searchable reports but could not search free-text fields across 8-10 million documents. The DPA criticized the initial refusal but found rejecting free-text field searches justified under Section 19 of the Law Enforcement Act as these mainly describe work functions rather than personal behaviors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
