a75_case_summary: A citizen complained that Velliv insurance company did not provide full access to personal data processed about him. The DPA found Velliv properly withheld internal working documents containing legal assessments and correspondence with lawyers under Danish Data Protection Act §22. The DPA determined Velliv complied with Article 15 as personal data in withheld materials had already been provided and legal assessments didn't contain personal data about the complainant.

a36_legal_basis_summary: DGU claimed processing was based on consent under Article 6(1)(a). The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness, granularity, and unambiguous expression of will. The consent solution did not allow refusal and considered continued website use as consent.
a75_case_summary: DGU Erhverv A/S processed personal data on golf.dk website visitors for marketing and statistics based on invalid consent. The consent solution lacked voluntariness (no refusal option), granularity (no purpose selection), and unambiguous expression (continued use considered consent). DPA issued serious criticism and reprimand under Article 58(2)(b).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found insurance company violated Article 15 right of access by refusing to provide surveillance material (photos, videos, observation reports) collected during monitoring of complainant. Company claimed exemption under Danish Data Protection Act section 22 citing protection of business interests and police investigation, but DPA found no imminent danger of significant damage to justify withholding objective surveillance data. DPA issued serious criticism reprimand but no fine as material was eventually provided.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for contract fulfillment (Art 6(1)(b)) and for legal claims (Art 9(2)(f)). DPA found both legal bases valid as processing was necessary to assess insurance claim and determine compensation entitlement.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found Tryg Forsikring's processing of health data lawful for insurance claim assessment. Processing was based on Article 6(1)(b) (contract necessity) and Article 9(2)(f) (legal claims). DPA determined data collection was necessary and minimized according to Article 5(1)(c), rejecting complainant's claim that 10-year data collection exceeded consent scope.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Cryos International ApS refused to provide a sperm donor with information about the number of children conceived using his donations, claiming this wasn't personal data about him and would violate others' rights. The Danish DPA found that information about the number of donor children constitutes personal data about the donor and must be disclosed under Article 15. The DPA issued criticism and an order requiring Cryos to provide this information by December 7, 2021.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA ruled that father's use of Orienteringsret.dk website for requesting child information fell under household exemption (Article 2(2)(c)). The website itself was subject to GDPR as it provided means for processing personal data. DPA conducted security assessment but found no grounds to establish violation of Article 32 security requirements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Joga ApS was criticized for inadequate security measures in its fitness membership system. The DPA found violations of Article 32(1) GDPR due to using members' birth dates as permanent passwords and lacking login attempt limits. An injunction was issued requiring Joga to implement proper password security measures for all members.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding inadequate security measures aggravating and Joga's subsequent implementation of security improvements mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted as no fine was imposed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(d) and (e) as legal bases. DPA found Article 6(1)(e) invalid for general recording practice as it was not necessary for public task performance. DPA also found Article 6(1)(d) invalid as vital interests protection should only apply exceptionally.
a75_case_summary: Danish Business Authority recorded all incoming calls to customer center since 2018 for police documentation and training purposes. DPA found general recording practice violated data minimization principle and could not be justified under Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. DPA issued serious criticism and ordered compliance within 4 weeks.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public task under Article 6(1)(e) and Danish Statistics Act. DPA found this legal basis valid as Statistics Denmark has authority to collect statistical information and processing was necessary for this task.
a75_case_summary: Statistics Denmark failed to properly register complainant on internal opt-out list despite multiple requests, resulting in continued survey contacts. DPA found legal basis valid under Article 6(1)(e) for public task but criticized accuracy violation under Article 5(1)(d). No deletion obligation under Article 17(3)(b) as processing necessary for statistical purposes. Internal procedures initiated to prevent future errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA noted Statistics Denmark initiated internal procedures to ensure proper registration of opt-outs as mitigating factor. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing based on Article 6(1)(e) public task and Article 9(2)(j) research purposes. The DPA found the legal bases valid for all three research projects as scientific studies of significant societal importance.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA conducted a written inspection of Region Southern Denmark's research data processing. While finding legal bases valid for three research projects, the DPA criticized the region for failing to demonstrate decisions on supervision levels for two data processor agreements and not following their own supervision guidelines. The DPA issued a reprimand and order to bring processing into compliance regarding supervision of data processors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing authority under the Folkeskole Act (Article 6(1)(e)). The DPA found this valid for core educational purposes but invalid for supplementary products like YouTube where data was transferred to Google without proper legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Helsingør Municipality used Google Chromebooks and G-Suite in schools without proper risk assessments. Students' personal data was exposed through supplementary products like YouTube. The DPA found violations of data minimization, security, legal basis for supplementary products, breach notification, and impact assessment requirements. Corrective measures included orders to conduct risk assessments and implement restrictions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to children's special protection needs. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as municipality failed basic assessments. Mitigating factors included actions taken to close access to supplementary products. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(e) public task under the Folkeskole Act. The DPA found this legal basis valid for the core educational purposes but invalid for any processing beyond educational purposes, including potential marketing use by Google.
a75_case_summary: Helsingør Municipality used Google Chromebooks and Workspace for Education in schools. The DPA found multiple GDPR violations including inadequate risk assessment, insufficient documentation, unlawful third-country transfers to the US, and failure to conduct required DPIA. The DPA issued a processing ban, suspension of US transfers, and serious criticism, noting special risks to children's data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, cooperation as mitigating, technical measures as aggravating, and data categories as aggravating. The municipality's positive cooperation and previous adequacy assessment for US transfers were considered mitigating factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed processing basis under Article 6(1)(e) public task for educational purposes. DPA found processing unlawful because personal data was transferred to Google for Google's own purposes beyond educational tasks, violating purpose limitation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for data protection impact assessment (DPIA) and determination of whether the processing is "likely to involve a high risk" according to Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Helsingør Municipality used Google Workspace/Core Services in schools. DPA found high inherent risk due to children's data processing, complex technology, and extensive processing. Municipality failed to conduct proper DPIA addressing full technology stack risks. DPA upheld ban until compliance achieved, citing unauthorized data transfers to Google for its own purposes beyond educational tasks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to children's special protection. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to insufficient risk mitigation. Categories of personal data were aggravating due to children's data processing. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA suspended ban on Helsingør Municipality's use of Google Workspace for Education but issued orders to legalize processing. Municipality acknowledged processing was illegal with high unmitigated risks to students' rights. Orders include contract amendments, data flow documentation, updated impact assessment, and compliance plan within two months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, technical measures as aggravating, data categories as aggravating. DPA considered cooperation and mitigation actions as mitigating. Other factors not discussed systematically.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent (Art 6(1)(a)) for competition data processing and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for questionnaire data sharing. DPA found consent valid for competition data but invalidated legitimate interests basis for questionnaire data sharing, requiring consent due to detailed nature of information.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Article 29-Group Opinion 6/2014 on the legitimate interests of the controller as referred to in Article 7 of Directive 95/46/EC
a75_case_summary: DPA investigated SmartResponse's processing of personal data through internet competitions and questionnaires. Found consent valid for competition data collection but invalidated legitimate interests basis for sharing detailed questionnaire data. Issued serious criticism for unnecessary no-thanks list processing and 5-year storage period violating data minimization and storage limitation principles. Ordered deletion of no-thanks list data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: DBA claimed consent for marketing and legitimate interests for analytics. DPA found consent invalid due to lack of granularity and transparency. DPA also rejected legitimate interests basis due to US data transfers without adequate safeguards.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines on 05/2020 on consent Version 1.1.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA initiated own-initiative case against DBA's cookie consent solutions. Found both pre-June 2020 and current solutions violated GDPR consent requirements. Consent lacked granularity, specificity, and transparency. Also rejected legitimate interests basis for analytics due to US data transfers without adequate safeguards post-Schrems II.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for TV surveillance. DPA found this basis valid for crime prevention and legal claims purposes, noting employees were informed about surveillance purposes.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Fitness World's employee TV surveillance and data security practices following employee complaints. Found TV surveillance lawful under Article 6(1)(f) for crime prevention and legal claims purposes, with proper employee information. Issued serious criticism for Article 32 violation due to storing employee medical certificates, resignations, contracts, warnings and surveillance images on shared computer accessible to other employees.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Found inadequate technical/organizational measures (Article 83(2)(d)) as aggravating. Noted remedial actions taken (Article 83(2)(c)) as mitigating. Other factors not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of a public task under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this legal basis valid, emphasizing the university's obligation to ensure exam integrity during COVID-19 online examinations and the specific necessity assessment conducted for this particular subject.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated IT University's use of ProctorExam monitoring software during online exams due to COVID-19. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for public task, and compliant with Articles 5(1)(a)(c)(f), 32, and 35. The university conducted specific necessity assessments, chose least intrusive solution, implemented security measures, and provided adequate information to students.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed several Article 83(2) factors though not systematically. Cooperation with authority was mitigating, technical/organizational measures were mitigating, actions to mitigate damage were mitigating, and nature/gravity/duration was neutral. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of Article 32 security requirements and Article 28 processor agreements, but did not discuss specific legal bases for processing.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA found the Family Court violated Article 32 security requirements through inadequate technical/organizational measures, resulting in 134 unintentional disclosures including 34 cases involving protected names/addresses. Violations included insufficient testing of self-service solutions and inadequate processor agreements with CBRAIN and Visma. The DPA issued a reprimand considering the sensitive nature of data, prolonged duration since 2016, and the Court's mitigation efforts through implementation plans.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, categories of data affected, and technical/organizational measures. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, and other factors like organizational transition efforts.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for processing website visitor data for statistical purposes. DPA found processing valid under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for municipality's exercise of authority to optimize website efficiency and user-friendliness for citizens.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA initiated own-motion investigation into Næstved Municipality's processing of website visitor data via cookies. Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for statistical processing to optimize website user experience. DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(a) due to misleading text suggesting marketing purposes, but validated processing under Article 6(1)(e) for statistical purposes as part of municipal authority exercise.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Copenhagen Zoo experienced a security breach where a software engineer accessed annual card holders' personal data due to weak login security (4-digit passwords, no brute-force protection). The DPA found violations of Articles 32, 33, 34 and 5(1)(a) due to inadequate security measures and incorrect breach notifications. The Zoo was ordered to notify affected data subjects properly and correct previously given information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed multiple Article 83(2) factors as aggravating: large number of data subjects (140,000), insufficient security measures, lack of knowledge about system vulnerabilities, incorrect assumption about protected addresses, deficient notification to data subjects, and untruthful description of measures taken. No mitigating factors were mentioned.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Dantherm violated Article 24(1) accountability requirement by failing to demonstrate appropriate security measures and violated Article 32(1) by not implementing adequate technical measures to protect against risks.
a75_case_summary: Dantherm suffered a ransomware attack where hackers accessed employee data through an external consultant's administrator account. The DPA found Dantherm violated Article 32(1) by failing to implement adequate security measures, particularly regarding administrator privilege restrictions and log protection. Dantherm also violated Article 24(1) by being unable to demonstrate compliance or document when the compromised account was active.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish FSA inadvertently disclosed whistleblower email addresses to journalist through inadequate PDF redaction technique; DPA found insufficient technical/organizational measures for anonymization; Special risk due to whistleblower scheme; Issued serious criticism reprimand under Article 32(1)
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered information from whistleblower scheme as aggravating; Lack of adequate technical/organizational measures as aggravating; Long case processing time as mitigating factor; Did not systematically discuss Article 83(2) factors

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Capital Region of Denmark was responsible for two security breaches involving medication prescription data affecting thousands of patients. Code changes in the Health Platform caused integrity errors in the Joint Medicine Card system, resulting in double prescriptions. The DPA found violations of Article 32 security requirements due to inadequate testing procedures and failure to notify other controllers promptly. The repetitive nature of similar breaches was an aggravating factor.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as AGGRAVATING due to sensitive health data and prolonged integrity loss. Technical/organizational measures were AGGRAVATING due to inadequate security procedures. Previous infringements were AGGRAVATING as similar breaches occurred repeatedly. Categories of personal data were AGGRAVATING due to sensitive health information.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA's own secretariat disposed of confidential paper documents as ordinary waste instead of shredding for approximately 6 months. The DPA found breaches of Article 32(1) security requirements and Article 33(1) notification timeline. Serious criticism was issued due to the Authority's special obligation as data protection supervisor to comply with its own regulatory requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration (6 months) as aggravating, the intentional/negligent character as aggravating, the security measures deficiency as aggravating, and the special category data involved as aggravating. The Authority's remedial actions were considered mitigating. The Authority's special role as data protection supervisor was an additional aggravating factor.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: DBU and Divisionsforeningen refused access to CCTV footage from football stadium citing public safety concerns. DPA found Article 5(1)(a) breached due to conflicting information about data responsibility but upheld refusal of access under Danish Data Protection Act section 22 exemptions for public security. DPA recommended future specific assessments of access requests.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint about Trustpilot's response to access request regarding invitation emails sent on behalf of Asus Online Shop. Trustpilot claimed processor status for invitation emails but controller status for website usage. DPA investigated but decision outcome not specified in provided text.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: T. Hansen Gruppen A/S failed to implement appropriate security measures, storing passwords in plain text and allowing unauthorized access when a phone number was reassigned. The Danish DPA found violations of Articles 32(1) and 33(1) GDPR. The company was ordered to encrypt all passwords using recognized algorithms.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The Catholic Church claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests and Article 9(2)(d) for religious organizations, but the DPA did not assess the validity of these legal bases, focusing instead on the access request refusal.
a75_case_summary: The Catholic Church refused a data subject's access request regarding witness statements in a marriage annulment case, claiming exemption under Danish Data Protection Act section 22 for private interests including religious freedom and confidentiality. The DPA found the Church failed to conduct proper balancing of interests and generally refused access without specific assessment, violating Article 15. The DPA issued criticism and an order to reassess the request with proper balancing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for investigating workplace culture and potential abusive acts. The DPA found this legal basis valid for collecting general personal data but invalid for processing special category data without proper safeguards under Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Article 29 Working Party Guidelines for transparency under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: TV2 and law firm Norrbom Vinding conducted a workplace investigation into historical abusive acts and culture issues. The DPA found legitimate interests valid for general data collection under Article 6(1)(f) but criticized the broad collection of special category data without proper Article 9 safeguards. The DPA also found transparency violations under Articles 12-14 and issued serious criticism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. The nature/gravity of the infringement was aggravating due to sensitive data processing. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to failure to implement proper safeguards. Categories of personal data affected was aggravating due to special category data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent was valid under Article 6(1)(a); DPA found consent not voluntary for statistical purposes processing; DPA required demonstration that statistical processing is necessary part of paid alternative or separate consent mechanism.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA examined GulogGratis' cookie wall implementation offering choice between consent or payment. Found consent generally valid when payment alternative is reasonable and provides equivalent service. However, controller failed to demonstrate statistical processing was necessary part of paid alternative, violating accountability principle and consent requirements. Issued order to demonstrate necessity or implement separate consent for statistical purposes.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found controllers not obligated to search/review over 1 million documents for complainant's access request. Documents related to complainant's board member role and ongoing litigation. DPA determined information appeared accessory to business function and request was excessive under Article 12(5)(b).

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid due to insufficient information and lack of withdrawal mechanism; processing occurred before consent was obtained.
a75_case_summary: Leadwise processed personal data via cookies on letfinans.dk before obtaining valid consent. The DPA found consent invalid due to insufficient information and lack of withdrawal mechanism. Processing occurred before user interaction with consent banner. The DPA expressed serious criticism but noted Leadwise had changed the consent solution by June 2022.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(d) vital interests; DPA found Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests was correct basis; DPA upheld controller's assessment that processing was necessary to prevent fraud and maintain platform blocking
a75_case_summary: DPA rejected complaint about right to erasure; DBA retained user data to block complainant from platform due to multiple fraud complaints; DPA found legitimate interests basis valid under Article 6(1)(f); Storage limitation principle not breached as data automatically deleted after 24 months inactivity

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: TeeShoppen failed to delete complainant's personal data for marketing purposes despite previous 2020 complaint and assurance of deletion. DPA found violation of Article 17(1)(c) right to erasure when objecting to marketing. DPA issued serious criticism and order to delete data by August 23, 2022, which company complied with on same day.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for processing ordinary personal data, which the DPA found valid. For special category data, the DPA rejected the political party exemption under Article 9(2)(d) but accepted the legal claims basis under Article 9(2)(f).
a75_case_summary: The Conservative People's Party commissioned a legal investigation into sexual abuse allegations against a member. The DPA found processing lawful under Article 6(1)(f) and Article 9(2)(f) but criticized insufficient transparency under Article 14. The investigation aimed to assess membership continuation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness as the service offered against consent was not equivalent to paid alternative
a74_guidelines_referenced: European Data Protection Board, Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679, v. 1.1
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found Jysk Fynske Medier's cookie wall implementation invalid as consent was not voluntary. The company offered different content levels for consent vs payment, failing to provide equivalent alternatives. DPA issued order to ensure consent meets GDPR requirements for voluntariness.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to unequal employer-employee relationship. DPA found legitimate interest basis valid under Article 6(1)(f) as security approval was necessary for employment tasks.
a75_case_summary: Former security guard complained that Securitas A/S disclosed personal data to intelligence services without consent for security clearance. DPA found consent invalid due to employer-employee power imbalance but upheld processing under Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interest basis. Security approval was necessary for employment tasks and disclosure of social security number was justified for unique identification.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Article 6(1)(f) to avoid rumors. The DPA found this invalid because the data subject's interests outweighed this interest, as the information went beyond what was necessary.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA criticized an employer for informing entire workplace about employee dismissal due to cooperation difficulties. Employer claimed legitimate interest to prevent rumors. DPA found data subject's interests outweighed employer's interest as information went beyond what was necessary for informing about resignation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Elgiganten A/S failed to properly secure a returned television containing complainant's personal data during processing; television was stolen from warehouse during burglary; DPA found breach of Article 32 security obligations; criticized inadequate risk assessment that didn't account for employee deviations under pressure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; technical/organizational measures as aggravating; categories of data affected as aggravating; actions to mitigate damage as mitigating; other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Falkonergården mistakenly sent a student's absence warning letter to another student via e-Boks due to incorrect social security number entry. The DPA found Article 33 breached for failure to report the security breach, as the school failed to prove it was unlikely to pose risk to the student's rights. The DPA did not find Article 32 breached regarding security measures, citing appropriate procedures but called for reconsideration if recurrence occurs.

a7_defendant_name: National Board of Health and Welfare
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e) and for legal claims under Article 9(2)(f). The DPA found some disclosures were necessary but others exceeded what was required for the tortfeasor to relate to the recourse claim.
a75_case_summary: The Danish Civil Agency disclosed excessive personal data about a crime victim to the tortfeasor during recourse proceedings. While some disclosure was necessary to establish legal claims, the agency shared unnecessary information including details about family members, school changes, and psychological treatments. The DPA found violations of data minimization principles and issued serious criticism along with orders to update internal guidelines.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to sensitive data and police protection orders. Technical measures were aggravating as insufficient redaction occurred. Cooperation was mitigating as the agency acknowledged errors and updated guidelines. Damage mitigation was mitigating through subsequent procedural improvements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid; processing violated data minimization principle; disclosure of fertility treatment details was unnecessary for purpose
a75_case_summary: Municipality disclosed employee's fertility treatment details to entire department of 51 people via email. DPA found violation of data minimization principle (Article 5(1)(c)) as disclosure was unnecessary. Municipality acknowledged error and offered compensation, but DPA issued serious criticism due to sensitive nature of data and broad disclosure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered confidentiality of information and group size as aggravating; municipality's acknowledgment and cooperation as mitigating; no systematic Article 83(2) discussion.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Former municipal employee requested access to all communications mentioning them during employment. Municipality refused as excessive request under Article 12(5)(b). DPA upheld municipality's assessment that workplace communications primarily describe job functions rather than personal information about the individual.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(e) (public task). The DPA found the processing valid under this basis, noting both agencies have authority under national laws (Tax Control Act and Debt Recovery Act) to perform their official duties including tax assessment and debt recovery.
a75_case_summary: A citizen complained that the Tax Agency shared inheritance information with the Debt Agency within the Tax Administration. The DPA found the sharing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as both agencies perform public tasks related to state proceeds. The DPA determined the sharing did not violate purpose limitation as there was significant connection between tax assessment and debt recovery tasks.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent (Art 6(1)(a)) for preferences/statistics/marketing and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for functional purposes. DPA found consent invalid due to lack of informed consent and color nudging, but found legitimate interests valid for functional cookie processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DPA found JP/Politikens Hus's cookie consent solution violated GDPR consent requirements. The "Accept all" option failed to inform users about preference processing purpose, and color scheme (green=accept, red=reject) constituted problematic nudging. DPA expressed serious criticism but only addressed the previous consent solution as defendant had already changed it.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted written audit of Allerød Municipality's access control procedures in social administration systems. Municipality had generally satisfactory procedures but failed to conduct required log sampling for over six months during COVID-19. DPA found breach of Article 32 security requirements as municipality did not follow its own guidelines for control in at least one case.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA found nature/gravity/duration aggravating due to processing sensitive data and prolonged non-compliance. Technical measures were aggravating due to inadequate log sampling. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as normal operations resumed. Other mitigating factors included COVID-19 situation affecting operations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted audit of Gladsaxe Municipality's access rights management in SBSYS system used for school children's data. Municipality failed to revoke access rights for terminated employees and lacked effective control procedures. DPA found violation of Article 32(1) security requirements. Criticism expressed but no fine imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to sensitive children's data, technical measures as aggravating due to inadequate access controls, and mitigating actions as mitigating due to municipality's self-investigation. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted written supervision of Høje-Taastrup Municipality's access rights in file systems. Municipality lacked guidelines or objective criteria for registration in AD groups granting access to personal data. 410 employees had access to LOIS database without documented assessment of work-related needs. DPA found breach of Article 32(1) security requirements but noted municipality's intention to prepare guidelines.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA found nature/gravity/duration (83(2)(a)) aggravating due to 410 unauthorized accesses. Technical/organizational measures (83(2)(d)) were aggravating due to lack of access control guidelines. Actions to mitigate damage (83(2)(c)) were mitigating as municipality planned to implement guidelines. Other factors (83(2)(k)) were mitigating due to high technical competency required to actually use access.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA conducted a planned inspection of Hedensted Municipality's security measures under Article 32 GDPR. The inspection focused on reducing personal data breaches, particularly involving citizens with name and address protection. The DPA found the municipality had implemented appropriate security measures including procedures, technical tools, and organizational measures following past breaches. No criticism was expressed and no violations were found.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: KMD as data processor failed to adequately test new functionality in Institution I2 system, leading to foster parents gaining unauthorized access to foster children's data in AULA. The DPA found KMD violated Article 32(1) by not implementing appropriate technical and organizational security measures. The breach affected at least 23 foster children's contact details and social security numbers. Previous similar incidents in November 2020 were considered aggravating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered Article 83(2) factors including: nature/gravity/duration as AGGRAVATING, technical measures as AGGRAVATING, previous infringements as AGGRAVATING, and categories of data affected as AGGRAVATING due to children's sensitive data being compromised.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Falck's COVID-19 rapid testing information practices for students aged 12-15. Found compliance with Article 13 information obligations through multiple communication channels to both students and parents. Recommended child-targeted information materials but concluded no violations of transparency requirements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA criticized EG Digital Welfare ApS for inadequate security measures in Mediconnect IT system processing sensitive health data. Passwords were stored in clear text and single-factor authentication was used for accessing special category data. The DPA issued orders for irreversible password encryption and implementation of enhanced login security beyond username/password. The decision was based on Article 32 security requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of sensitive health data and processing of minors' data as aggravating factors. Planned security improvements were noted as mitigating. Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a) for facial recognition access control. The DPA found consent valid for customers but warned that employee consent may not be voluntary due to power imbalance. The DPA warned against processing without consent for statistical purposes and for non-consenting individuals.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated FysioDanmark's planned use of facial recognition for access control. The DPA found consent could be valid for customers but warned against processing biometric data without consent for statistical purposes and for non-consenting individuals captured by the continuously active system. The DPA issued warnings under Article 58(2)(a) regarding these potential violations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA criticized Gyldendal A/S for inadequate security measures in Systime Screening service used by teachers to screen students. The URL design with short randomized characters allowed unauthorized access to student test results across schools. The DPA found this violated Article 32(1) as it failed to protect against known risks like URL manipulation and incorrect entry.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating (10+ years, affected many students), technical measures as aggravating (inadequate URL security), and mitigating factors included risk reassessment, URL adjustments, informing controllers, cooperation, and guidance preparation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess legal bases as no violation was found; the case focused on security measures and balancing of interests in an emergency situation.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Joannahuset crisis center for requesting social security number via SMS. The DPA found no violation as the specific emergency situation justified balancing data protection against the young person's immediate safety needs. The DPA acknowledged that while SMS transmission poses security risks, considerations for the vulnerable youth's welfare outweighed data protection concerns in this exceptional case.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Mindworking A/S, a data processor for real estate agents, developed a platform with a security vulnerability allowing unauthorized access to personal data via source code inspection using a function key. The Danish DPA found Article 32 breached due to inadequate security measures, noting the vulnerability existed from early 2019 until November 2021. The DPA issued criticism, considering the elementary nature of the error and potential access to sensitive data, while noting prompt correction upon discovery.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration (83(2)(a)) aggravating due to the elementary mistake and long duration. Intentional/negligent character (83(2)(b)) was aggravating as the error should have been avoided. Actions to mitigate damage (83(2)(c)) were mitigating due to same-day correction. Technical measures (83(2)(d)) were aggravating due to inadequate security. Categories of data (83(2)(g)) was aggravating due to potential access to sensitive information.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Aarhus Municipality requested Article 36 consultation regarding Google Workspace for Education processing involving student data. DPA found high risks that couldn't be reduced and issued orders under Article 58(2)(d) to amend agreements, clarify data flows, update impact assessments, and create legalization plan. The processing involved unclear controller roles and potential third country transfers.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA initiated an own-initiative case against the Family Court regarding 37 breaches involving accidental disclosure of protected name/address information to unauthorized parties, primarily in family law cases where one party had protection against the other. Despite implementing measures after a previous 2021 decision, the DPA found the Family Court failed to adequately reassess security measures given repeated similar breaches. The DPA issued serious criticism for violating Article 32(1) and ordered a renewed risk assessment with necessary organizational/technical measures by January 2023.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration (83(2)(a)) aggravating due to serious consequences for data subjects, and previous infringements (83(2)(e)) aggravating as repeat offenses. Technical/organizational measures (83(2)(d)) were aggravating due to insufficient procedures. Actions to mitigate damage (83(2)(c)) were mitigating as the Family Court implemented significant organizational measures. Other factors (83(2)(k)) were mitigating due to organizational efforts like GDPR ambassadors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on public task authority under Section 222 of the Health Act. The DPA did not invalidate this legal basis but focused on transparency obligations under Article 14.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679 (wp260rev.01);Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25, Data protection by design and data protection by default
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated SSI's compliance with Article 14 information obligations regarding blood sample analysis and biobank storage. SSI argued notification would require disproportionate effort due to system limitations and costs. The DPA found SSI cannot invoke Article 14(5)(b) exception as difficulties were not caused by indirect data collection but by inadequate system setup. SSI was ordered to explain how it will fulfill Article 14 obligations within 3 months.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA issued serious criticism to trade union 3F Østfyn for GDPR violations after unintentionally disclosing a member's new name to their former violent cohabitant. The union's CRM system retained outdated addresses as default values when members had address protection, and lacked technical/organizational measures to ensure data accuracy and security. The DPA found breaches of Article 5(1)(d) accuracy principle and Article 32 security requirements, noting serious consequences for the data subject.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration of infringement as AGGRAVATING due to serious consequences for the data subject. Lack of technical/organizational measures was AGGRAVATING. Actions to mitigate damage were MITIGATING as 3F planned information campaigns and procedure updates. Categories of personal data affected was AGGRAVATING given the sensitive context of domestic violence. Other aggravating factors included the member's extra effort to inform 3F specifically about risks.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Legal basis discussion was not part of this security breach case; the decision focused solely on Article 32 security measures and Article 33 breach notification compliance.
a75_case_summary: Coop Danmark A/S was criticized for failing to implement adequate security measures under Article 32 GDPR after discovering personal data of 477 employees and consultants on a shared drive without proper access controls dating back to 2013. The DPA found the company should have proactively checked and cleaned the shared drive earlier given its size and the sensitive nature of data involved. While Coop timely reported the breach under Article 33, the DPA issued serious criticism but no fine, noting the company was transitioning to a more secure system.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the long duration (2013-2021) and sensitive nature of data (health, financial, social security numbers) as aggravating factors. Cooperation with the authority and remediation efforts were viewed as mitigating. The decision did not systematically apply Article 83(2) factors as this was a reprimand case without financial penalty.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Designbysi ApS experienced a hacker attack where unauthorized JavaScript was inserted on their webshop to collect customer card information. The Danish DPA found Designbysi violated Article 32(1) by failing to implement appropriate security measures, specifically multifactor authentication for users with payment script access. The DPA issued serious criticism noting the lack of security measures enabled access to payment information that could cause financial harm to customers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the lack of security measures aggravating as it enabled hackers to access payment information potentially causing financial harm. Designbysi's post-incident implementation of two-factor authentication was noted as a mitigating factor. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Sports Connection ApS was hacked through its Magento webshop, allowing unauthorized access to customer payment information. The DPA found the company failed to implement appropriate security measures by not updating to the latest Magento version and not maintaining proper documentation. Serious criticism was issued for breaches of Articles 32(1) and 24(1) regarding security measures and accountability.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized the known risk scenario of e-commerce platform vulnerabilities and the sensitivity of payment information as aggravating factors. The company's immediate shutdown and customer notification were mitigating factors. The lack of proper documentation was also considered aggravating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that LB Forsikring failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures both in system design (Article 25) and security measures (Article 32), particularly criticizing the use of email domains as the sole factor for determining document access rights.
a75_case_summary: LB Forsikring's archiving system improperly granted customers access to third-party documents by using email domain as sole access control. The flaw persisted for 959 days, exposing personal data of witnesses, counterparties, and mechanics. The DPA found violations of Articles 25 and 32 for inadequate security measures and failure to implement data protection by design. Serious criticism was issued due to prolonged duration, inadequate risk assessment, and special protection needs of certain data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors: inadequate risk assessment, prolonged duration (959 days), significant processing scope, special protection needs of witnesses, and awareness of risk. Mitigating factors: personal data was generally already known to the accessing party. LB's future investigation plans were noted but not treated as mitigation.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Silkeborg Municipality sent unencrypted email containing 12,915 students' social security numbers, school names, and codes to Statistics Denmark Consulting. The DPA found inadequate security measures as TLS 1.1 encryption was insufficient and content encryption was lacking. The municipality violated Articles 32(1) and 5(1)(f) by failing to implement appropriate technical measures for sensitive children's data transmission.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed several Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity was AGGRAVATING due to large volume of sensitive children's data; technical measures were AGGRAVATING due to insufficient encryption; mitigation actions were MITIGATING as the municipality implemented training and upgraded to TLS 1.2; manner of discovery was MITIGATING as the municipality self-reported.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Digitization Agency mistakenly granted 26 trustees access to wrong companies' digital mailboxes due to human error in list preparation. The DPA found inadequate security measures under Article 32(1), criticizing reliance on past error-free performance rather than implementing verification procedures. The agency had experienced similar errors previously and implemented multi-eye principle after the incident.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered previous similar infringements as aggravating, the implementation of corrective measures as mitigating, and inadequate technical/organizational measures as aggravating. Human error being common knowledge was also cited as an aggravating factor.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess specific legal bases but focused on security obligations under Article 32.
a75_case_summary: North Jutland Region failed to implement appropriate security measures for its MineAftaler/SelvBooking IT solution, allowing unauthorized access to patient data via a known vulnerability (broken access control) from May 2018 to April 2021. The DPA found Article 32 breached due to insufficient security requirements in contracts and testing procedures. Aggravating factors included sensitive health data exposure affecting 500,000 patients over three years; mitigating factors included NemID login deterrent and GDPR audit attempts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly: nature/gravity/duration (AGGRAVATING), technical measures (AGGRAVATING), data categories (AGGRAVATING), actions to mitigate (MITIGATING), and cooperation (NEUTRAL). No systematic analysis of all factors was performed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danske Bank experienced a technical error that made 132 electronic invoices containing name, address and invoice number visible to 14,511 Finnish business customers for 5 days. The DPA found inadequate security measures under Article 32(1) GDPR, specifically noting failure to continuously test technical measures. A reprimand was issued as the breach involved only basic information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of the breach as aggravating due to inadequate security measures, but mitigating factors included that only name, address and invoice number were exposed. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Health Authority employee stored pseudonymized health data in unauthorized development environment Microsoft Azure DevOps for one year. Authority lacked controls to detect such storage errors despite guidelines prohibiting it. DPA found violation of Article 32(1) security requirements, citing inadequate technical/organizational measures to prevent mistaken storage in agile development environments.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating factors included special categories of data, large number of citizens affected, and duration of one year; mitigating factors included pseudonymization and limited access to trusted employees; no systematic weighing of all factors was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Tax Administration failed to notify data subject of personal data breach involving financial information and social security numbers for approximately 40 days after discovery. The DPA found this violated Article 34(1) due to high risk to data subject rights. The agency provided incorrect information in its initial breach notification, claiming notification had occurred when it hadn't. Holiday period was rejected as justification for delay.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors: nature/gravity/duration of breach (40-day delay), negligent character, and inadequate organizational measures. Mitigating factors included: Tax Administration's cooperation in self-reporting the error and taking actions to mitigate damage by eventually notifying the data subject.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: University of Southern Denmark failed to test software update that reset HR system permissions, giving all 7011 employees access to 417 job applications containing sensitive data including social security numbers and health information. The DPA found violation of Article 32(1) due to insufficient testing procedures and lack of access logging. Mitigating factors included quick remediation and cooperation, but aggravating factors included sensitive data exposure and basic security failure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors without systematic framework. Aggravating: nature/gravity (basic rights management failure), technical measures (no testing), categories of data (health/social security numbers). Mitigating: actions to mitigate damage (quick remediation), cooperation with authority. Neutral factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish Health Data Agency breached Articles 32 and 33 GDPR when a code change in Health Platform caused unintended changes in Common Medical Card affecting 267 patients. Agency failed to ensure adequate security measures including testing for integrity errors in service-based architecture. Agency also reported breach 4 days late instead of within 72 hours. Previous similar errors were considered aggravating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to risk to patients. Technical measures were aggravating due to inadequate security. Previous infringements were aggravating due to similar past errors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found insufficient allocation of roles and responsibilities between Boligportal and Meta Ireland as joint controllers, particularly regarding compliance with Article 26 GDPR for demonstrating lawful processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on controllers and processors
a75_case_summary: BoligPortal was reprimanded for failing to demonstrate compliance with GDPR regarding joint controllership with Meta Ireland for processing website visitor data through Facebook Business Tools. The DPA found insufficient allocation of responsibilities under Article 26 GDPR and ordered compliance. The decision did not rule on actual data transfers to the US due to factual disagreements between parties.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A housing association refused a resident's access request, citing Public Information Act rules instead of GDPR. The DPA found serious criticism warranted for failing to assess the request under Article 15 and delaying response. The DPA upheld the association's assessment that complainant identities could be withheld under Danish Data Protection Act §22(1) due to concrete harassment risks.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found no basis to override the National Police's assessment that disclosure was permissible under Danish Data Protection Act §10(1) for scientific research of significant societal importance, but found the disclosure violated Article 5 principles regarding purpose limitation and data minimization when involving individuals who had objected to fines and were awaiting court decisions.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA criticized the National Police for disclosing speeding fine information to a university research project involving individuals who had objected to their fines and were awaiting court decisions. The DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(b) purpose limitation and 5(1)(c) data minimization principles, as the disclosure lacked factual and relevant purpose for individuals presumed innocent until court decision. The authority issued an order to cease such disclosures and expressed serious criticism, while acknowledging the research project's general legitimacy under Danish law.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: SIRIUS lawyers failed to implement basic security measures for remote access to IT systems containing special category data. A hacker attack compromised client information, creating serious risks to data subjects. The Danish DPA found inadequate security measures despite high-risk processing context. The firm was cooperative and implementing multifactor authentication at time of breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized nature/gravity of infringement and need for effective deterrent fine as aggravating factors. Cooperative behavior and ongoing security improvements were mitigating factors. Data categories affected weighed against the controller.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA issued serious criticism to Digital Agency and Signaturgruppen for insufficient security measures in MitID authentication system. A race condition error allowed citizens to access others' bank accounts when logging in within milliseconds. The DPA found Article 32 violated as security recommendations weren't made mandatory requirements despite high risks. The nationwide authentication solution processes sensitive personal data and provides access to financial systems.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as AGGRAVATING due to nationwide impact and access to financial data. Technical/organizational measures were AGGRAVATING as security wasn't adequate. Actions to mitigate damage were MITIGATING as the agency implemented fixes after incident. Other factors were NOT_DISCUSSED.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal authority but the DPA focused exclusively on data minimization principle violation without assessing legal basis validity.
a75_case_summary: The Danish Agency for Digitalisation processed personal data of all 3.96 million Danish driving license holders for its digital driving license app, though only 1.7 million had joined. The DPA found this violated Article 5(1)(c) data minimization principle as processing extended to 2.26 million non-users without necessity. The DPA issued serious criticism and banned processing of non-users' data, requiring cessation within 4 weeks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement aggravating due to extensive processing of personal data without necessity. Technical limitations cited by the agency were deemed insufficient justification. Categories of personal data affected included sensitive data, further aggravating the violation. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Salling Group stored customer passwords in plain text in log files for over a year, exposing them to up to 146 internal users. The DPA found violation of Article 32(1) for inadequate security measures. Serious criticism was issued and an order to notify affected customers was given. The company corrected the error and deleted the unencrypted data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the large number of affected customers and serious potential consequences as aggravating. The company's corrective actions were mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Hovedstadens Beredskab I/S reported a security breach where all users of their ESDH system had access to sensitive employee data including names, social security numbers, and protected addresses since May 2022. The DPA found violation of Article 32(1) for inadequate access controls, noting that only HR personnel needed this access but 184+ users had it. The DPA issued criticism and noted the organization's planned remediation by April 2023.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to widespread access to sensitive data. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as the organization reported promptly and planned remediation. Cooperation was mitigating as they provided information. Categories of data affected were aggravating due to sensitive personal data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a) for facial recognition access control. The DPA found consent could be valid if properly informed, but criticized specific consent attempts to the complainant as not voluntary due to misinformation about alternatives.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;EDPB Guidelines 3/2019 on the use of video equipment for the processing of personal data
a75_case_summary: A gym implemented facial recognition for access control based on consent. The DPA found facial recognition itself permissible but required valid consent with real alternatives. While generally valid consent was possible, the DPA criticized specific consent attempts to the complainant as not voluntary due to misinformation about access alternatives (reception hours only vs actual 24/7 code/support options).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA issued serious criticism to Clemens Bar ApS for deleting CCTV footage after refusing data subject's access request. The nightclub refused access citing security concerns and potential infringement of others' rights. DPA found deletion violated Article 5(1)(a) by depriving complainant of ability to verify rights through DPA or courts.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA ruled on two complaints regarding the Danish Development and Simplification Agency's refusal to disclose the identity of an unintended recipient of personal data. The DPA found that unintended recipients fall within the broad definition of "recipient" under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR and that the auditor's name was not confidential under tax confidentiality rules. The DPA ordered the agency to provide information about the auditor but upheld the refusal regarding the client's identity.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Article 6(1)(e) and Article 9(2)(g) could serve as legal bases but require supplementary national legal basis. Development was valid under existing Services Act provisions, but operation required clearer legal basis due to intrusive nature of AI processing.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA assessed Copenhagen Municipality's authority to develop and operate an AI solution predicting citizens' need for rehabilitation. While development was authorized under existing Services Act provisions, operation required clearer legal basis due to intrusive AI processing of sensitive health data affecting vulnerable groups. The DPA emphasized AI's fundamentally different nature from traditional case processing necessitating greater legal clarity.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA inspected 6 municipalities' processing security in AULA education system. Found deficiencies in risk assessments and impact analyses regarding processing of children's sensitive data. Issued orders for impact analyses and expressed criticism/serious criticism regarding inadequate security measures and documentation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to high risks to children's data. Lack of technical/organizational measures was aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating. Other factors not systematically discussed under Art 83(2).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA criticized the Ministry of Immigration and Integration for failing to conduct ongoing checks on automatic deletion practices in the national visa information system, violating accountability principles under GDPR Article 5(2). The ministry also failed to immediately delete information when visa applicants obtained EU citizenship before deletion deadlines, violating VIS Regulation Article 25(1). Additionally, the ministry failed to notify responsible Member States when applicants obtained Danish citizenship, violating VIS Regulation Article 25(2).

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on user consent through Tink API, but the DPA found this resulted in processing beyond what was necessary for the purpose. The DPA determined that controllers cannot base processing on scenarios where they are aware more data than necessary will be processed.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated Dansk Retursystem's Pant app for mortgage payments which integrated Tink's API to obtain bank account information. The DPA found the app processed excessive personal data beyond what was necessary for the payment purpose, including balances, loans, transaction history and identity information. The DPA held Dansk Retursystem responsible as controller for violating data minimization and lawfulness principles, regardless of using third-party APIs. The company was ordered to bring processing into compliance by January 2025 and received a warning about future violations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent for customer data processing but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of granularity for multiple purposes. For employee data, DPA validated legitimate interests basis. AI analysis was deemed not an independent purpose requiring separate legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: European Data Protection Board Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DPA investigated IDA Forsikring's use of AI to analyze recorded customer service calls. Found consent process invalid due to lack of granularity for documentation and quality assurance purposes. Validated legitimate interests basis for employee data processing. AI analysis deemed compliant with principles when proper legal basis established.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a). The DPA found consent invalid due to the inherent power imbalance between public authorities and patients, making consent non-voluntary. The DPA referenced EDPB guidelines and Recital 43 regarding public authorities' limited ability to use consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDBP's guidelines 5/2020 regarding consent in accordance with regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Aarhus University Hospital published patient photos and health information on Instagram for marketing and recruitment purposes, claiming consent as legal basis. The Danish DPA found consent invalid due to the power imbalance between public healthcare providers and vulnerable patients. The processing violated Articles 5, 6(1)(a), and 9(2)(a) GDPR. The DPA issued serious criticism and ordered deletion of all patient posts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature/gravity of infringement and categories of personal data affected as aggravating factors. Other factors were not systematically addressed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that the National Audit Office's processing basis is Article 6(1)(e) (public task) with supplementary authority from the National Auditors Act Section 12(1). The Ministry of Justice had assessed this provision as compatible with GDPR, as processing is necessary for performance of a task in the interest of society.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA conducted an inspection of the National Audit Office's processing of personal data during auditing activities. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) with supplementary authority from the National Auditors Act. The DPA also found compliance with data minimization principles through documented procedures and dialogue with audited authorities.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Digital Agency's use of JavaScript in MitID login system following citizen complaint about security risks. Agency conducted general risk assessment but failed to specifically assess JavaScript risks despite known security vulnerabilities. DPA found violations of accountability principle and security obligations, issuing criticism but no fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to critical national infrastructure context. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to insufficient risk assessment. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish Agency for Digitization received serious criticism for inadequate security measures in its Next Generation Digital Post system. Multiple security breaches occurred during data migration and system updates, including unauthorized access to mailboxes and incorrect registrations. The DPA found violations of Article 32(1) due to insufficient technical and organizational measures, emphasizing the system's critical role as the primary communication channel between authorities and citizens.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors but did not systematically apply them. The nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to multiple serious breaches over extended periods. The intentional/negligent character was aggravating as errors resulted from inadequate testing and planning. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as the agency corrected errors and notified affected parties. Technical measures were aggravating due to insufficient security protocols. Categories of data affected were aggravating given the sensitive nature of governmental communications.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Danish Data Protection Act section 8(4) for disclosing criminal offense information. DPA found the specific description of criminal enrichment was not necessary to safeguard the company's legitimate interest, and disclosure should have been limited to information about the expulsion only.
a75_case_summary: A Meny grocer verbally disclosed to complainant's former boss that complainant had been expelled due to criminal enrichment case based on CCTV review. DPA found this disclosure violated Danish Data Protection Act section 8(4) as the specific criminal offense description was unnecessary for legitimate interest. Only expulsion information should have been shared.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior and Health
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA ruled that the Ministry of the Interior and Health could not refuse a data subject's request for access to CPR security log information based on resource concerns. The decision follows the CJEU ruling in case C-579/21 which established that log files containing search dates and purposes constitute personal data subject to Article 15 access rights. The DPA found that Section 22(2) of the Danish Data Protection Act does not permit refusal based on administrative burden but only for specific public interest considerations.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis; DPA found processing necessary for official duties in notification case; DPA upheld municipality's assessment that legal basis was valid.
a75_case_summary: Helsingør Municipality processed illegally obtained wiretapping information in child protection case; DPA found processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for public task; DPA conducted fairness assessment weighing child protection interests against data protection rights; concluded processing was fair and compliant with GDPR principles.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA assessed processing under Article 9(2)(g) via Danish Data Protection Act Section 7(4) for substantial public interest. Permission was granted for football matches but denied for other events as not proportionate or necessary for essential public interest.
a75_case_summary: F.C. Copenhagen applied for permission to process biometric data via facial recognition for access control at events. The DPA granted permission for football matches under Section 7(4) of Danish Data Protection Act but denied it for other events as not proportionate or necessary for substantial public interest. The decision was based on lack of specific security problems and no prior quarantines for non-football events.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests as legal basis. The DPA found the processing not necessary for the stated purpose and that data subjects' privacy interests outweighed transparency interests, making the legal basis invalid.
a75_case_summary: Boliglag ApS operated a website aggregating publicly available housing data including homeowners' names, gender, age, and property sales history. The Danish DPA found the processing unlawful under Article 6(1)(f) as it was not necessary for the transparency purpose and data subjects' privacy interests outweighed the controller's interests. The DPA issued criticism noting the particularly intrusive nature of making personal data searchable by name.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered Boliglag's quick implementation of temporary measures to remove personal data as a mitigating circumstance in choosing the sanction of criticism rather than a fine. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed data under public task basis but the DPA found inadequate security measures violated Article 32(1) by failing to ensure appropriate technical and organizational security measures for the risks involved.
a75_case_summary: Copenhagen Municipality experienced a data security breach when 37,500 employees gained unauthorized access to personal data of up to 3.7 million people including children's sensitive information. The breach occurred due to human error during a disk swap that granted overly broad access rights. The DPA found the municipality violated Article 32(1) by failing to implement appropriate security measures, including proper access controls and post-transfer testing. The DPA issued serious criticism but no fine, noting the municipality had implemented some security measures but had subsequent similar breaches.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character as aggravating factors due to the scale of data and human error. The municipality's actions to mitigate damage and cooperation were mitigating factors. The categories of personal data affected (including children's sensitive data) was aggravating. The manner the infringement became known (self-reporting) was mitigating.

a7_defendant_name: National Board of Health and Welfare
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The National Board of Health and Welfare returned an unencrypted USB stick containing over 800 pages of sensitive complainant information that was lost during transit. The agency lacked guidelines for handling removable storage devices and failed to report the breach to the DPA. The DPA found inadequate security measures and recommended a DKK 100,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized the lack of encryption as an essential security measure that should be easily implemented, particularly for a state authority processing sensitive information. The agency's failure to have proper guidelines for caseworkers and the sensitive nature of the data were aggravating factors. The case involved a breach notification violation under Article 33.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: National Genome Center processed genetic data without consulting DPA despite DPIA showing high risk; DPA imposed temporary ban on data collection and restriction on processing; Violation of consultation requirement when high risk exists; Fine recommended due to seriousness but mitigated by NGC's cooperation and risk work quality.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered high risk to data subjects as aggravating; NGC's high quality risk work and active cooperation were mitigating factors; Other Art 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danske Bank failed to document proper deletion procedures across 400+ systems processing millions of individuals' data. The Danish DPA initiated an own-motion investigation after the bank self-reported deletion issues. The breach concerned fundamental GDPR principles including storage limitation and accountability. A DKK 10M fine was imposed considering the scale and basic nature of the violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (affecting many data subjects and basic principles). Mitigating factors included bank's efforts to limit damage and active cooperation. The fine was set to be effective, proportionate and deterrent.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vejle Municipality's dental care had automatic process sending welcome letters containing both parents' addresses without assessing disclosure necessity. This resulted in parents receiving information about other parent's address regardless of name/address protection. Danish DPA found inadequate security measures violating GDPR security requirements. Case discovered through municipality's own breach notification.
