a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA emphasized nature/seriousness of infringement, requirement for effective/proportionate/deterrent fine, and municipality size in terms of population and operating budget as aggravating factors. The fact that municipality self-reported the breach was considered mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest for informing customers about employee dismissal; DPA found legitimate interest existed for informing customers employee was dismissed but not for detailed criminal offense information; Detailed description of criminal offenses was not necessary to fulfill the objective.
a75_case_summary: Company disclosed detailed criminal offense information about former employee to customers via email; DPA found legitimate interest existed for informing customers about dismissal but not for detailed criminal information; Disclosure violated data protection principles as information about criminal offenses was not necessary; Proposed fine of DKK 150,000 for unlawful processing of special category data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity (AGGRAVATING) due to criminal offense data disclosure; Categories of personal data affected (AGGRAVATING) due to special category data; Other factors not explicitly discussed in Art 83(2) framework.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Gyldendal stored information about 685,000 resigned book club members in a passive database without deletion procedures, with 395,000 records kept over 10 years. The Danish DPA found violations of storage limitation and accountability principles. The DPA reported to police and recommended DKK 1,000,000 fine due to the large scale and intentional nature of violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the violation intentional and affecting many data subjects as aggravating factors. Gyldendal's cooperation and limited database access were mitigating factors. The DPA assessed sanctions under Article 83(2) but did not systematically discuss all factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Lolland Municipality failed to implement basic security measures by allowing employees to disable mandatory access codes on mobile devices. A stolen work phone without access code protection exposed citizens' sensitive information including names, social security numbers, and health data. The DPA found inadequate security measures and recommended a DKK 50,000 fine, emphasizing the municipality's special responsibility to protect citizen information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA conducted Article 83(2) assessment. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement, inadequate technical measures, sensitive data categories affected, and municipality's special responsibility. Mitigating factors included immediate remedial actions taken and breach self-reporting.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Medicals Nordic used WhatsApp to transmit confidential health information and social security numbers of COVID-19 test subjects. Employees used private phones and WhatsApp groups where unauthorized personnel received sensitive data, including former employees who weren't removed from groups. The Danish DPA found inadequate security measures and intentional violations due to lack of risk assessments.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized that confidential health information about many citizens was processed insecurely and shared with unauthorized persons, including former employees. Violations were considered intentional due to lack of necessary risk assessments. The nature of sensitive data and intentional character were aggravating factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Region Zealand granted 16,322 employees broad access to patient lists across all hospitals containing sensitive health data without adequate security measures. The DPA found this violated Article 32(1) by failing to implement appropriate technical and organizational security measures. The access was not limited to work-related needs and logging was insufficient to track which specific patient data users accessed. The DPA issued serious criticism and expects Region Zealand to audit all areas with broad access without concrete treatment relationships.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly but not systematically. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged broad access since 2017. Categories of personal data affected was aggravating due to sensitive health information. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to inadequate access controls and logging. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vejen Municipality reported stolen laptops containing unencrypted student data including information about children with special challenges. DPA investigation revealed up to 300 additional unencrypted computers in the municipality. The DPA emphasized encryption as a basic security measure and noted repeated similar violations across municipalities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration and technical measures as aggravating factors, while cooperation and manner of discovery were mitigating. The municipality had previous similar violations which was also aggravating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found processing illegal as mere flipping from public registers did not fulfill necessity condition.
a75_case_summary: Czech DPA found company violated GDPR by scraping personal data from public registers without valid legal basis. Company failed to inform data subjects about processing and facilitate exercise of rights. Administrative proceeding resulted in CZK 500,000 fine and remedial measures order.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Czech DPA inspected a media content provider's cookie processing practices. Found violations of Article 12(1) and (2) regarding transparency obligations - information was not easily accessible and incomplete. The controller rectified the illegal condition during inspection but was fined CZK 100,000 for non-cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA noted mitigating factors: the controller took technical and organizational measures under Article 32 and rectified the violation during inspection. An aggravating factor was non-cooperation with the authority. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior of the Czech Republic
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Czech Police collected health data of approximately 2 million COVID-19 patients from April 2021 to March 2022 without proper legal authority. The processing violated information obligations and failed to conduct mandatory data protection impact assessment or consult with the DPA. The Ministry of Interior was fined for exceeding police powers under national law implementing Directive 2016/680.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the seriousness of misconduct, number of affected persons (2 million), and other circumstances as aggravating factors. The fine amount was deemed reasonable given these considerations. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted as this case falls under the law enforcement directive regime.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid without conducting a proper proportionality test balancing the data subject's rights against the public interest in information about criminal proceedings.
a75_case_summary: Individual posted partially anonymized criminal order containing personal data on Facebook. First instance DPA found GDPR violations and imposed CZK 10,000 fine. Municipal Court annulled decision due to failure to conduct proper proportionality test for legitimate interests. Appellate body returned case for new hearing requiring balance test between public interest and data protection rights.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was needed but DPA found disclosure of complainant's expulsion to insurance companies violated Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1), and 9(1) as no valid legal basis existed under Articles 6 or 9 for this processing operation.
a75_case_summary: The Pancyprian Association of Motor Appraisers disclosed a member's expulsion to insurance companies without legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1), 9(1) and 31 due to unlawful processing of special category data (trade union membership) and lack of cooperation. The Association failed to demonstrate compliance or provide requested documentation during investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered lack of cooperation as aggravating and first-time offense as mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted beyond these factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Cabinet Office breached GDPR by sharing New Year Honours list with 1,097 recipients before official announcement. The data included home addresses and unshared postal details. The ICO found multiple Article 5 principle violations and failure to notify breach promptly. The processing lacked appropriate security measures and exceeded necessary data sharing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The ICO systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of breach, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and sensitive data categories. Mitigating factors included cooperation with investigation, actions to mitigate damage, and prompt breach reporting. The overall assessment led to a £500,000 fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for employee monitoring system. DPA found this invalid as defendant failed to demonstrate necessity and proportionality, and did not consider less intrusive measures before implementation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 2/2018 on Workplace Video Surveillance and Use of Biometric Systems;Opinion 2/2017 on Data Processing at Work;Opinion 06/2014 on Meaning of Legitimate Interests
a75_case_summary: KEO PLC implemented an upgraded employee card system with low-resolution photo capture for time tracking. DPA found violations of data minimization principle (installing camera without considering less intrusive measures) and storage limitation principle (7-year retention period). Defendant claimed legitimate interests but failed to demonstrate necessity and proportionality. DPA issued compliance order to suspend system and develop new measures with employee consultation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered Article 83(2) factors but did not impose fine. Cooperation with authority and compliance efforts were mitigating factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating. No systematic discussion of most factors occurred.

a7_defendant_name: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and accountability obligation due to inability to locate insurance policy containing personal data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Personal data breach notification under Regulation 2016/679 WP 250 rev.1
a75_case_summary: Bank failed to locate complainant's insurance policy despite requests. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2), 15, 32, and 33 due to inadequate security measures leading to data unavailability, failure to demonstrate accountability, and lack of breach notification. Bank claimed policy might be misplaced but couldn't prove it still existed within their systems.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature of breach, manner authority informed, and infringement duration. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage, and no financial benefit. Neutral factors included categories of data affected and number of data subjects.

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Deutsche Wohnen SE violated multiple GDPR principles by storing tenant personal data indefinitely without proper purpose limitation, data minimization, or storage limitation. The housing company failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data protection. The Berlin DPA found systematic violations across Article 5 principles due to the company's failure to establish proper data retention policies and deletion concepts. The fine was reduced from initial proposal due to cooperation and remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures, and previous infringements were aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage and cooperation were mitigating. Other mitigating factors included the company's efforts to improve compliance.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) and (e); DPA found Article 6(1)(c) should be considered as legal basis instead of consent or public task; DPA emphasized candidates should be fully informed about processing.
a75_case_summary: The Examinations Service processed candidate data for statistical scoring methods without proper GDPR compliance. Violations included lack of processor contract under Article 28(1), failure to prove compliance under Article 24(1), and no prior consultation for regulatory measures under Article 36(4). The DPA issued reprimands but no fine due to mitigating factors including pseudonymization measures and absence of fraud.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered Article 83(2) factors: absence of fraud was mitigating; pseudonymization measures were mitigating; categories of data (non-special) were mitigating; detection via complaint rather than self-reporting was aggravating. No fine was imposed based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Tarlun Limited failed to respond to a subject access request within the one-month timeframe required by Article 12(3) GDPR. The controller mistakenly believed the request was about subscription reimbursement and only became aware of the SAR after being notified by the Cyprus SA. The DPA found a violation and issued a reprimand, noting both aggravating (delayed response, lack of procedures) and mitigating factors (no previous violations, eventual compliance, staff training).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/gravity/duration of infringement, negligent character, lack of technical/organizational measures, and manner infringement became known. Mitigating factors included: actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other factors like eventual compliance and staff training. Categories of data affected were considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant stated there was no legal basis for integrating Google Analytics; the DPA found processing occurred without proper legal basis but did not explicitly invalidate any specific legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2021 on the interaction between the application of Article 3 and the provisions on international transfers according to Chapter V of the Regulation
a75_case_summary: The Cyprus DPA found violations by Cyprus News Agency regarding Google Analytics implementation. The defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with accountability principles (Article 5(2)) and did not ensure adequate protection for data transfers to the US (Article 44). The DPA issued reprimands and ordered compliance with the new EU-US Data Protection Framework or appropriate safeguards.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant used Facebook Pixel tool for advertising purposes;DPA found defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with data protection principles;No valid legal basis established for potential data transfers to US
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2021 on the interplay between Article 3 and Chapter V
a75_case_summary: Cypriot newspaper used Facebook Pixel tool;DPA found unlawful data transfers to US without adequate safeguards;Defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with accountability principle;Reprimands issued but no fine imposed due to new EU-US framework

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed perpetual consent and continuing doctor-patient relationship; DPA found no valid legal basis as processing was not necessary for medical diagnosis or treatment purposes under Article 9(2)(h); consent must be specific and cannot be perpetual.
a75_case_summary: A doctor accessed a former patient's medical records in Cyprus's national health system without authorization; DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 9(2)(h) as no doctor-patient relationship existed; defendant claimed perpetual consent and genuine interest but DPA rejected these arguments; reprimand issued instead of fine due to mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included sensitive data access and multiple incidents; mitigating factors included defendant no longer contracted with NHS, cooperation with authority, and no previous infringements; overall assessment led to reprimand instead of fine.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Cyprus SA issued reprimand to financial controller for failing to notify complainant about erasure request action within GDPR timeframe. Controller claimed emails were lost due to volume and complainant used wrong email address. Commissioner found infringement of Articles 12(3) and 24(1) GDPR due to lack of proper procedures for handling data subject rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed. Aggravating: duration of breach, lack of appropriate procedures. Mitigating: no previous violations, cooperation with authority, remedial actions taken. Neutral: categories of personal data affected.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed identification documents were needed to verify identity for data subject access requests under Recital 64 GDPR. The DPA found this excessive as email verification was sufficient and collecting IDs solely for potential requests violates data minimization principles.
a75_case_summary: Technius Ltd violated GDPR by requesting excessive government ID for access requests and inadequate breach communication. The DPA found requesting IDs violated data minimization principles as email verification was sufficient. Blog post breach notification was insufficient despite controller's claims about scale. A reprimand was issued considering mitigating factors including first violation and prompt compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating factors included no previous violations, prompt compliance with requests, and staff training measures. Aggravating factors included inadequate breach communication methods and excessive identification procedures given special category data processing.

a2_authority_name: Commissioner for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for journalistic purposes. The DPA found this basis invalid because the publication of names and photos was not necessary for the journalistic purpose and overrode the data subjects' fundamental rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 for the calculation of administrative sanctions on the basis of GDPR 2016/679
a75_case_summary: A newspaper published names and photos of police investigators involved in detaining an elderly Turkish Cypriot woman at Larnaca airport. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c) and 6(1)(f) as the publication was disproportionate to journalistic purposes and unnecessary for public information. The DPA imposed a €7,000 fine after weighing aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional character as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as mitigating, cooperation as mitigating, and categories of data affected as mitigating. Other factors were not discussed.

a7_defendant_name: Council of Registration of Hairdressers and Barbers of Cyprus
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed employee consent as legal basis for CCTV monitoring. The DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship, citing EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 that consent cannot be freely given in employer-employee contexts.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices;EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Cyprus Hairdressers and Barbers Registration Board installed CCTV in office monitoring employees and visitors without proper legal basis. The DPA found consent invalid due to employer-employee power imbalance. Orders were issued to permanently stop CCTV operation, delete recordings, and provide implementation proof within 2 weeks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: cooperation with authority and absence of previous incidents were mitigating; lack of appropriate legal basis was aggravating. No systematic discussion of all factors occurred.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access (Version 2.0)
a75_case_summary: Brivio Limited failed to respond to a data subject access request within the one-month timeframe required by Article 12(3) GDPR. The controller claimed the request was part of a pattern of manifestly unfounded requests from a law firm, but the Commissioner found each request must be assessed individually regardless of the representative. The Commissioner imposed a €2,000 fine considering both mitigating and aggravating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: the nature/gravity/duration of infringement, lack of appropriate measures, manner infringement became known, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included: actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with supervisory authority.

a2_authority_name: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection in Cyprus
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f); DPA found processing lawful since data was manifestly made public by data subjects on public sources like Google; purpose remained unchanged from original publication of business contact details
a75_case_summary: Senira Limited operated nicelocal.com website collecting business information from public sources; failed to respond to data subject erasure requests within GDPR timeframe; violated Article 12(3) by not acting on requests within one month; violated Article 31 by failing to cooperate with supervisory authority's investigation requests
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; mitigating factors: requests eventually satisfied, no harm occurred, no sensitive data; aggravating factors: increasing complaints, lack of appropriate procedures, lack of response to preliminary decision order

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for journalistic purposes; DPA found publication of photographs excessive and not necessary for public information right; violated minimization principle and invalidated legitimate interest basis
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guideline 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative sanctions on the basis of the GDPR 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Newspaper publisher Breikot Management Ltd published photographs of three complainants in four articles about their family architectural firm continuing public works despite conviction. DPA found violation of Articles 5(1)(c) and 6 GDPR as photographs exceeded journalistic necessity and minimization principle. Administrative Court upheld violation but annulled fine amount, leading to review that maintained original €3,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; negligent character, mitigation actions, cooperation, and first offense as mitigating; data categories as neutral. Fine maintained at €3,000 after review of aggravating and mitigating factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Irish DPC conducted ex officio inspection at Aylo Freesites Ltd (formerly Mindgeek) focusing on cookie consent, biometric data processing, DPIAs and data processing agreements. Multiple GDPR breaches found including accountability, transparency, lawfulness, data minimization, storage limitation, data security and legal basis requirements. Company implemented corrective measures but fined €58,400 total for pre-compliance violations and illegal cookie use.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC considered breaches significant as they occurred four years after GDPR implementation (aggravating). Company's compliance with recommendations and implementation of corrective measures were mitigating factors. Other Art 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Open University of Cyprus suffered a ransomware attack where hackers stole and published personal data of students, graduates, and contractors. The University failed to implement appropriate security measures and violated the accountability principle. The DPA considered mitigating factors including planned security improvements and the University's public sector status, imposing a €45,000 fine and ordering security measures implementation oversight.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered inadequate technical measures as aggravating and the University's cooperation and planned security improvements as mitigating. The University's public sector status was also considered as a mitigating factor in the sanction determination.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for credit assessment purposes; the DPA found violations of accuracy and storage limitation principles due to retention of data beyond legal period; key reasoning was that technical limitations and lack of resources do not excuse non-compliance with GDPR obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Housing Finance Organization retained complainant's loan application data beyond the 6-month retention period; inaccurate data from a 2020 rejected application was used in assessing a 2023 application; the DPA found violations of accuracy, storage limitation, and accountability principles; technical limitations and resource constraints were rejected as justifications for non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, and failure to implement measures; mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage; neutral factor was categories of data affected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for security failures leading to data leak of over 1 million vehicle owners' personal data. Agency found inadequate technical/organizational measures under Article 32 and failure to prescribe maximum retention periods under Article 5(1)(e). Fine reduced due to defendant's public authority status under national implementation law.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed include nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data affected as aggravating, and other mitigating factors (public authority status). Most factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for GDPR violations. HUO failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures under Article 32, compromising personal data security. Additionally, HUO violated Article 5(1)(e) by not prescribing maximum retention periods for personal data. The fine amount considered HUO's status as a legal entity with public authority.

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis for processing but DPA found incorrect information regarding legal basis under Article 6(1); violation of transparency requirements under Article 13(1)
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined debt collection agency B2 Kapital €2,265,000 for multiple GDPR violations. Violations included: failure to properly inform data subjects about processing (Article 13); lack of processor contract for bankruptcy monitoring service (Article 28); inadequate security measures leading to data exfiltration of 77,317 individuals' sensitive financial data (Article 32). The violations lasted from 2018-2023 and were discovered through anonymous tip with USB containing exfiltrated data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of violations; negligent character; categories of data affected; lack of cooperation; failure to implement corrective measures. Mitigating: no specific mitigating actions mentioned. The violations affected at least 132,652 data subjects with sensitive financial data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed property protection but the DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6 as the video surveillance captured public areas and others' properties without consent or legal authorization.
a75_case_summary: An individual installed CCTV cameras on their residential building that captured public areas and neighboring properties without valid legal basis. The Croatian DPA found violations of Article 6 GDPR and national video surveillance laws. The DPA ordered the camera angles to be adjusted within 15 days to only cover the individual's own property boundaries.

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller lacks clear legal basis for scanning identity cards and bank cards. Consent is invalid in employment context due to power imbalance. Legal obligation under labor law does not cover document scanning.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Opinion 249 on the processing of data in the workplace
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA responded to an inquiry about processing employee data through scanning identity cards and bank cards. The DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 GDPR for such processing, noting labor law obligations don't cover document scanning. Consent was deemed invalid due to employer-employee power imbalance, and legitimate interest would require proportionality testing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controllers claimed consent as legal basis for cookie processing but DPA found consent invalid due to cookie banner not allowing clear distinction between purposes and processing occurring before consent was given
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA imposed nine fines totaling €51,000 on controllers for GDPR violations. Gambling operators fined €15,000-€20,000 for invalid cookie consent and transparency violations. Hotels and shops fined €500-€4,000 for inadequate CCTV signage violating national implementation law requirements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controllers claimed consent for cookie processing but DPA found consent invalid due to cookie banner not allowing clear distinction between purposes and processing occurring before consent given
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA imposed nine fines totaling EUR 51,000 on controllers for GDPR violations. Two gambling/betting operators fined EUR 15,000 and EUR 20,000 for invalid cookie consent and transparency violations. Seven retail/hospitality operators fined EUR 16,000 total for inadequate CCTV signage violations under national implementation law.

a7_defendant_name: company for the provision of IT services from Zagreb
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: IT services company failed to implement appropriate technical security measures, leading to unauthorized access by hackers affecting 28,085 data subjects. The processor violated Article 32(1)(b) and (d) and paragraph 2 by not ensuring adequate security against existing risks. The incident was reported by the controller telecommunications company. Given the company's role providing services to major clients including government institutions, the Agency imposed an administrative fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and legitimate interests as legal bases. The DPA found consent invalid after termination of contractual relationship and legitimate interests invalid as the data subject did not reasonably expect further processing.
a75_case_summary: Bank X processed applicant's personal data for marketing purposes after termination of contractual relationship. The DPA found no legal basis as consent was invalid after relationship ended and legitimate interests did not apply since data subject did not reasonably expect further processing. Violations of Article 5(1)(b) purpose limitation and Article 6(1) lawful basis were established. No corrective measures were imposed as processing had already ceased.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest and contract execution as legal bases. DPA invalidated both, finding processing of health data not necessary for intended purpose and legitimate interest test conducted after processing began.
a75_case_summary: EOS Matrix violated GDPR through inadequate security measures allowing data exfiltration, processing non-debtor data without legal basis, processing health data without proper legal basis, failing to transparently inform about health data processing, recording phone calls without legal basis, and failing to inform about call recording. DPA found contract execution and legitimate interest claims invalid for health data processing.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A retail chain was fined HRK 675,000 for failing to implement appropriate security measures under Article 32 GDPR. Employees unauthorizedly recorded and distributed video surveillance footage to social networks and media. The company had organizational measures like employee education but lacked adequate technical and organizational security measures to prevent such incidents.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity/duration as aggravating and technical/organizational measures as aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no specific legal basis but argued the photos were publicly available on social media. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6 for publishing the photos in the specific article context, as it did not relate to the applicant's political activities or media statements.
a75_case_summary: A media company published photos of a political party member from her private Facebook profile in an article about personal relationships. The DPA found the publication lacked lawful purpose and legal basis under Articles 5 and 6 GDPR, as the content did not relate to her political activities. The company was ordered to remove the photos from its portal and inform the DPA of compliance.

a7_defendant_name: Tourist Board of the City of X
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for photography at public event. DPA found legitimate interest valid for general event photography but invalid for using individual child's photo for promotional purposes without consent. DPA determined consent under Article 6(1)(a) was required but not obtained.
a75_case_summary: Tourist Board organized public sports event and photographed attendees including minor child. Used child's individual photo for promotional purposes without consent. DPA found legitimate interest valid for general event photography but invalid for individual promotional use requiring consent. Controller removed photos after complaint but violated Articles 5 and 6 GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (using child's photo without consent), categories of data as aggravating (child's personal data), and remedial actions as mitigating (removing photos after complaint). Other factors not systematically discussed under Article 83(2).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: AZOP fined a bank for violating Article 15(3) GDPR by refusing to provide copies of personal data. The bank received 2577 access requests but denied them, claiming credit documentation wasn't personal data subject to GDPR. AZOP found the documents contained personal data and ordered compliance in 34 prior decisions, but the bank continued non-compliance intentionally to avoid financial costs.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: AZOP discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors: intentional character, prolonged duration, failure to mitigate consequences, non-compliance with prior orders, and financial benefit gained. Mitigating factors: no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and efforts to mitigate damage were considered neutral or mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined Zagrebačka holding €25,000 for GDPR violations. The company failed to properly inform users about legal basis and storage periods when collecting ID copies for email invoice requests. It also lacked adequate technical measures for user identification, inconsistently requiring ID documents based on email address structure.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller could not demonstrate any legal basis for recording telephone conversations despite repeated requests from the Agency, violating Article 6(1) and the accountability principle under Article 5(2).
a75_case_summary: A Croatian special hospital was fined €190,000 for multiple GDPR violations. The hospital failed to implement appropriate technical measures (backups) for radiological image data, leading to irreversible loss of special category health data. It also failed to report the security breach within 72 hours, lacked a processor contract, recorded phone calls without legal basis or proper transparency, and excluded its DPO from key decisions. The hospital claimed cost concerns for backups, but the Agency found this unjustified given the sensitivity of health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Agency considered the nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), technical measures (aggravating), categories of data affected (aggravating), and actions to mitigate damage (mitigating). The hospital failed to correct irregularities, weighing against it.

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was proven for cookie processing. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) existed, violating the lawfulness principle.
a75_case_summary: Gambling companies processed personal data through cookies without legal basis under Article 6(1). They failed to provide adequate information under Article 13 and obtain valid consent under Article 7. The DPA imposed fines of €20,000 and €30,000 for these violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA noted consideration of Article 83(2) factors including nature, severity and duration of violation; intentional or negligent character; and degree of controller responsibility. No specific aggravating or mitigating factors were detailed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no specific legal basis. The DPA found no legitimate purpose or legal basis under Article 6 for publishing personal data on a public notice board. The publication violated privacy as data became accessible to non-tenants.
a75_case_summary: A building co-owner representative posted a court decision containing personal data (name, ID number, property details) on a public notice board. The Croatian DPA found violations of Articles 5 and 6 GDPR as the publication lacked legitimate purpose and legal basis. The data was removed before the decision, so no additional measures were imposed. The publication violated privacy by making data accessible to non-tenants.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the removal of data before the decision as mitigating. No other Article 83(2) factors were discussed.

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected complaint against real estate agency regarding publication of photo showing complainant during apartment viewing. Agency determined the photo did not constitute personal data as the person was wearing a mask and jacket, making identification impossible for an average person. No GDPR violation found as the data did not meet the definition of personal data under Article 4(1).

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: trading company for organizing games of chance - betting games (sports betting)
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for legal obligations under anti-money laundering law, but DPA found this invalid as processing bank card copies was not necessary for compliance with legal obligations.
a75_case_summary: Controller processed bank card copies without legal basis, violating Article 6. Failed to inform data subjects about this processing, violating Article 13. Implemented inadequate technical measures for new payment service, violating Article 25. Stored data without encryption and security assessments, violating Article 32. Financial data processing created high risk to rights and freedoms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered financial data sensitivity as aggravating. Controller's post-supervision cooperation, system improvements, and data deletion were mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests, citing the Media Act as legal basis and noting the public interest in information about social assistance beneficiaries and the applicant's status as a public figure outweighs privacy interests.
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected a complaint alleging unlawful publication of personal data by media companies. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(f) as the applicant was a political party leader and public figure, and the publication served public interest in transparency of social welfare spending. The media companies published minimal necessary data (name and benefit amount) in compliance with Media Act provisions on journalism and public interest.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for survey calls. DPA found this invalid as applicant was not a client/user, no balance test was conducted, and number was in Do Not Call Registry. Human error admission proved lack of appropriate protection measures.
a75_case_summary: Company x called applicant's phone number for survey purposes while number was registered in Do Not Call Registry. DPA found processing unlawful as legitimate interest claim invalid without proper balance test and applicant not being client. Company admitted human error, proving inadequate protection measures. Violations found of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 6, 14, and 17.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined telecommunications provider HRK 2.15M for security failures leading to unauthorized access to 100,000 data subjects' personal data. Controller failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures as required by GDPR Articles 25(1) and 32(1)(b)(d)(2). The breach was reported by the controller under Article 33. Aggravating factors included the company's market position and failure to implement complex security measures despite processing large volumes of personal data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed include nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, technical measures as aggravating, and manner of discovery (self-reporting) as mitigating. The controller's market position was cited as an additional aggravating factor.

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: car sales and service center based in Zagreb
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA conducted ex officio supervision of car sales and service center's CCTV system; Found violation of Article 27(1) of national GDPR implementation law for failing to mark video surveillance areas; Imposed HRK 30,000 administrative fine deemed effective, proportional and deterrent; Fine paid to state budget.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected complaint alleging GDPR violations by municipal office. Office received anonymous letter with intimate photos but couldn't identify data subject. DPA found office acted correctly by refusing access/deletion requests since identity couldn't be established. No evidence of unauthorized data sharing or media publication of personal data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for the performance of a task of public interest under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this legal basis valid as the processing was necessary for delivering guaranteed minimum compensation to the applicant.
a75_case_summary: Applicant claimed Center for Social Welfare disclosed personal data by paying guaranteed minimum compensation through postal service instead of bank account. DPA found no violation as processing had legitimate purpose and legal basis under Article 6(1)(e) for public task performance. Data sharing with postal service was necessary and proportionate for benefit delivery.

a7_defendant_name: hotel manager (legal entity within which the hotel operates)
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary but DPA found no legal basis existed for collecting CVC number and copy of personal documents as reservation was possible without these excessive data
a75_case_summary: Hotel collected excessive personal data (CVC numbers and ID copies) without legal basis during reservations. Failed to provide transparent information about processing through Terms and Conditions. Lacked appropriate technical/organizational security measures. Appointed hotel manager as DPO creating conflict of interest.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal obligation under Budget Act; DPA found no legal basis for publishing names in litigation list; Special regulations require only concise description of disputes, not personal data.
a75_case_summary: Health Center published financial statements including names of litigation opponents on website; DPA found no legal basis for publishing personal data under Budget Act requirements; Controller ordered to delete personal data and implement protective measures; Processing violated GDPR principles of lawfulness, purpose limitation, and data minimization.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The bank claimed processing was necessary under national gambling regulations but the DPA found no valid legal basis existed for publishing excessive personal data (OIB and residential address) beyond what was necessary for transparency purposes.
a75_case_summary: A Croatian bank published excessive personal data of prize winners (including OIB and residential address) on its website during a promotional lottery. The DPA found violations of Articles 5 and 6 GDPR as the bank failed to demonstrate a valid legal basis for publishing this excessive data beyond what was necessary for transparency. The bank claimed compliance with national gambling regulations but the DPA determined this did not justify excessive data publication. An official warning and compliance order were issued as corrective measures.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest as legal basis for publishing anonymized leave schedule;DPA found no legitimate interest proven as proportionality test was not conducted;DPA determined no legal basis existed under Article 6
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found Social Welfare Center violated GDPR by publishing employee leave schedule containing names on bulletin board;Center claimed legitimate interest but failed to conduct proportionality test;DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 and violation of Article 5 principles;Order issued to prohibit further processing without legal basis

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for compliance with legal obligations under the Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act. The DPA found Article 6(1)(c) valid as the company was obliged to establish customer identity through ID card collection. The processing was deemed lawful for fulfilling specific legal obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA rejected a complaint against company Y, an electronic money institution, which requested a copy of the applicant's ID card for customer due diligence under anti-money laundering regulations. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary for compliance with legal obligations under the Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act. The company properly informed the applicant about processing purposes and legal basis as required by Article 13. No GDPR violations were found as the processing was fair, lawful, and transparent.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that Media Act provided legal basis for processing under Article 6 GDPR as special law, and that publication of personal data (name, contract details, payment amount) was justified by public interest in transparency of public fund spending.
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected complaint against media company y for publishing applicant's name and payment details from EU-funded project. DPA found Media Act provided legal basis under Article 6 GDPR, and publication served public interest in transparency of public fund spending. The processing was minimal and proportionate to the purpose of informing public about use of budgetary funds.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found Secondary Vocational School xx violated Articles 25 and 32 GDPR after losing employee documentation containing personal data. The school stored personnel files in locked cabinets but documentation went missing possibly during renovations after weather-related flooding. The DPA ordered the school to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to prevent future data losses.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: HEP-Toplinarstvo stored user passwords in readable form in its database and sent users' actual passwords via email during password reset process. The controller failed to implement basic security measures like encryption or temporary password generation, exposing nearly 16,000 users to security risks. The controller also failed to cooperate with the supervisory authority by not providing necessary information and not taking remedial actions after learning of the breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, the intentional/negligent character as aggravating, lack of cooperation as aggravating, and failure to mitigate damage as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined an information and communication company €50,000 for security failures that led to a hacker attack compromising user data. The controller failed to implement appropriate technical security measures, allowing the attacker complete system access. The violation specifically concerned Article 32(1)(b) and (d) and Article 32(2) regarding security of processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the failure to implement appropriate technical security measures as aggravating, while the controller's immediate response to resolve the security issue was mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Individual installed CCTV cameras that excessively monitored public road area beyond property protection needs. Croatian DPA found violation of national GDPR implementation law Article 32 prohibiting public area monitoring by private entities. Ordered camera angle adjustment and deletion of unlawfully collected recordings.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found the proportionality test inadequate and failed to prove necessity or proper balancing against data subject rights. The controller incorrectly cited national laws as legal basis instead of GDPR provisions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (WP 243 rev.01);Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines (WP 253)
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA fined a business data provider _ d.o.o. €40,000 for multiple GDPR violations. The company processed craft owners' personal data without proper legal basis under Article 6(1)(f), failed transparency obligations under Articles 12-14, maintained inadequate records under Article 30, and appointed a DPO with conflict of interest under Article 38. Violations were discovered through citizen complaints and DPA inspection.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged violations since 2018. Intentional character was aggravating for transparency violations, negligent for others. Previous infringements were aggravating. Cooperation was aggravating due to initial non-cooperation. No damage mitigation was neutral.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers;Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found controller violated GDPR Articles 37(7) and 38(6) by appointing DPO with conflict of interest (company procurator) and failing to publish DPO contact details on website. The DPA determined procurator role involves determining purposes/means of processing, creating conflict with DPO advisory role. Fine imposed based on coordinated EDPB activity investigating DPO positions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/duration of infringement, poor cooperation with authority, failure to resolve conflict of interest. Mitigating: negligent not intentional conduct, actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements. Neutral: manner authority became aware.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes exemption under national law; DPA found processing lawful for journalistic purposes as it served public interest in informing about contradiction between public figure's statements and actions during pandemic; Consent was not required for journalistic processing.
a75_case_summary: Bulgarian DPA examined complaint about media outlet disclosing MP's COVID-19 vaccination status without consent. Found media processing lawful under journalistic purposes exemption as it served public interest in revealing contradiction between public figure's anti-vaccine statements and actual vaccination. However, found doctor and medical center violated Article 32 GDPR for unauthorized access to health data through inadequate security measures for electronic signatures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature of data (special category) and negligence were aggravating; first violation and pandemic workload were mitigating; imposed BGN 500 fine on doctor and official warning to medical center.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The bank claimed legitimate interest basis for marketing but DPA found it invalid since complainant was no longer a customer and didn't meet bank's own criteria for marketing campaigns.
a75_case_summary: Bank sent marketing email to former customer after account closure. DPA found violation of Article 6(1) as legitimate interest basis was invalid for non-customers. Technical measures were inadequate but bank revised them. Warning issued instead of fine due to limited data scope and remedial actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature of data (mitigating), technical measures (aggravating), cooperation (mitigating), and remedial actions (mitigating). No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent was given but handwriting expertise proved the signature was forged. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) as consent was invalid and legitimate interests did not override data subject rights.
a75_case_summary: A political party processed complainant's personal data by forging his signature on election registration lists. Handwriting expertise confirmed the signature was not authentic. The DPA found violation of Article 6(1) as no valid legal basis existed. A fine of BGN 2000 was imposed considering aggravating factors including previous similar violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating circumstances included: irreparable violation, processing of unique civil number, political affiliation creation, restriction of electoral rights, and previous identical violations. Some factors were deemed irrelevant for legal entities.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(a) consent and Article 6(1)(b) pre-contractual steps. The DPA found no legal basis existed for processing personal data by providing it to the National Revenue Agency for employment contract registration since no actual employment contract had been concluded between the parties.
a75_case_summary: The Bulgarian DPA found H.M.B. EAD violated GDPR by processing complainant's personal data without legal basis. The company provided the complainant's data to the National Revenue Agency to register an employment contract that was never actually signed. The DPA determined no valid legal basis existed under Article 6 since no employment contract had been concluded between the parties.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating factors included: first violation, cooperation with authority, and remedial actions taken. Aggravating factors included: processing of national ID number and negative impact on complainant's social benefits. Some factors were deemed irrelevant.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on contractual relations but the DPA found no valid contract existed since the data subject never visited the office or signed the application, making Article 6(1)(b) invalid.
a75_case_summary: A telecommunications operator illegally processed a complainant's personal data by transferring her mobile number without consent or valid legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 due to lack of proper identification procedures and insufficient organizational measures. The controller had previous similar violations and was ordered to improve its data protection policies and pay a reduced fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: duration was mitigating (short period), actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (corrected error quickly), technical measures were aggravating (insufficient controls), previous infringements were aggravating (repeat offender), and cooperation was neutral. Other mitigating factors included no financial benefit and stopping violation voluntarily.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal bases under Art 6(1)(a) consent, (c) legal obligation, and (f) legitimate interests. DPA found none valid as data provision to German authorities was not necessary for employment contract, consent was not specific to this purpose, and legitimate interests did not outweigh data subject's rights given factual errors.
a75_case_summary: Company D. JSC unlawfully provided employee's personal data to German transport authorities for a traffic violation that occurred while employee was on sick leave and vehicle was no longer in company's possession. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (b) with Articles 6(1) as data was processed without valid legal basis. Fine imposed due to intentional violation, irreparable consequences, and failure to correct erroneous information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: intentional nature, irreparable consequences, failure to take corrective measures. Mitigating: cooperation with authority, no previous infringements, reimbursement of fine. Neutral: categories of personal data affected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid as the data subjects' interests took precedence over the political party's interest in participating in elections. No valid consent was obtained and no other legal bases under Article 6(1) were applicable.
a75_case_summary: A Bulgarian political party unlawfully processed complainants' personal data by including them in election registration lists without consent. Handwriting expertise confirmed signatures were forged. The DPA found violations of Articles 6(1), 5(2) and 24 GDPR due to lack of legal basis and inadequate organizational measures. The party was fined 25,000 BGN and ordered to implement proper data protection measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: violation of three individuals' rights; processing of identification numbers; lack of cooperation with DPA; previous identical violations; and the completed nature of infringements. No mitigating circumstances were found. The violation was not the first for this controller.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on error/mistake rather than a valid legal basis. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and held the processing unlawful.
a75_case_summary: A telecommunications operator illegally processed complainant's personal data (name, ID number, phone number) by transferring her mobile number without consent or valid legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 due to inadequate identification procedures and organizational measures. The operator corrected the error quickly but had previous similar violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating: violation stopped quickly, no damages, self-correction. Aggravating: insufficient technical/organizational measures, repeat offender. Neutral: cooperation with authority.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for property protection and child safety. DPA found legitimate interest valid as property protection and child safety interests outweigh data subjects' interests given conflict relations and vandalism evidence.
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged illegal CCTV in co-owned property. DPA found video surveillance lawful under legitimate interest (Art 6(1)(f)) as controller had majority ownership share and demonstrated need for property protection and child safety. DPA cited conflict relations, vandalism evidence, and information stickers as justifying surveillance of common areas.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes but the DPA found the processing unlawful as it violated Article 5 principles; the DPA determined the processing was not done lawfully, fairly, or transparently regardless of journalistic purpose claims.
a75_case_summary: A journalist published a medical diploma and criminal record containing personal data of a doctor on Facebook; the DPA found violations of Article 5 principles regarding lawfulness, fairness, and accuracy; both the journalist and the doctor who provided the data received official warnings; the DPA considered the short publication duration mitigating but the inclusion of third-party data aggravating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly; aggravating factors included nature/gravity and categories of data affected; mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, and other mitigating circumstances; the discussion was not systematic.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that data processing appeared lawful under Article 6(1)(a) as individuals voluntarily provided data and expressly consented to public disclosure through petitions.
a75_case_summary: CPDP investigated Vazrazhdane-Varna for publishing a blacklist of teachers who signed petitions against education law amendments. The DPA found the data originated from publicly available petitions where individuals consented to disclosure. Processing appeared lawful under Article 6(1)(a) as consent was explicitly given for public dissemination.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Interlocutory decision on language of proceedings in complaint against IAB Europe regarding GDPR violations in digital advertising. Belgian DPA maintains French as procedural language but allows parties to use French, Dutch, or English. Decision will be issued in French with Dutch and English translations provided simultaneously.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed execution of contract (Art 6(1)(b)) as legal basis for processing candidate data. The DPA found this valid for both processing operations (mailing lists and portal account creation), dismissing complaints about legality.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found employment agency violated GDPR by failing to properly handle data erasure request. The agency's internal procedure was not followed due to human error, resulting in continued processing. The DPA issued a reprimand but found no violation regarding legal basis or portal account creation. The case involved an isolated incident with mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed several Art 83(2) factors: nature/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was mitigating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were mitigating; other factors were mitigating. The violation was one-off, non-intentional, and the controller took remedial actions.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller failed to establish a valid legal basis for continuing to process the complainant's email data after termination of employment. The Disputes Chamber found no justification under Article 6(1)(a), (b), or (f) GDPR for the continued processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent in accordance with Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA found violations regarding failure to close an employee's professional mailbox after termination and insufficient follow-up to an access request. The defendant failed to delete the mailbox within 1-3 months after employment ended, violating purpose limitation, data minimization, and storage limitation principles. The DPA issued a warning and ordered compliance with the access request within 30 days.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for managing the fan page. The DPA found this invalid as commercial interests cannot override data subject rights, especially after contractual relations ended.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found a record company violated GDPR by managing a Facebook fan page using an artist's name without legal basis after contract termination. The company claimed legitimate interests but DPA ruled commercial interests cannot override data subject rights. The defendant failed to comply with data subject's objection rights and transparency obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity was aggravating due to core GDPR violations. Duration was aggravating as violations lasted over 5 months. Data categories affected was aggravating as personal identity data was involved. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant failed to respond to data subject's erasure request within required timeframe and continued sending promotional emails. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 17.1 GDPR. Ordered defendant to comply with erasure request within 30 days and report outcome to DPA.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest but DPA found it invalid due to lack of necessity and failure of balancing test; initial collection was based on contract necessity; no compatible further processing basis existed.
a75_case_summary: School sent newsletter email to parents with all recipients visible in CC field instead of BCC, disclosing email addresses. DPA found violation of purpose limitation (Art 5(1)(b)) and lack of legal basis for incompatible processing (Art 6). Defendant admitted error but had repeated violations despite guidelines. DPA issued reprimand and compliance order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered defendant's admission of error and willingness to avoid future incidents as mitigating factors. Lack of appropriate technical measures was aggravating. No systematic Art 83(2) discussion conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Recruitment agency failed to respond to data subject's repeated requests for data erasure under Article 17 GDPR. Despite multiple contacts from complainant requesting deletion, defendant continued communications. Dispute Chamber found potential violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 17.1 GDPR and ordered compliance with erasure request within 30 days.

a7_defendant_name: Family Service / The National Service for Promotion of Children's Articles, NV
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent (Art. 6(1)(a)) and legitimate interests (Art. 6(1)(f)) as legal bases. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of freedom, specificity, and informed nature. Legitimate interests were invalid due to insufficient safeguards and failure to pass balancing test.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 216/679
a75_case_summary: The defendant operated a service providing "Pink Boxes" to expectant mothers while trading their personal data to third parties for marketing. The DPA found multiple GDPR violations including invalid consent due to non-free and non-transparent practices, inadequate legal basis for pre-2018 data processing, insufficient transparency, disproportionate retention, and lack of processor agreements. The core issue was disguising data trading activities while presenting as a beneficial service.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringements, intentional/negligent character, inadequate technical measures, previous infringements, categories of data affected, and need for deterrence. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and COVID-19 economic impact. Cooperation with authority was considered neutral.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found controller violated GDPR by failing to comply with data subject's erasure request for email address receiving unwanted marketing emails. Controller requested additional email addresses instead of deleting the problematic address, violating data minimization and accountability principles. The DPA ordered compliance with erasure request within 30 days.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent not free due to lack of alternative; DPA also examined legitimate interests and found data subject interests prevailed; no valid legal basis established.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent within the meaning of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Retailer required electronic ID card scanning for loyalty card creation without alternative. DPA found violations of data minimization (Article 5(1)(c)) due to processing irrelevant data like gender and national register number, and no valid legal basis (Article 6) as consent wasn't free and legitimate interests didn't prevail. Also found transparency violations (Article 13) regarding legal basis and storage period information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to fundamental principle violation and considerable impact on all customers. Also discussed categories of data as aggravating due to national register number processing. No other factors discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA orders public entity Y to comply with data subject's access request regarding consultation of national register; Defendant failed to respond due to non-functional email address; Decision orders compliance within 30 days or case will proceed to merits; This is a preliminary decision under Article 95 LCA, not a final merits decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed forwarding was unintentional error; DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6; Legitimate interest test failed necessity and balancing requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 1/2010 on concepts of controller and processor
a75_case_summary: Accounting firm mistakenly emailed complainant's personal data to former business associate; DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(b), 5(1)(c), and 6 GDPR due to lack of legal basis; Reprimand issued to accounting firm; Second defendant ordered to permanently cease processing the email.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating; intentional/negligent character as mitigating due to human error; actions to mitigate damage as mitigating; previous infringements as mitigating as first offense; cooperation as mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for processing candidate data. The DPA found consent valid for candidates who explicitly consented, and no violation of Articles 6 and 5(2) was established.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation on the appointment of a Data Protection Officer;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: A recruitment consultancy failed to properly respond to a data deletion request and had incomplete transparency documentation. The DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 13.2(b), 30.1(d) and 30.1(g) but noted the defendant's cooperative efforts and modest business size. A reprimand was issued without financial penalty.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the defendant's modest enterprise size, collaborative spirit, and pre-procedure compliance efforts as mitigating factors. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found controller violated GDPR by failing to comply with data subject's erasure request. Complainant requested deletion of email address used for unsolicited marketing emails on November 9 and 14, 2022, but continued receiving emails on January 16, 2023. The DPA ordered the controller to comply with the erasure request within 30 days and notify the Authority of the result.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on his public function as mayor. The DPA found the reuse of citizen contact data for electoral purposes incompatible with the original purpose of collection, violating Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR.
a75_case_summary: A municipal mayor reused citizen contact data collected during his official duties for electoral campaigning. The DPA found this violated purpose limitation principles under Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR. The breach was considered serious due to the electoral context and defendant's public position. A €5,000 fine and reprimand were imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to fundamental principle violation. Intentional character was aggravating as processing was deliberate. Data categories were neutral as only identification data. Other aggravating factors included defendant's public position and electoral context.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued preliminary decision against two financial defendants for failing to respond to data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The Litigation Chamber ordered defendants to comply with the access request within 30 days. This is a prima facie decision that may lead to substantive proceedings if defendants contest or fail to comply.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found consent was valid legal basis for processing candidate data; defendant obtained explicit consent from candidates already in database before GDPR via mailing and from new applicants at time of application.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation on the appointment of a Data Protection Officer;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: Defendant failed to properly respond to data erasure request within required timeframe and provide clear reasons for non-compliance. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 13.2(b), 30.1(d) and 30.1(g) regarding transparency obligations and record keeping. Defendant demonstrated cooperation and made improvements during proceedings. A reprimand was issued considering defendant's modest size and collaborative spirit.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered defendant's modest enterprise size, collaborative spirit, and efforts to improve compliance as mitigating factors. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.
